60ff6101-71eb-4c77-b5ce-df90e81edc8d.text: "What progress, you ask, have I made? I have begun to be a friend to myself." That was indeed a great benefit; such a person can never be alone. You may be sure that such a man is a friend to all mankind.
60ff6101-71eb-4c77-b5ce-df90e81edc8d.author: Marcus Aurelius

3aadcbd4-5734-419f-a386-2b0c128841c6.text: A better wrestler. But not a better citizen, a better person, a better resource in tight places, a better forgiver of faults.
3aadcbd4-5734-419f-a386-2b0c128841c6.author: Marcus Aurelius

82780e92-8b05-4de0-b968-5a4fc815a790.text: A good man does not spy around for the black spots in others, but presses unswervingly on towards his mark.
82780e92-8b05-4de0-b968-5a4fc815a790.author: Marcus Aurelius

a6a34ed1-d64a-4d72-a356-8545f0a1d1e4.text: A key point to bear in mind: The value of attentiveness varies in proportion to its object. You’re better off not giving the small things more time than they deserve.
a6a34ed1-d64a-4d72-a356-8545f0a1d1e4.author: Marcus Aurelius

6b3d44e3-9f76-4e5d-a569-03e0eb30c25e.text: A limit of time is fixed for thee, which if thou dost not use for clearing away the clouds from thy mind, it will go and thou wilt go, and it will never return.
6b3d44e3-9f76-4e5d-a569-03e0eb30c25e.author: Marcus Aurelius

459401bf-fc4d-46f4-a785-088b7a4b4636.text: A little flesh, a little breath, and a Reason to rule all – that is myself.
459401bf-fc4d-46f4-a785-088b7a4b4636.author: Marcus Aurelius

4a8337fb-eef9-4aa1-836a-75239cf83df8.text: A little wisp of soul carrying a corpse.”—Epictetus.
4a8337fb-eef9-4aa1-836a-75239cf83df8.author: Marcus Aurelius

b0120688-feaa-4ded-b00e-62b98a34ad04.text: A man cannot lose a thing if he has it not.
b0120688-feaa-4ded-b00e-62b98a34ad04.author: Marcus Aurelius

1187d82a-94ce-4096-b717-eb3817a3804a.text: A man must stand erect, not be kept erect by others.
1187d82a-94ce-4096-b717-eb3817a3804a.author: Marcus Aurelius

db318000-3a82-4ad5-8386-8e7e8550702b.text: A man when he has done a good act, does not call out for others to come and see, but he goes on to another act, as a vine goes on to produce again the grapes in season.
db318000-3a82-4ad5-8386-8e7e8550702b.author: Marcus Aurelius

c24c4980-6b0d-457d-9024-747dd2f3fd28.text: A Man's life is dyed the color of his imagination.
c24c4980-6b0d-457d-9024-747dd2f3fd28.author: Marcus Aurelius

d5f3bfcd-5c85-4b7f-af6c-2bfb89624048.text: A man’s worth is no greater than the worth of his ambitions.
d5f3bfcd-5c85-4b7f-af6c-2bfb89624048.author: Marcus Aurelius

1fa9c39b-e9b8-4150-8da1-020660556764.text: A noble man compares and estimates himself by an idea which is higher than himself; and a mean man, by one lower than himself. The one produces aspiration; the other ambition, which is the way in which a vulgar man aspires.
1fa9c39b-e9b8-4150-8da1-020660556764.author: Marcus Aurelius

8f92071c-7872-474e-ab06-839d10e16e49.text: A person's worth is measured by the worth of what he values.
8f92071c-7872-474e-ab06-839d10e16e49.author: Marcus Aurelius

a6571a08-fd02-45ae-ad87-f56b2c476026.text: A philosopher without clothes and one without books. “I have nothing to eat,” says he, as he stands there half-naked, “but I subsist on the logos.” And with nothing to read, I subsist on it too.
a6571a08-fd02-45ae-ad87-f56b2c476026.author: Marcus Aurelius

6b934131-750f-430f-9316-1cc44077171c.text: A poor soul burdened with a corpse,' Epictetus calls you.
6b934131-750f-430f-9316-1cc44077171c.author: Marcus Aurelius

3e9c5422-f15c-4c37-b3c9-c66d8ed55e8e.text: A prudent governor will not roughly oppose even the superstitions of his people; and though he may wish that they were wiser, he will know that he cannot make them so by offending their prejudices.
3e9c5422-f15c-4c37-b3c9-c66d8ed55e8e.author: Marcus Aurelius

3ab28096-a995-42e5-bb0b-c678a7af898d.text: A prudent governor will not roughly oppose even the superstitions of his people; and though he may wish they were wiser, he will know that he cannot make them so by offending their prejudices.
3ab28096-a995-42e5-bb0b-c678a7af898d.author: Marcus Aurelius

dfe6caa7-5f96-4bae-81fa-18902df24d5d.text: A ripe mature man, a perfect sound man; one that could not endure to be flattered; able to govern both himself and others.
dfe6caa7-5f96-4bae-81fa-18902df24d5d.author: Marcus Aurelius

6addc57f-2119-4e94-af87-71136c091da4.text: A society of equal laws, governed by equality of status and of speech, and of rulers who respect the liberty of their subjects above all else.
6addc57f-2119-4e94-af87-71136c091da4.author: Marcus Aurelius

16c40195-4be8-4cab-8171-3fdaf749fb5c.text: A very ridiculous thing it is, that any man should dispense with vice and wickedness in himself, which is in his power to restrain; and should go about to suppress it in others, which is altogether impossible.
16c40195-4be8-4cab-8171-3fdaf749fb5c.author: Marcus Aurelius

70a36ebb-910f-4237-a43c-9eefd7d3f358.text: A wrongdoer is often a man who has left something undone, not always one who has done something.
70a36ebb-910f-4237-a43c-9eefd7d3f358.author: Marcus Aurelius

6f8ee134-2604-4898-acf2-5af9c3072c2b.text: Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together,but do so with all your heart.
6f8ee134-2604-4898-acf2-5af9c3072c2b.author: Marcus Aurelius

4c7a91a2-2ca1-46aa-8e4e-7138a8945513.text: Accept the things to which life binds you, and love the people with whom life brings you together, but do so with all your heart.
4c7a91a2-2ca1-46aa-8e4e-7138a8945513.author: Marcus Aurelius

0ce8e626-0fa0-4330-8876-d92a39d5a9b1.text: Accept whatever comes to you woven in the pattern of your destiny, for what could more aptly fit your needs?
0ce8e626-0fa0-4330-8876-d92a39d5a9b1.author: Marcus Aurelius

c857247e-e5fd-454f-b67f-0c6e0f2e51ad.text: Accustom yourself not to be disregarding of what someone else has to say: as far as possible enter into the mind of the speaker.
c857247e-e5fd-454f-b67f-0c6e0f2e51ad.author: Marcus Aurelius

0406c924-9033-4831-99e0-7ca8df97b4e0.text: Adapt yourself to the life you have been given; and truly love the people with whom destiny has surrounded you.
0406c924-9033-4831-99e0-7ca8df97b4e0.author: Marcus Aurelius

d5f9b5ed-a642-4e56-a31d-e37938cb798d.text: Adapt yourself to the things among which your lot has been cast and love sincerely the fellow creatures with whom destiny has ordained that you shall live.
d5f9b5ed-a642-4e56-a31d-e37938cb798d.author: Marcus Aurelius

535fea13-a17b-4489-9a9c-5a2033190adf.text: Alexander the Great and his mule driver both died and the same thing happened to both.
535fea13-a17b-4489-9a9c-5a2033190adf.author: Marcus Aurelius

8b1d82f5-cac4-429e-9bbe-9cd9c78e5949.text: Alexander the Macedonian and his groom by death were brought to the same state; for either they were received among the same seminal principles of the universe, or they were alike dispersed among the atoms.
8b1d82f5-cac4-429e-9bbe-9cd9c78e5949.author: Marcus Aurelius

e41e1d4d-8d3e-44df-b80b-03da85286fee.text: All is ephemeral, both what remembers and what is remembered.
e41e1d4d-8d3e-44df-b80b-03da85286fee.author: Marcus Aurelius

3c28910c-e1d2-48df-baeb-caeee23904c4.text: All men are made one for another: either then teach them better or bear with them.
3c28910c-e1d2-48df-baeb-caeee23904c4.author: Marcus Aurelius

9082a07c-16aa-418a-bb72-e546ed911d93.text: All of us are creatures of a day; the rememberer and the remembered alike.
9082a07c-16aa-418a-bb72-e546ed911d93.author: Marcus Aurelius

cbe2fc80-2900-4ba8-9314-75c7830b3dca.text: All that comes to pass is as familiar and well known as the rose in spring, and the grape in summer. Of like fashion are sickness, death, calumny, intrigue, and all that gladdens or saddens the foolish.
cbe2fc80-2900-4ba8-9314-75c7830b3dca.author: Marcus Aurelius

61f6b496-db76-48cf-94eb-637196c099a3.text: All that exists is the seed of what will emerge from it.
61f6b496-db76-48cf-94eb-637196c099a3.author: Marcus Aurelius

46652b89-c072-46b7-bf95-f243bcde6cdd.text: All these things, which thou seest, change immediately and will no longer be; and constantly bear in mind how many of these changes thou hast already witnessed.
46652b89-c072-46b7-bf95-f243bcde6cdd.author: Marcus Aurelius

40db6211-e1d6-454e-8f3c-2ad69434c175.text: All things fade and quickly turn to myth.
40db6211-e1d6-454e-8f3c-2ad69434c175.author: Marcus Aurelius

1d4e0b59-83c1-44d0-a304-b247d8f11bca.text: All things fade into the storied past, and in a little while are shrouded in oblivion.
1d4e0b59-83c1-44d0-a304-b247d8f11bca.author: Marcus Aurelius

40900de1-33c8-44aa-8660-e292fabb0675.text: All things from eternity are of like forms and come round in a circle.
40900de1-33c8-44aa-8660-e292fabb0675.author: Marcus Aurelius

b6327d66-5b6c-4af7-8ce7-6c6940b83141.text: All things of the body stream away like a river, all things of the mind are dreams and delusion; life is warfare, and a visit to a strange land; the only lasting fame is oblivion.
b6327d66-5b6c-4af7-8ce7-6c6940b83141.author: Marcus Aurelius

b64203d5-873e-4655-9e83-84b21b88ac9f.text: All things soon pass away and become a mere tale, and complete oblivion soon buries them. And I say this of those who have shone in a wondrous way.
b64203d5-873e-4655-9e83-84b21b88ac9f.author: Marcus Aurelius

cc59c43f-eb85-4317-9658-444fb8f88529.text: Ambition means tying your well-being to what other people say or do. Self-indulgence means tying it to the things that happen to you. Sanity means tying it to your own actions.
cc59c43f-eb85-4317-9658-444fb8f88529.author: Marcus Aurelius

6d157604-522f-47fd-9ea7-94f6da835b83.text: And as upon thy face and looks, thy mind hath easily power over them to keep them to that which is grave and decent; so let it challenge the same power over the whole body also.
6d157604-522f-47fd-9ea7-94f6da835b83.author: Marcus Aurelius

54bd7ae8-e251-4bfd-b94a-e6ed1b00c3d3.text: And give up your thirst for books, so that you do not die a grouch, but in true grace and heartfelt gratitude to the god.
54bd7ae8-e251-4bfd-b94a-e6ed1b00c3d3.author: Marcus Aurelius

4fa44df8-9f4a-4f13-bf0d-dc26f9e29b3b.text: And he cares nothing for their praise—men who can’t even meet their own standards.
4fa44df8-9f4a-4f13-bf0d-dc26f9e29b3b.author: Marcus Aurelius

d0162909-7572-4c62-b1b8-831c984e659c.text: And he who pursues pleasure will not abstain from injustice, and this is plainly impiety.
d0162909-7572-4c62-b1b8-831c984e659c.author: Marcus Aurelius

98f72d66-0f8a-4200-9a94-768243eb42d8.text: And in the case of superior things like stars, we discover a kind of unity in separation. The higher we rise on the scale of being, the easier it is to discern a connection even among things separated by vast distances.
98f72d66-0f8a-4200-9a94-768243eb42d8.author: Marcus Aurelius

54fb3ea2-577b-42fe-82d4-3ae4451089d1.text: And indeed he who pursues pleasure as good, and avoids pain as evil, is guilty of impiety.
54fb3ea2-577b-42fe-82d4-3ae4451089d1.author: Marcus Aurelius

3b132d24-4d83-496c-8c5d-c9003569d043.text: And not to think of philosophy as your instructor, but as the sponge and egg white that relieve ophthalmia—as a soothing ointment, a warm lotion.
3b132d24-4d83-496c-8c5d-c9003569d043.author: Marcus Aurelius

0d3ff42f-6a1a-4063-b729-7f9bd44fca1b.text: And so accept everything that happens, even if it is disagreeable, because it leads to this, to the health of the universe and to the prosperity and felicity of Zeus.
0d3ff42f-6a1a-4063-b729-7f9bd44fca1b.author: Marcus Aurelius

30b4f7a7-d698-4db9-8cbd-4dcd02a7848d.text: And that might be applied to him which is recorded of Socrates, that he was able both to abstain from, and to enjoy, those things which many are too weak to abstain from, and cannot enjoy without excess.
30b4f7a7-d698-4db9-8cbd-4dcd02a7848d.author: Marcus Aurelius

7f3e6fb8-991e-44ce-a854-4889bffce402.text: And those who complain and try to obstruct and thwart things—they help as much as anyone. The world needs them as well.
7f3e6fb8-991e-44ce-a854-4889bffce402.author: Marcus Aurelius

a8871179-98f4-4321-9c7b-174feb658e43.text: And thou wilt give thyself relief, if thou doest every act of thy life as if it were the last.
a8871179-98f4-4321-9c7b-174feb658e43.author: Marcus Aurelius

5a42b305-666c-4e1e-a5c0-9f05aaadaf1e.text: And to be easy and ready to be reconciled, and well pleased again with them that had offended me, as soon as any of them would be content to seek unto me again.
5a42b305-666c-4e1e-a5c0-9f05aaadaf1e.author: Marcus Aurelius

b17b3003-8fa1-4c88-82c7-a7fb790bd298.text: And to behave in a conciliatory way when people who have angered or annoyed us want to make up.
b17b3003-8fa1-4c88-82c7-a7fb790bd298.author: Marcus Aurelius

4f88c5cc-61f1-421a-b90e-5effb374c487.text: And to have learned how to accept favors from friends without losing your self-respect or appearing ungrateful.
4f88c5cc-61f1-421a-b90e-5effb374c487.author: Marcus Aurelius

ea2615b6-31c4-4397-a1e7-1dda1576d53c.text: And why is it so hard when things go against you? If it’s imposed by nature, accept it gladly and stop fighting it. And if not, work out what your own nature requires, and aim at that, even if it brings you no glory.
ea2615b6-31c4-4397-a1e7-1dda1576d53c.author: Marcus Aurelius

f4c1c7b0-f1d5-4f4f-921e-251f507abf5d.text: Anger and the sorrow it produces are far more harmful than the things which make us angry.
f4c1c7b0-f1d5-4f4f-921e-251f507abf5d.author: Marcus Aurelius

6cc599f8-2729-4b20-8144-c74ed3c7f13c.text: Another does wrong. What is that to me? Let him look to it; he has his own disposition, his own activity. I have now what Universal Nature wills me to have, and I do what my own nature wills me to do.
6cc599f8-2729-4b20-8144-c74ed3c7f13c.author: Marcus Aurelius

bbd0a0f6-1e29-49f5-88a4-459dbf84919a.text: Another useful point to bear in mind: What qualities has nature given us to counter that defect? As an antidote to unkindness it gave us kindness. And other qualities to balance other flaws.
bbd0a0f6-1e29-49f5-88a4-459dbf84919a.author: Marcus Aurelius

4c6c6a78-05c2-4e6f-8a0c-b96a44f9aa52.text: Anything in any way beautiful derives its beauty from itself and asks nothing beyond itself. Praise is no part of it, for nothing is made worse or better by praise.
4c6c6a78-05c2-4e6f-8a0c-b96a44f9aa52.author: Marcus Aurelius

0c25d69c-8ba6-45a1-ba7b-63544815fd26.text: Anywhere you can lead your life, you can lead a good one.
0c25d69c-8ba6-45a1-ba7b-63544815fd26.author: Marcus Aurelius

db43e0c5-05c0-4c97-9f5c-161a6288f8ef.text: Art thou angry with him whose armpits stink? Art thou angry with him whose mouth smells foul?
db43e0c5-05c0-4c97-9f5c-161a6288f8ef.author: Marcus Aurelius

3082ec44-8772-4a0e-a57c-81934898d243.text: As far as you can, get into the habit of asking yourself in relation to any action taken by another: "What is his point of reference here?" But begin with yourself: examine yourself first.
3082ec44-8772-4a0e-a57c-81934898d243.author: Marcus Aurelius

9481a983-70eb-47ee-98f4-698652b22d7d.text: As for thy thirst after books, away with it with all speed.
9481a983-70eb-47ee-98f4-698652b22d7d.author: Marcus Aurelius

65fbdac7-e847-4dd2-9f95-607bd73dd443.text: As they that long after figs in winter when they cannot be had; so are they that long after children, before they be granted them.
65fbdac7-e847-4dd2-9f95-607bd73dd443.author: Marcus Aurelius

319ee5df-c1e1-4684-a69d-b04cece28f9d.text: Ask yourself at every moment, 'Is this necessary?
319ee5df-c1e1-4684-a69d-b04cece28f9d.author: Marcus Aurelius

3ab85439-6f90-4067-9a5c-666f870a4583.text: At best suffer patiently, if thou canst not suffer joyously.
3ab85439-6f90-4067-9a5c-666f870a4583.author: Marcus Aurelius

18a9a290-99e4-4d29-8b3e-8f58c0aee0cd.text: Attend to the matter before you, whether it is an opinion or an act or a word. You suffer this justly: for you choose rather to become good tomorrow than to be good today.
18a9a290-99e4-4d29-8b3e-8f58c0aee0cd.author: Marcus Aurelius

35336d04-9d40-4d10-9536-000d44efec1e.text: B.C.)—Stoicism stressed the search for inner peace and ethical certainty despite the apparent chaos of the external world by emulating in one’s personal conduct the underlying orderliness and lawfulness of nature.
35336d04-9d40-4d10-9536-000d44efec1e.author: Marcus Aurelius

9c5df0c2-6a37-4382-88ec-2d9cbe433205.text: Be cheerful also, and seek not external help nor the tranquility which others give. A man then must stand erect, not be kept erect by others.
9c5df0c2-6a37-4382-88ec-2d9cbe433205.author: Marcus Aurelius

0c291fe8-8222-4af4-a06f-a17ada503dab.text: Be content to seem what you really are.
0c291fe8-8222-4af4-a06f-a17ada503dab.author: Marcus Aurelius

a44e1781-1e21-4d5a-8c3f-6169c0f752a7.text: Be like the cliff against which the waves continually break; but it stands firm and tames the fury of the water around it.
a44e1781-1e21-4d5a-8c3f-6169c0f752a7.author: Marcus Aurelius

671d7ff1-12df-49ce-8263-392f77d46d04.text: Be not either a man of many words, or busy about too many things.
671d7ff1-12df-49ce-8263-392f77d46d04.author: Marcus Aurelius

54de2c0c-35e2-40c9-bf5b-1e0694b96c80.text: Be not querulous, be Content with little, be kind, be free; avoid all superfluity, all vain prattling; be magnanimous.
54de2c0c-35e2-40c9-bf5b-1e0694b96c80.author: Marcus Aurelius

1a141a1b-fba0-4cf1-b811-d736bd2e35f8.text: Be tolerant with others and strict with yourself.
1a141a1b-fba0-4cf1-b811-d736bd2e35f8.author: Marcus Aurelius

ccc7fa8e-b3fa-4596-905d-8bc42490e34d.text: Be your own master, and look at things as a man, as a human being, as a citizen, as a mortal creature.
ccc7fa8e-b3fa-4596-905d-8bc42490e34d.author: Marcus Aurelius

8a8a4d85-5198-4b67-9077-5658bc8d9fff.text: Bear in mind that everything that exists is already fraying at the edges, and in transition, subject to fragmentation and to rot. Or that everything was born to die.
8a8a4d85-5198-4b67-9077-5658bc8d9fff.author: Marcus Aurelius

85c6abc1-cf0a-4c5b-9097-269048939725.text: Bear in mind that the measure of a man is the worth of the things he cares about.
85c6abc1-cf0a-4c5b-9097-269048939725.author: Marcus Aurelius

9722d506-a744-4cac-a749-2878a819ea2d.text: Beautiful things of any kind are beautiful in themselves and sufficient to themselves. Praise is extraneous. The object of praise remains what it was—no better and no worse.
9722d506-a744-4cac-a749-2878a819ea2d.author: Marcus Aurelius

4a9c85a6-7506-4ff0-bb2f-dec83e80e6cc.text: Because a thing seems difficult for you, do not think it impossible for anyone to accomplish.
4a9c85a6-7506-4ff0-bb2f-dec83e80e6cc.author: Marcus Aurelius

02eda2b0-15ca-400a-a3a1-5cea007b06c1.text: Because most of what we say and do is not essential. If you can eliminate it, you'll have more time and more tranquillity. Ask yourself at every moment, is this necessary….
02eda2b0-15ca-400a-a3a1-5cea007b06c1.author: Marcus Aurelius

03f2cea9-31a7-422b-ac74-d8b1d036543b.text: Because most of what we say and do is not essential. If you can eliminate it, you’ll have more time, and more tranquillity. Ask yourself at every moment, “Is this necessary?”
03f2cea9-31a7-422b-ac74-d8b1d036543b.author: Marcus Aurelius

443443c3-ae7c-4ab6-b93c-8428bdf2d099.text: Because your own strength is unequal to the task, do not assume that it is beyond the powers of man; but if anything is within the powers and province of man, believe that it is within your own compass also.  Marcus Aurelius.
443443c3-ae7c-4ab6-b93c-8428bdf2d099.author: Marcus Aurelius

7fe421f5-4786-41b9-8d14-d0793a3cc63e.text: Begin each day by telling yourself: Today I shall be meeting with interference, ingratitude, insolence, disloyalty, ill-will, and selfishness – all of them due to the offenders’ ignorance of what is good or evil.
7fe421f5-4786-41b9-8d14-d0793a3cc63e.author: Marcus Aurelius

89462e15-5031-4ea3-9705-4667dfd59c87.text: BEGIN the morning by saying to thyself, I shall meet with the busy-body, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial.
89462e15-5031-4ea3-9705-4667dfd59c87.author: Marcus Aurelius

6b972be4-c3d0-4d5e-822a-fcad358d295d.text: Begin the morning by saying to thyself, I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happen to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil.
6b972be4-c3d0-4d5e-822a-fcad358d295d.author: Marcus Aurelius

a2617f1a-b7eb-4fc0-bc82-ba8809a55b13.text: Blame and praise have no true effects.
a2617f1a-b7eb-4fc0-bc82-ba8809a55b13.author: Marcus Aurelius

da472e7f-2948-45c2-bd75-91a441af463f.text: But by all means bear this in mind, that within a very short time both thou and he will be dead; and soon not even your names will be left behind.
da472e7f-2948-45c2-bd75-91a441af463f.author: Marcus Aurelius

e397e33f-cf5d-4aa0-b2f1-161b2c93b01a.text: But cast away the thirst after books, that thou mayest not die murmuring, but cheerfully, truly, and from thy heart thankful to the gods.
e397e33f-cf5d-4aa0-b2f1-161b2c93b01a.author: Marcus Aurelius

f5475a38-a7cc-40e8-8c0e-ff434be64be5.text: But death and life, honor and dishonor, pain and pleasure—all these things equally happen to good men and bad, being things which make us neither better nor worse. Therefore they are neither good nor evil.
f5475a38-a7cc-40e8-8c0e-ff434be64be5.author: Marcus Aurelius

aa0d0898-fe50-47fe-aa51-b575bdeddb9d.text: But death and life, success and failure, pain and pleasure, wealth and poverty, all these happen to good and bad alike, and they are neither noble or shameful—and hence neither good nor bad.
aa0d0898-fe50-47fe-aa51-b575bdeddb9d.author: Marcus Aurelius

745ebd16-4e83-4ca6-81d6-b1a259e88f91.text: But death certainly, and life, honour and dishonour, pain and pleasure, all these things equally happen to good men and bad, being things which make us neither better nor worse. Therefore they are neither good nor evil.
745ebd16-4e83-4ca6-81d6-b1a259e88f91.author: Marcus Aurelius

32065b4c-61ac-4b57-8773-6e5ef55524c7.text: But fortunate means that a man has assigned to himself a good fortune: and a good fortune is good disposition of the soul, good emotions, good actions.
32065b4c-61ac-4b57-8773-6e5ef55524c7.author: Marcus Aurelius

54b42482-a360-4294-9e98-106ed64ea601.text: Call to mind the whole of Substance of which you have a very small portion, and the whole of time whereof a small hair's breadth has been determined for you, and of the chain of causation whereof you are how small a link.
54b42482-a360-4294-9e98-106ed64ea601.author: Marcus Aurelius

5334ce1f-d797-429b-a150-a29dabe28e45.text: Casting aside other things, hold to the precious few; and besides bear in mind that every man lives only the present, which is an indivisible point, and that all the rest of his life is either past or is uncertain.
5334ce1f-d797-429b-a150-a29dabe28e45.author: Marcus Aurelius

58e1df85-a756-49cd-b97c-7d60d9985f95.text: Casting therefore all other things aside, keep thyself to these few, and remember withal that no man properly can be said to live more than that which is now present, which is but a moment of time.
58e1df85-a756-49cd-b97c-7d60d9985f95.author: Marcus Aurelius

825bac25-2e19-447b-9cc9-84d8fef124ce.text: Choose not to be harmed—and you won’t feel harmed.
825bac25-2e19-447b-9cc9-84d8fef124ce.author: Marcus Aurelius

c2c9cf95-b34d-4699-a2ac-807efda06ff0.text: Choose not to be harmed—and you won’t feel harmed. Don’t feel harmed—and you haven’t been.
c2c9cf95-b34d-4699-a2ac-807efda06ff0.author: Marcus Aurelius

29ed48b7-65e2-4aea-be09-dcf08b8e8d01.text: Consider how much more pain is brought on us by the anger and vexation caused by such acts than by the acts themselves, at which we are angry and vexed.
29ed48b7-65e2-4aea-be09-dcf08b8e8d01.author: Marcus Aurelius

f4ffddb8-84d0-40f6-b9b6-a96386300a4a.text: Consider how quickly all things are dissolved and resolved.
f4ffddb8-84d0-40f6-b9b6-a96386300a4a.author: Marcus Aurelius

9f188d44-8d2a-4919-b123-4baab2d2a037.text: Consider how quickly all things are dissolved and resolved: the bodies and substances themselves, into the matter and substance of the world: and their memories into the general age and time of the world.
9f188d44-8d2a-4919-b123-4baab2d2a037.author: Marcus Aurelius

71857d54-21d5-455e-9d11-520d348c2bbd.text: Consider that everything is opinion, and opinion is in thy power. Take away then, when thou choosest, thy opinion, and like a mariner, who has doubled the promontory, thou wilt find calm, everything stable, and a waveless bay.
71857d54-21d5-455e-9d11-520d348c2bbd.author: Marcus Aurelius

c6a4cfe8-e62a-437d-ae25-53d67958fd10.text: Consider yourself to be dead, and to have completed your life up to the present time; and now live according to nature the remainder which is allowed you.
c6a4cfe8-e62a-437d-ae25-53d67958fd10.author: Marcus Aurelius

ff252888-47f8-4438-a032-979c392a2ec4.text: Continually, and, if possible, in the case of every mental image, consider its nature, realize its emotional content, and judge it rationally.
ff252888-47f8-4438-a032-979c392a2ec4.author: Marcus Aurelius

d45101ea-3da8-4b22-8369-d44a95bcdcc8.text: Death hangs over thee. While thou livest, while it is in thy power, be good.
d45101ea-3da8-4b22-8369-d44a95bcdcc8.author: Marcus Aurelius

e6662be6-363d-4ba6-b384-c0f0ed4a4b77.text: Death is a cessation from the impression of the senses, the tyranny of the passions, the errors of the mind, and the servitude of the body.
e6662be6-363d-4ba6-b384-c0f0ed4a4b77.author: Marcus Aurelius

1a829dd1-50af-47a9-894f-743845e22ed4.text: Death is a cessation of the impressions through the senses, and of the pulling of the strings that move the appetites, and of the discursive movements of the thoughts, and of the service to the flesh.
1a829dd1-50af-47a9-894f-743845e22ed4.author: Marcus Aurelius

e2b497a8-688e-4a66-a6da-fef5bcd3b3aa.text: Death is a release from the impressions of the senses, and from desires that make us their puppets, and from the vagaries of the mind, and from the hard service of the flesh.
e2b497a8-688e-4a66-a6da-fef5bcd3b3aa.author: Marcus Aurelius

17954788-2008-47ea-83b6-6a2d846f5f96.text: Death is such as generation is, a mystery of nature; a composition out of the same elements, and a decomposition into the same.
17954788-2008-47ea-83b6-6a2d846f5f96.author: Marcus Aurelius

c8bea66f-d17b-4abb-b441-48148ef32ed7.text: Death smiles at us all, all a man can do is smile back.
c8bea66f-d17b-4abb-b441-48148ef32ed7.author: Marcus Aurelius

2aa08a4d-53a7-4ac3-8eec-6ada4b48325b.text: Death smiles at us all; all we can do is smile back.
2aa08a4d-53a7-4ac3-8eec-6ada4b48325b.author: Marcus Aurelius

19e688a1-8d43-450e-bb2d-90e70d2490a1.text: Death. The end of sense-perception, of being controlled by our emotions, of mental activity, of enslavement to our bodies.
19e688a1-8d43-450e-bb2d-90e70d2490a1.author: Marcus Aurelius

a75232cd-e152-4f48-84d1-f9ee4d467daf.text: Dig deep; the water- goodness- is down there. And as long as you keep digging, it will keep bubbling up.
a75232cd-e152-4f48-84d1-f9ee4d467daf.author: Marcus Aurelius

7f461e74-5c24-44b0-bf23-ee9880761c19.text: Dig within. Within is the wellspring of Good; and it is always ready to bubble up, if you just dig.
7f461e74-5c24-44b0-bf23-ee9880761c19.author: Marcus Aurelius

41a7cbbb-1a4a-4106-9dea-9f41cbc62e04.text: Disgraceful: for the soul to give up when the body is still going strong.
41a7cbbb-1a4a-4106-9dea-9f41cbc62e04.author: Marcus Aurelius

d7238ccc-8f85-4583-9560-75684726db06.text: Do every act of your life as if it were your last.
d7238ccc-8f85-4583-9560-75684726db06.author: Marcus Aurelius

6cd8bee6-8edb-4828-8bb5-1fd9b793c662.text: Do every act of your life as though it were the very last act of your life.
6cd8bee6-8edb-4828-8bb5-1fd9b793c662.author: Marcus Aurelius

fb0b6ffb-e9bd-48cb-9192-9dcaa81f1d98.text: Do external things distract you? Then make time for yourself to learn something worthwhile; stop letting yourself be pulled in all directions.
fb0b6ffb-e9bd-48cb-9192-9dcaa81f1d98.author: Marcus Aurelius

d0b75c5b-6abd-40b3-9913-804db7ef9b82.text: Do not act as if thou wert going to live ten thousand years. Death hangs over thee. While thou livest, while it is in thy power, be good.
d0b75c5b-6abd-40b3-9913-804db7ef9b82.author: Marcus Aurelius

bd52ac3e-d341-4740-a5bf-04a277d48082.text: Do not act as if you had ten thousand years to live ... while you have life in you, while you still can, make yourself good.
bd52ac3e-d341-4740-a5bf-04a277d48082.author: Marcus Aurelius

2b49553e-270f-48e3-9ab9-5dbbafec3d5f.text: Do not act as if you had ten thousand years to throw away. Death stands at your elbow. Be good for something while you live and it is in your power.
2b49553e-270f-48e3-9ab9-5dbbafec3d5f.author: Marcus Aurelius

5f224fe2-1ab4-44a3-9c6b-52527f9edf9e.text: Do not act as if you were going to live ten thousand years. Death hangs over you. While you live, while it is in your power, be good.
5f224fe2-1ab4-44a3-9c6b-52527f9edf9e.author: Marcus Aurelius

a509cb16-0fcb-447c-a955-a46867ae1963.text: Do not be ashamed of help.
a509cb16-0fcb-447c-a955-a46867ae1963.author: Marcus Aurelius

775ec1eb-135a-4447-9fce-f424ecd3ab79.text: Do not indulge in dreams of having what you have not, but reckon up the chief of the blessings you do possess, and then thankfully remember how you would crave for them if they were not yours.
775ec1eb-135a-4447-9fce-f424ecd3ab79.author: Marcus Aurelius

caa47a4e-c622-4f16-a71d-3fb1c6a80f9a.text: Do not let the future disturb you, for you will arrive there, if you arrive, with the same reason you now apply to the present.
caa47a4e-c622-4f16-a71d-3fb1c6a80f9a.author: Marcus Aurelius

9450555c-eeed-45fe-82f4-1f96ebaff574.text: Do not look around to discover other people's ruling principles, but look straight to this, to what nature leads you, both the universal nature through which things happen to you, and your own nature through the acts which must be done by you.
9450555c-eeed-45fe-82f4-1f96ebaff574.author: Marcus Aurelius

53dd2124-9553-46ec-89fd-aa0453407815.text: Do not suppose you are hurt, and your complaint ceases; cease your complaint, and you are not hurt.
53dd2124-9553-46ec-89fd-aa0453407815.author: Marcus Aurelius

dc50c326-f0c6-402e-b831-70a3384e90ed.text: Do not think that what is hard for you to master is humanly impossible; and if it is humanly possible, consider it to be within your reach.
dc50c326-f0c6-402e-b831-70a3384e90ed.author: Marcus Aurelius

9f415f34-e210-4188-95ac-7ba10531eb64.text: Do not waste the remainder of thy life in thoughts about others, when thou dost not refer thy thoughts to some object of common utility.
9f415f34-e210-4188-95ac-7ba10531eb64.author: Marcus Aurelius

e06686ff-4b9d-4f56-ab85-f979525c93ad.text: Do nothing against thy will, nor contrary to the community, nor without due examination, nor with reluctancy.
e06686ff-4b9d-4f56-ab85-f979525c93ad.author: Marcus Aurelius

133751a3-e284-49c3-9f72-d6cb6ec0c65a.text: Do the things external which fall upon thee distract thee? Give thyself time to learn something new and good, and cease to be whirled around.
133751a3-e284-49c3-9f72-d6cb6ec0c65a.author: Marcus Aurelius

887a5d77-25c5-418a-aa95-b7c8d07b7c36.text: Do what you will. Even if you tear yourself apart, most people will continue doing the same things.
887a5d77-25c5-418a-aa95-b7c8d07b7c36.author: Marcus Aurelius

44bfbeea-f298-435f-a50d-dcaf7fb36f77.text: Do you have reason? I have. Why then do you not use it? For if reason does its own work, what else could you wish for?
44bfbeea-f298-435f-a50d-dcaf7fb36f77.author: Marcus Aurelius

dc7cf7e3-250a-469f-9b70-20cc45094f0d.text: Do, soul, do; abuse and contemn thyself; yet a while and the time for thee to respect thyself, will be at an end.
dc7cf7e3-250a-469f-9b70-20cc45094f0d.author: Marcus Aurelius

d8d136c1-87a7-4ddd-a456-951960e9bec4.text: Does a man offend your pride? Remember he will be dead soon, as will you.
d8d136c1-87a7-4ddd-a456-951960e9bec4.author: Marcus Aurelius

f5bb4131-5dd3-4ea6-9f2a-5dd9a668bd4a.text: Does another do me wrong? Let him look to it. He has his own disposition, his own activity. I now have what the universal nature wills me to have; and I do what my nature now wills me to do.
f5bb4131-5dd3-4ea6-9f2a-5dd9a668bd4a.author: Marcus Aurelius

936b5596-65ae-4e93-8985-9cd7f3d04b6c.text: Does the emerald lose its beauty for lack of admiration?
936b5596-65ae-4e93-8985-9cd7f3d04b6c.author: Marcus Aurelius

d17bc667-2f8d-493c-8b50-da45aad91cad.text: Does the emerald lose its beauty for lack of admiration? Does gold, or ivory, or purple? A lyre or a dagger, a rosebud or a sapling?
d17bc667-2f8d-493c-8b50-da45aad91cad.author: Marcus Aurelius

fb5815b3-276c-4409-a16d-8bd8ef84b600.text: Don't live as though you were going to live a myriad years. Fate is hanging over your head; while you have life, while you may, become good.
fb5815b3-276c-4409-a16d-8bd8ef84b600.author: Marcus Aurelius

d22571f1-94cc-449a-8da3-5c36a97264d9.text: Don’t be ashamed to need help. Like a soldier storming a wall, you have a mission to accomplish. And if you’ve been wounded and you need a comrade to pull you up? So what?
d22571f1-94cc-449a-8da3-5c36a97264d9.author: Marcus Aurelius

2855d5b6-7d9b-4d95-bb52-5e599998da1c.text: Don’t imagine that something is good for you if, in pursuing it, you must break a promise, harm anyone else, lose self-respect, act hypocritically, or hide in shame.
2855d5b6-7d9b-4d95-bb52-5e599998da1c.author: Marcus Aurelius

6cb749a2-8cb0-4799-bbb2-ab9a289fd141.text: Don’t look at things the way wrong-doers do. Don’t look at things as wrong-doers want you too, either. Instead, strive to see things in truth, as they really are.
6cb749a2-8cb0-4799-bbb2-ab9a289fd141.author: Marcus Aurelius

ac5c1bf9-250f-4817-9705-3dfdd818de37.text: Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them.
ac5c1bf9-250f-4817-9705-3dfdd818de37.author: Marcus Aurelius

ef17387b-8b2b-42f0-8a2f-8165f85d9d8e.text: Each of us lives only now, in this brief instant. The rest of our life has been lived already, or is impossible to see because it lies in the unknowable future.
ef17387b-8b2b-42f0-8a2f-8165f85d9d8e.author: Marcus Aurelius

6a2e2c9d-8f59-41f1-bf62-42deaf49b937.text: Either teach them better if it be in thy power; or if it be not, remember that for this use, to bear with them patiently, was mildness and goodness granted unto thee.
6a2e2c9d-8f59-41f1-bf62-42deaf49b937.author: Marcus Aurelius

130f593a-9e4e-4b7e-bbd5-27e24dba0a67.text: Enter their minds, and you'll find the judges you're so afraid of—and how judiciously they judge themselves.
130f593a-9e4e-4b7e-bbd5-27e24dba0a67.author: Marcus Aurelius

c6febbd6-760e-452d-9b4d-3de9d9733603.text: Even chance is not divorced from nature, from the inweaving and and enfolding of things governed by Providence.
c6febbd6-760e-452d-9b4d-3de9d9733603.author: Marcus Aurelius

25d01865-ea3e-46cf-be3b-859e244ac441.text: Even the least of our activities ought to have some end in view.
25d01865-ea3e-46cf-be3b-859e244ac441.author: Marcus Aurelius

bf412630-b009-42fb-8b66-8953465c7fe4.text: Even when the gods stood on the side of righteousness, they were concerned with the act more than with the intent.
bf412630-b009-42fb-8b66-8953465c7fe4.author: Marcus Aurelius

5879d408-784e-4f39-93f4-887307fe9266.text: Every living organism is fulfilled when it follows the right path for its own nature.
5879d408-784e-4f39-93f4-887307fe9266.author: Marcus Aurelius

7a6a4b23-3269-442a-a415-9c246d5afdcf.text: Every man is worth   just so much as the things are worth about which he busies himself. .
7a6a4b23-3269-442a-a415-9c246d5afdcf.author: Marcus Aurelius

55151515-6422-4efc-92cd-611a0edacbca.text: Every man is worth just so much as the things about which he busies himself.
55151515-6422-4efc-92cd-611a0edacbca.author: Marcus Aurelius

e9dc8b3d-e98d-4fc7-a040-11489e4e864c.text: Every man is worth just so much as the things are worth about which he busies himself.
e9dc8b3d-e98d-4fc7-a040-11489e4e864c.author: Marcus Aurelius

28535844-50c2-4af6-8cd6-3e78f45f4cf8.text: Every man's happiness depends from himself, but behold thy life is almost at an end, whiles affording thyself no respect, thou dost make thy happiness to consist in the souls, and conceits of other men.
28535844-50c2-4af6-8cd6-3e78f45f4cf8.author: Marcus Aurelius

10c828fe-1265-4a42-8312-46949dc2aed9.text: Every portion of me will be reassigned as another portion of the world, and that in turn transformed into another. Ad infinitum.
10c828fe-1265-4a42-8312-46949dc2aed9.author: Marcus Aurelius

002b6c5d-09b8-42f3-b0c4-dde93e2ec3c5.text: Everything - a horse, a vine - is created for some duty... For what task, then, were you yourself created?
002b6c5d-09b8-42f3-b0c4-dde93e2ec3c5.author: Marcus Aurelius

1fbd5525-3e01-4e35-8cec-d27bf5302050.text: Everything is banal in experience, fleeting in duration, sordid in content; in all respects the same today as generations now dead and buried have found it to be.
1fbd5525-3e01-4e35-8cec-d27bf5302050.author: Marcus Aurelius

bd2a36fc-28a7-4f69-af63-0bbede6a7ca0.text: Everything is interwoven, and the web is holy; none of its parts are unconnected. They are composed harmoniously, and together they compose the world. One world, made up of all things. One divinity, present in them all.
bd2a36fc-28a7-4f69-af63-0bbede6a7ca0.author: Marcus Aurelius

ee524388-7c90-41e5-8712-600f85e2a22a.text: Everything is only for a day, both that which remembers and that which is remembered.
ee524388-7c90-41e5-8712-600f85e2a22a.author: Marcus Aurelius

f1ed1a76-bb0e-4852-bb1a-9b75f88df0ac.text: Everything of the body is a river. Everything of the soul is dream and vapour. Life is war and the abode of a stranger. The only fame after death is oblivion.
f1ed1a76-bb0e-4852-bb1a-9b75f88df0ac.author: Marcus Aurelius

843749b7-3cd2-4219-98e2-36c12b3dff4b.text: Everything that exists is in a manner the seed of that which will be.
843749b7-3cd2-4219-98e2-36c12b3dff4b.author: Marcus Aurelius

23db8b44-1831-41ba-bf78-cf00cb3b74ba.text: Everything that happens is either endurable or not. If it’s endurable, then endure it. Stop complaining. If it’s unendurable … then stop complaining. Your destruction will mean its end as well.
23db8b44-1831-41ba-bf78-cf00cb3b74ba.author: Marcus Aurelius

36e6ec44-404f-4aef-9e6f-cbc3223c1baa.text: Everything that happens, happens as it should, and if you observe carefully, you will find this to be so.
36e6ec44-404f-4aef-9e6f-cbc3223c1baa.author: Marcus Aurelius

e8d6aeb1-6446-4cd1-9ab9-3d74d0e62fc3.text: Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact. Everything we see is a perspective, not the truth.
e8d6aeb1-6446-4cd1-9ab9-3d74d0e62fc3.author: Marcus Aurelius

dbcf7350-e9ff-4128-92b6-ee373ccdc29c.text: Everything which belongs to the body is a stream, and what belongs to the soul is a dream.
dbcf7350-e9ff-4128-92b6-ee373ccdc29c.author: Marcus Aurelius

5cc1ddee-ee23-49ab-8633-bdd2fe571db2.text: Everywhere, at each moment, you have the option: to accept this event with humility, to treat this person as he should be treated, or to approach this thought with care, so that nothing irrational creeps in.
5cc1ddee-ee23-49ab-8633-bdd2fe571db2.author: Marcus Aurelius

c04f638a-7b93-42a4-a267-7d78d32c795d.text: Everywhere, at each moment, you have the option: to accept this event with humility; to treat this person as he should be treated; to approach this thought with care, so that nothing irrational creeps in.
c04f638a-7b93-42a4-a267-7d78d32c795d.author: Marcus Aurelius

2a4948f0-6398-437a-9843-3bc25d40acda.text: External things are not the problem. It’s your assessment of them. Which you can erase right now. If the problem is something in your own character, who’s stopping you from setting your mind straight?
2a4948f0-6398-437a-9843-3bc25d40acda.author: Marcus Aurelius

880c523a-02db-4c24-a406-ceda4c2c67c4.text: Failure to observe what is in the mind of another has seldom made a man unhappy; but those who do not observe the movements of their own minds must of necessity be unhappy.
880c523a-02db-4c24-a406-ceda4c2c67c4.author: Marcus Aurelius

ea2c768d-940f-4834-a862-fc81dd5cd968.text: Failure to read what is happening in another's soul is not easily seen as a cause of unhappiness: but those who fail to attend the motions of their own soul are necessarily unhappy.
ea2c768d-940f-4834-a862-fc81dd5cd968.author: Marcus Aurelius

c17e7bd8-8515-46b8-94f3-46dab406048a.text: Fame in a world like this is worthless.
c17e7bd8-8515-46b8-94f3-46dab406048a.author: Marcus Aurelius

45c732c1-9fd1-4921-92aa-f6ffb548c5a0.text: Finally, in every event which leads you to sorrow, remember to use this principle: that this is not a misfortune, but that to bear it like a brave man is good fortune.
45c732c1-9fd1-4921-92aa-f6ffb548c5a0.author: Marcus Aurelius

b637ffd4-2f36-433e-bad3-4f32b02230d5.text: Finally, therefore, remember your retreat into this little domain which is yourself, and above all be not disturbed nor on the rack, but be free and look at things as a man, a human being, a citizen, a creature that must die.
b637ffd4-2f36-433e-bad3-4f32b02230d5.author: Marcus Aurelius

ef191c0f-fae4-461d-aa01-cd965ae52f2a.text: Finally, waiting for death with a cheerful mind, as being nothing else than a dissolution of the elements of which every living being is compounded.
ef191c0f-fae4-461d-aa01-cd965ae52f2a.author: Marcus Aurelius

8176d3db-c920-4dde-9dd3-ce50c4a4c208.text: For a man cannot lose either the past or the future: for what a man has not, how can any one take this from him?
8176d3db-c920-4dde-9dd3-ce50c4a4c208.author: Marcus Aurelius

2186fd62-c683-4e40-a293-ea24147c435b.text: For a man to be proud and high conceited, that he is not proud and high conceited, is of all kind of pride and presumption, the most intolerable.
2186fd62-c683-4e40-a293-ea24147c435b.author: Marcus Aurelius

3e937d99-1c82-4549-877f-8a1e8b55f19b.text: For all things fade and turn to fable, and quickly too, utter oblivion covers them like sand.
3e937d99-1c82-4549-877f-8a1e8b55f19b.author: Marcus Aurelius

393ac603-48ef-4307-ae3f-dfe2ea5eb0af.text: For in those things that properly belong unto the mind, she cannot be hindered by any man.
393ac603-48ef-4307-ae3f-dfe2ea5eb0af.author: Marcus Aurelius

6c9fc9d9-6246-472c-bca2-6687491d3371.text: For it is according to nature, and nothing is evil which is according to nature.
6c9fc9d9-6246-472c-bca2-6687491d3371.author: Marcus Aurelius

abc578cc-5263-44d1-9c36-d5c8f808604e.text: For it is in your power to retire into yourself whenever you choose.
abc578cc-5263-44d1-9c36-d5c8f808604e.author: Marcus Aurelius

27b54c82-637e-441b-b8fc-2b822c6ac4d4.text: For outward show is a wonderful perverter of the reason.
27b54c82-637e-441b-b8fc-2b822c6ac4d4.author: Marcus Aurelius

43641b16-312c-4a41-9d5e-6c2b7d7d58b8.text: For the entire earth is but a point, and the place of your own habitation but a minute corner in it. Remember then to withdraw into the little field of self. Above all, never struggle or strain; but be master of yourself.
43641b16-312c-4a41-9d5e-6c2b7d7d58b8.author: Marcus Aurelius

85af2b4a-5a92-4a77-a55f-f200141b2dd7.text: For the present is the only thing of which a man can be deprived, if it is true that this is the only thing which he has, and that a man cannot lose a thing if he has it not.
85af2b4a-5a92-4a77-a55f-f200141b2dd7.author: Marcus Aurelius

61238b3e-6c5f-4746-ab4c-6aac78d2c31d.text: For the sole thing of which any man can be deprived is the present; since this is all he owns, and nobody can lose what is not his.
61238b3e-6c5f-4746-ab4c-6aac78d2c31d.author: Marcus Aurelius

5085887c-3a68-427e-a81b-9b8707ba46b0.text: For then thou wilt neither blame those who offend involuntarily, nor wilt thou want their approbation, if thou lookest to the sources of their opinions and appetites.
5085887c-3a68-427e-a81b-9b8707ba46b0.author: Marcus Aurelius

c6100668-1a45-4ac4-9422-6c293ff1af35.text: For we are made for co-operation, like feet, like hands, like eyelids, like the rows of the upper and lower teeth. To act against one another then is contrary to nature; and it is acting against one another to be vexed and to turn away.
c6100668-1a45-4ac4-9422-6c293ff1af35.author: Marcus Aurelius

c115d2d4-ea52-4bf1-a8e8-08c66125ddb2.text: Forget everything else. Keep hold of this alone and remember it: Each of us lives only now, this brief instant. The rest has been lived already, or is impossible to see.
c115d2d4-ea52-4bf1-a8e8-08c66125ddb2.author: Marcus Aurelius

d4dc7309-1083-4dcc-a9e4-28c8ec637281.text: Forget everything else. Keep hold of this alone and remember it: Each of us lives only now, this brief instant. The rest has been lived already, or is impossible to see. The span we live is small—small.
d4dc7309-1083-4dcc-a9e4-28c8ec637281.author: Marcus Aurelius

aab0351a-d53f-4594-a4bc-fe6d3e3d398b.text: From my grandfather Verus I learned good morals and the government of my temper.
aab0351a-d53f-4594-a4bc-fe6d3e3d398b.author: Marcus Aurelius

3677dc92-868a-4d14-bc99-a04d116829ca.text: From my Great-grandfather, not to have frequented public schools, and to have had good teachers at home, and to know that on such things a man should spend liberally.
3677dc92-868a-4d14-bc99-a04d116829ca.author: Marcus Aurelius

54b6660b-6a98-49d6-9775-f7f1f370519e.text: From my great-grandfather: not to have attended schools for the public; to have had good teachers at home, and to realize that this is the sort of thing on which one should spend lavishly.
54b6660b-6a98-49d6-9775-f7f1f370519e.author: Marcus Aurelius

5c62d051-cf20-487c-90a6-1e2c743db617.text: From the philosopher Catulus, never to be dismissive of a friend's accusation, even if it seems unreasonable, but to make every effort to restore the relationship to its normal condition.
5c62d051-cf20-487c-90a6-1e2c743db617.author: Marcus Aurelius

e5c027e3-3c93-4400-aa84-fe204e289c48.text: Give thyself time to learn something new and good, and cease to be whirled around.
e5c027e3-3c93-4400-aa84-fe204e289c48.author: Marcus Aurelius

c09b617e-b26f-4d6d-9fca-db31fe799ec2.text: Give up your thirst for books so that you do not die a grouch.
c09b617e-b26f-4d6d-9fca-db31fe799ec2.author: Marcus Aurelius

d4e59c70-b1b4-4d85-8125-394bf9660483.text: Give up your thirst for books, so that you do not die a grouch.
d4e59c70-b1b4-4d85-8125-394bf9660483.author: Marcus Aurelius

a5a8ee1d-7c5d-4e1d-8195-831271dd22b5.text: Give what thou wilt, and take away what thou wilt, saith he that is well taught and truly modest, to Him that gives, and takes away. And it is not out of a stout and peremptory resolution, that he saith it, but in mere love, and humble submission.
a5a8ee1d-7c5d-4e1d-8195-831271dd22b5.author: Marcus Aurelius

6ddec670-2131-4600-9940-53ead922086e.text: Give your heart to the trade you have learnt, and draw refreshment from it.
6ddec670-2131-4600-9940-53ead922086e.author: Marcus Aurelius

30e3a5f5-8ee5-49f3-9bd7-d88e62482412.text: God give me patience, to reconcile with what I am not able to change Give me strength to change what I can And give me wisdom to distinguish one from another.
30e3a5f5-8ee5-49f3-9bd7-d88e62482412.author: Marcus Aurelius

b3b6f443-0f9e-49ee-a253-03762b0c05ed.text: He blind, who cannot see with the eyes of his understanding.
b3b6f443-0f9e-49ee-a253-03762b0c05ed.author: Marcus Aurelius

55df024e-337c-47b1-8838-8ecf1ee24d7a.text: He claimed that a man's life should be valued according to the value of the things to which he gave his attention.
55df024e-337c-47b1-8838-8ecf1ee24d7a.author: Marcus Aurelius

e3156d99-5616-4b8d-97ac-9d6e9e4298d6.text: He is an abscess on the universe who withdraws and separates himself from the reason of our common nature through being displeased with the things that happen; for the same nature that produces these things has produced you, too.
e3156d99-5616-4b8d-97ac-9d6e9e4298d6.author: Marcus Aurelius

13875902-95ab-47f6-b5fa-dd77c05f84c8.text: He is so rich, he has no room to shit.
13875902-95ab-47f6-b5fa-dd77c05f84c8.author: Marcus Aurelius

5ae2fca9-2cbb-4621-afdf-2f24ae4420ff.text: He may not be profound, he is always sincere.
5ae2fca9-2cbb-4621-afdf-2f24ae4420ff.author: Marcus Aurelius

aaab5e16-61ab-4b9d-be14-4de295705eec.text: He that knoweth not what the world is, knoweth not where he himself is. And he that knoweth not what the world was made for, cannot possibly know either what are the qualities, or what is the nature of the world.
aaab5e16-61ab-4b9d-be14-4de295705eec.author: Marcus Aurelius

a92bf084-3ac4-4384-9a8e-50e428faa057.text: He that sinneth, sinneth unto himself. He that is unjust, hurts himself, in that he makes himself worse than he was before. Not he only that committeth, but he also that omitteth something, is oftentimes unjust.
a92bf084-3ac4-4384-9a8e-50e428faa057.author: Marcus Aurelius

1a4f0653-db3f-4cdb-8ba4-05cb5484ca6c.text: He was taught to dress plainly and to live simply, to avoid all softness and luxury.
1a4f0653-db3f-4cdb-8ba4-05cb5484ca6c.author: Marcus Aurelius

1c7613ef-1c08-4235-85f3-a5ddbf5b2926.text: HE WHO ACTS UNJUSTLY ACTS IMPIOUSLY.
1c7613ef-1c08-4235-85f3-a5ddbf5b2926.author: Marcus Aurelius

b23b09e4-ed09-4d83-b299-9a123a9f23f7.text: He who eats my bread does my will.
b23b09e4-ed09-4d83-b299-9a123a9f23f7.author: Marcus Aurelius

6cd03557-b31a-4aa2-8010-c7032b42b129.text: He who follows reason in all things is both tranquil and active at the same time, and also cheerful and collected.
6cd03557-b31a-4aa2-8010-c7032b42b129.author: Marcus Aurelius

a735cab2-4c10-4b91-8ae8-60d009570cd2.text: He who has seen the present has seen everything, that which happened in the most distant past and that which will happen in the future.
a735cab2-4c10-4b91-8ae8-60d009570cd2.author: Marcus Aurelius

51240543-f225-457b-8033-f68de7dbd8df.text: He who loves fame considers another man’s activity to be his own good; and he who loves pleasure, his own sensations; but he who has understanding, considers his own acts to be his own good.
51240543-f225-457b-8033-f68de7dbd8df.author: Marcus Aurelius

0da4e5d7-deb6-4f78-9de9-8dd25922adc6.text: Here is a rule to remember in future, when anything tempts you to feel bitter: not "This is misfortune," but "To bear this worthily is good fortune."
0da4e5d7-deb6-4f78-9de9-8dd25922adc6.author: Marcus Aurelius

bea9ebcb-17b1-4c36-9885-ed06241e3f25.text: Honor and revere the gods, treat human beings as they deserve, be tolerant with others and strict with yourself. Remember, nothing belongs to you but your flesh and blood—and nothing else is under your control.
bea9ebcb-17b1-4c36-9885-ed06241e3f25.author: Marcus Aurelius

bb00e2c2-bc0d-421f-9cfe-7a0897b0e1c3.text: How free from all vanity he carried himself in matter of honour and dignity, (as they are esteemed:) his laboriousness and assiduity, his readiness to hear any man, that had aught to say tending to any common good.
bb00e2c2-bc0d-421f-9cfe-7a0897b0e1c3.author: Marcus Aurelius

5e853dfd-7bb6-40c0-a70b-0ef08f196502.text: How good it is, when you have roast meat or suchlike foods before you, to impress on your mind that this is the dead body of a fish, this the dead body of a bird or pig.
5e853dfd-7bb6-40c0-a70b-0ef08f196502.author: Marcus Aurelius

bd3e9dcc-a64b-4bfb-a95d-dc05bf388915.text: How many of them who came into the world at the same time when I did, are already gone out of it? LII.
bd3e9dcc-a64b-4bfb-a95d-dc05bf388915.author: Marcus Aurelius

8e1c780c-be3b-432b-af0a-5d7ebda710ed.text: How many together with whom I came into the world are already gone out of it.
8e1c780c-be3b-432b-af0a-5d7ebda710ed.author: Marcus Aurelius

a9bd3282-ea0d-41d0-b455-361bfb53ab1a.text: How much more grievous are the consequences of anger than the causes of it.
a9bd3282-ea0d-41d0-b455-361bfb53ab1a.author: Marcus Aurelius

701d5d5c-c595-4a2e-92e4-217c913f5eb2.text: How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does or thinks, but only at what he does himself, to make it just and holy.
701d5d5c-c595-4a2e-92e4-217c913f5eb2.author: Marcus Aurelius

4505c563-42a5-427b-8a56-cb3188ef86f3.text: How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbour says or does or thinks, but only at what he does himself, to make it just and holy.
4505c563-42a5-427b-8a56-cb3188ef86f3.author: Marcus Aurelius

40c3b1ea-7aaa-4933-95c3-724aa0bc3a55.text: How much time he saves who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does or thinks.
40c3b1ea-7aaa-4933-95c3-724aa0bc3a55.author: Marcus Aurelius

183a2415-7e5b-4dde-ac44-df6c6b25537e.text: How plain does it appear that there is not another condition of life so well suited for philosophising as this in which thou now happenest to be.
183a2415-7e5b-4dde-ac44-df6c6b25537e.author: Marcus Aurelius

76ffd2fd-2e26-4a81-aea6-80c7d5065625.text: How ridiculous and how strange to be surprised at anything which happens in life.
76ffd2fd-2e26-4a81-aea6-80c7d5065625.author: Marcus Aurelius

0709d9e8-4528-4758-84c3-7bfc8cfd810c.text: How ridiculous and unrealistic is the man who is astonished at anything that happens in life.
0709d9e8-4528-4758-84c3-7bfc8cfd810c.author: Marcus Aurelius

591a78ed-9abd-4bb3-8350-058164ba1d2d.text: How ridiculous and what a stranger he is who is surprised at anything that happens in life.
591a78ed-9abd-4bb3-8350-058164ba1d2d.author: Marcus Aurelius

a485b3b0-09a8-40ce-99a9-d5282cad7360.text: How ridiculous and what a stranger he is who is surprised at anything which happens in life.
a485b3b0-09a8-40ce-99a9-d5282cad7360.author: Marcus Aurelius

c3b9b628-d395-436a-8974-065aefeee9d2.text: How ridiculous not to flee from one's own wickedness, which is possible, yet endeavour to flee from another's, which is not.
c3b9b628-d395-436a-8974-065aefeee9d2.author: Marcus Aurelius

5f1cda7e-080e-47e4-9a9c-4b61e89a5b47.text: How rotten and spurious is the man who says: “I have decided to be straightforward with you.”
5f1cda7e-080e-47e4-9a9c-4b61e89a5b47.author: Marcus Aurelius

45d9616a-5648-454f-ab6f-cc7fd870d8fa.text: How soon will time cover all things.
45d9616a-5648-454f-ab6f-cc7fd870d8fa.author: Marcus Aurelius

71e2bc3a-4019-431d-aed6-2a671f5d2104.text: How unsound and insincere is he who says, I have determined to deal with thee in a fair way.—What art thou doing, man?
71e2bc3a-4019-431d-aed6-2a671f5d2104.author: Marcus Aurelius

2e4508f1-2971-44f9-ad81-30e1f587e86d.text: Humans have come into being for the sake of each other, so either teach them, or learn to bear them.
2e4508f1-2971-44f9-ad81-30e1f587e86d.author: Marcus Aurelius

b516ae3f-bcc6-460c-a829-5510ca4998d8.text: I am happy, though this has happened to me, because I continue free from pain, neither crushed by the present nor fearing the future.
b516ae3f-bcc6-460c-a829-5510ca4998d8.author: Marcus Aurelius

d2026db8-2cf7-45a4-b997-c34c73c6788e.text: I am unhappy, because this has happened to me.” Not so: say, “I am happy, though this has happened to me, because I continue free from pain, neither crushed by the present nor fearing the future.”
d2026db8-2cf7-45a4-b997-c34c73c6788e.author: Marcus Aurelius

88d8e761-f48b-43fa-b3c3-e17249ddab9f.text: I can control my thoughts as necessary; then how can I be troubled? What is outside my mind means nothing to it. Absorb that lesson and your feet stand firm.
88d8e761-f48b-43fa-b3c3-e17249ddab9f.author: Marcus Aurelius

1db5d4f6-5e67-49d3-b8c3-8fd44c49395b.text: I do my duty: other things trouble me not; for they are either things without life, or things without reason, or things that have rambled and know not the way.
1db5d4f6-5e67-49d3-b8c3-8fd44c49395b.author: Marcus Aurelius

8b03eed3-f100-4256-87ae-2dcce77356f6.text: I do not regard a man as poor, if the little which remains is enough for him.
8b03eed3-f100-4256-87ae-2dcce77356f6.author: Marcus Aurelius

1a1dc95f-c170-4236-8720-0e98996e7b97.text: I have no right to do myself an injury. Have I ever injured anyone else if I could avoid it?
1a1dc95f-c170-4236-8720-0e98996e7b97.author: Marcus Aurelius

d7915c9c-37f9-4f8b-9d8f-41f8be590449.text: I have often wondered how it is that every man loves himself more than all the rest of men, but yet sets less value on his own opinion of himself than on the opinion of others.
d7915c9c-37f9-4f8b-9d8f-41f8be590449.author: Marcus Aurelius

0de85ced-6b3a-4e0d-88b6-f48edf881ab5.text: I learned endurance of labour, and to want little, and to work with my own hands, and not to meddle with other people's affairs, and not to be ready to listen to slander.
0de85ced-6b3a-4e0d-88b6-f48edf881ab5.author: Marcus Aurelius

a6cb2a4b-56ed-4959-b42b-53e695529e06.text: I was once a fortunate man but at some point fortune abandoned me.  But true good fortune is what you make for yourself. Good fortune: good character, good intentions, and good actions.
a6cb2a4b-56ed-4959-b42b-53e695529e06.author: Marcus Aurelius

af9cedd7-cc53-4096-81ad-04f6af5656b6.text: I was once a fortunate man but at some point fortune abandoned me. But true good fortune is what you make for yourself. Good fortune: good character, good intentions, and good actions.
af9cedd7-cc53-4096-81ad-04f6af5656b6.author: Marcus Aurelius

09b235eb-116c-4423-9dcf-faf9c96cdac1.text: If any man can convince and show me that I do not think or act right, I will gladly change; for I seek truth, by which no man was ever injured. But he is injured who abides in his error and ignorance.
09b235eb-116c-4423-9dcf-faf9c96cdac1.author: Marcus Aurelius

381f7e51-7115-4f9b-a701-8d7acb1132de.text: If any man despises me, that is his problem. My only concern is not doing or saying anything deserving of contempt.
381f7e51-7115-4f9b-a701-8d7acb1132de.author: Marcus Aurelius

8368dce7-c76d-4f19-8cef-6eaeb8bcbe0f.text: If any man is able to convince me and show me that I do not think or act right, I will gladly change; for I seek the truth by which no man was ever injured. But he is injured who abides in his error and ignorance.
8368dce7-c76d-4f19-8cef-6eaeb8bcbe0f.author: Marcus Aurelius

2b4a07ff-8497-4151-ac3d-7e5e3b1833d6.text: If anyone can refute me—show me I’m making a mistake or looking at things from the wrong perspective—I’ll gladly change. It’s the truth I’m after, and the truth never harmed anyone. What harms us is to persist in self-deceit and ignorance.
2b4a07ff-8497-4151-ac3d-7e5e3b1833d6.author: Marcus Aurelius

6c0b96ad-e8fe-426c-8611-1f35774838a6.text: If anyone can show me, and prove to me, that I am wrong in thought or deed, I will gladly change. I think the truth , which never yet hurt anybody. It is only persistence and self-delusion and ignorance which does harm.
6c0b96ad-e8fe-426c-8611-1f35774838a6.author: Marcus Aurelius

c325d349-6352-4ebe-9bc7-e98e5af549c1.text: If it doesn't harm your character, how can it harm your life?
c325d349-6352-4ebe-9bc7-e98e5af549c1.author: Marcus Aurelius

1294a1a7-c5c7-4915-8527-840c6c16542f.text: If our intellectual part is common, the reason also, in respect of which we are rational beings, is common: if this is so, common also is the reason which commands us what to do, and what not to do.
1294a1a7-c5c7-4915-8527-840c6c16542f.author: Marcus Aurelius

56712efa-d2d5-4ef4-980d-4a9b9c3f2b79.text: If some one tells you that so and so speaks ill of you, do not defend yourself against what he says, but answer, 'He did not know my other faults, or he would not have mentioned these alone.'
56712efa-d2d5-4ef4-980d-4a9b9c3f2b79.author: Marcus Aurelius

bee98b2a-deb6-4874-aeb5-ca2ad0edd65f.text: If someone can prove me wrong and show me my mistake in any thought or action, I shall gladly change. I seek the truth, which never harmed anyone: the harm is to persist in one's own self-deception and ignorance.
bee98b2a-deb6-4874-aeb5-ca2ad0edd65f.author: Marcus Aurelius

3915710a-9612-4a8c-b762-b4f2d0baff80.text: If someone is able to show me that what I think or do is not right, I will happily change, for I seek the truth, by which no one was ever truly harmed. It is the person who continues in his self-deception and ignorance who is harmed.
3915710a-9612-4a8c-b762-b4f2d0baff80.author: Marcus Aurelius

8602ebcb-a17b-4847-9db1-f73ca062a957.text: If something is difficult for you to accomplish, do not then think it impossible for any human being; rather, if it is humanly possible and corresponds to human nature, know that it is attainable by you as well.
8602ebcb-a17b-4847-9db1-f73ca062a957.author: Marcus Aurelius

fb918a3b-dfca-414f-abdf-dd60385f0bcd.text: If there were anything harmful on the other side of death, they would have made sure that the ability to avoid it was within you.
fb918a3b-dfca-414f-abdf-dd60385f0bcd.author: Marcus Aurelius

4422f02c-5a5a-4914-a716-c6e2c35d6c78.text: If therefore it be a thing external that causes thy grief, know, that it is not that properly that doth cause it, but thine own conceit and opinion concerning the thing: which thou mayest rid thyself of, when thou wilt.
4422f02c-5a5a-4914-a716-c6e2c35d6c78.author: Marcus Aurelius

63f74dee-6187-4eea-abaf-79813abd3799.text: If they’ve made a mistake, correct them gently and show them where they went wrong. If you can’t do that, then the blame lies with you. Or no one.
63f74dee-6187-4eea-abaf-79813abd3799.author: Marcus Aurelius

d42e24b4-d30e-44d0-992b-e9a3cb9bc738.text: If thou art pained by any external thing, it is not this that disturbs thee, but thy own judgment about it. And it is in thy power to wipe out this judgment now.
d42e24b4-d30e-44d0-992b-e9a3cb9bc738.author: Marcus Aurelius

8837f987-803d-4649-87ae-b182e6a8cfa7.text: If unwilling to rise in the morning, say to thyself, ‘I awake to do the work of a man.
8837f987-803d-4649-87ae-b182e6a8cfa7.author: Marcus Aurelius

94bb7a5c-1634-486f-ae13-ae2a92de783f.text: If within the power of another, whom do you blame—atoms or gods? To do either is folly.
94bb7a5c-1634-486f-ae13-ae2a92de783f.author: Marcus Aurelius

e432a173-0504-4078-b0d4-14169bcb24f7.text: If you are distressed about anything, the pain is not due to the thing but to your own estimate of it.
e432a173-0504-4078-b0d4-14169bcb24f7.author: Marcus Aurelius

9f30b252-49cb-4a07-8c90-f76f4ce9edb1.text: If you are distressed about anything, the pain is not one to the thing but to your own estimate to it.
9f30b252-49cb-4a07-8c90-f76f4ce9edb1.author: Marcus Aurelius

068dcd5f-efe7-4a14-894e-7de05dbeb26a.text: If you are distressed by anything external, the pain is not due to the thing itself, but to your estimate of it; and this you have the power to revoke at any moment.
068dcd5f-efe7-4a14-894e-7de05dbeb26a.author: Marcus Aurelius

3071487f-7318-4008-ab0f-2e94b9c7f7ca.text: If you are pained by external things, it is not they that disturb you, but your own judgement of them. And it is in your power to wipe out that judgement now.
3071487f-7318-4008-ab0f-2e94b9c7f7ca.author: Marcus Aurelius

640e7bdb-cee2-4cfb-a998-4579815273d3.text: If you find something very difficult to achieve yourself, don’t imagine it impossible—for anything possible and proper for another person can be achieved as easily by you.
640e7bdb-cee2-4cfb-a998-4579815273d3.author: Marcus Aurelius

987aa4fa-34c9-4ea4-b166-7c1611612e26.text: If you suffer distress because of some external cause, it is not the thing itself that troubles you but your judgement about it, and it is within your power to cancel that judgement at any moment.
987aa4fa-34c9-4ea4-b166-7c1611612e26.author: Marcus Aurelius

65c7bc97-93d2-41d9-af23-074bcb03837e.text: If you’re honest and straightforward and mean well, it should show in your eyes. It should be unmistakable.
65c7bc97-93d2-41d9-af23-074bcb03837e.author: Marcus Aurelius

4b94f0ed-8b9f-4833-b6dc-cb01632b4c0e.text: III. Hippocrates having cured many sicknesses, fell sick himself and died.
4b94f0ed-8b9f-4833-b6dc-cb01632b4c0e.author: Marcus Aurelius

831d4653-b245-4ddd-92a2-616e11d7234e.text: In a little while you will have forgotten everything; in a little while everything will have forgotten you.
831d4653-b245-4ddd-92a2-616e11d7234e.author: Marcus Aurelius

87c3dcb9-4a2b-4077-adeb-130db7450ee0.text: In a sense, people are our proper occupation. Our job is to do them good and put up with them.
87c3dcb9-4a2b-4077-adeb-130db7450ee0.author: Marcus Aurelius

f754988a-abc2-4e98-bc93-a325b184f5f7.text: In an expression of true gratitude, sadness is conspicuous only by its absence.
f754988a-abc2-4e98-bc93-a325b184f5f7.author: Marcus Aurelius

e27b0511-ff58-4daf-8aab-31e7372e55f8.text: In everything that you do, pause and ask yourself if death is a dreadful thing because it deprives you of this.
e27b0511-ff58-4daf-8aab-31e7372e55f8.author: Marcus Aurelius

4e9c7941-b9c8-46a5-accd-0ad24e4d83df.text: In no great while you will be no one and nowhere, and nothing that you now behold will be in existence, nor will anyone now alive. For it is in the nature of all things to change and alter and perish, so that others may arise in their turn.
4e9c7941-b9c8-46a5-accd-0ad24e4d83df.author: Marcus Aurelius

916adbe2-d6a9-45f4-978b-b6735a9f27e9.text: In the morning when thou risest unwillingly, let this thought be present - I am rising to the work of a human being. Why then am I dissatisfied if I am going to do the things for which I exist and for which I was brought into the world?
916adbe2-d6a9-45f4-978b-b6735a9f27e9.author: Marcus Aurelius

ddda9d35-298f-47e3-adf3-9d2ad25d5d9c.text: IN THE morning when thou risest unwillingly, let this thought be present- I am rising to the work of a human being. Why then am I dissatisfied if I am going to do the things for which I exist and for which I was brought into the world?
ddda9d35-298f-47e3-adf3-9d2ad25d5d9c.author: Marcus Aurelius

0cb7f918-dbda-4ad0-b359-64866826339d.text: In the ways of Nature there is no evil to be found.
0cb7f918-dbda-4ad0-b359-64866826339d.author: Marcus Aurelius

4bf6a59e-e481-44e9-9173-ef7e15fc8da4.text: In this infinity then what is the difference between him who lives three days and him who lives three generations? Always.
4bf6a59e-e481-44e9-9173-ef7e15fc8da4.author: Marcus Aurelius

425a2644-28fa-43b1-a136-ff5d17c331d3.text: In your actions, don't procrastinate. In your conversations, don't confuse. In your thoughts, don't wander. In your soul, don't be passive or aggressive. In your life, don't be all about business.
425a2644-28fa-43b1-a136-ff5d17c331d3.author: Marcus Aurelius

3d88c68c-d14c-4daf-b922-e43ec1c4e7a2.text: Is an emerald suddenly flawed if no one admires it?
3d88c68c-d14c-4daf-b922-e43ec1c4e7a2.author: Marcus Aurelius

b7f98204-4eae-47eb-9721-88feaa12229e.text: Is any man so foolish as to fear change, to which all things that once were not owe their being? And what is it, that is more pleasing and more familiar to the nature of the universe?
b7f98204-4eae-47eb-9721-88feaa12229e.author: Marcus Aurelius

cd1ebf85-2a91-4d32-b6a4-9f9a62a1ba3f.text: Is any man so foolish as to fear change, to which all things that once were not owe their being? And.
cd1ebf85-2a91-4d32-b6a4-9f9a62a1ba3f.author: Marcus Aurelius

29dda395-1485-416f-ae05-ae1958cd3759.text: Is this what I was created for? To huddle under the blankets and stay warm?
29dda395-1485-416f-ae05-ae1958cd3759.author: Marcus Aurelius

6f90fc41-10eb-4d10-b0a3-bfaa54f22d17.text: It can ruin your life only if it ruins your character. Otherwise it cannot harm you—inside or out.
6f90fc41-10eb-4d10-b0a3-bfaa54f22d17.author: Marcus Aurelius

adb46ff2-7c72-4e9a-802f-7474e75b383f.text: It is a ridiculous thing for a man not to fly from his own badness, which is indeed possible, but to fly from other men's badness, which is impossible.
adb46ff2-7c72-4e9a-802f-7474e75b383f.author: Marcus Aurelius

a361997c-9f80-49fa-85c1-fcef1f8c41d7.text: It is a shame when the soul is first to give way in this life, and the body does not give way.
a361997c-9f80-49fa-85c1-fcef1f8c41d7.author: Marcus Aurelius

31c623e4-fd00-450c-81b8-7c136f129b7b.text: It is crazy to want what is impossible. And impossible for the wicked not to do so.
31c623e4-fd00-450c-81b8-7c136f129b7b.author: Marcus Aurelius

210f03d7-1a25-439d-880d-f6b990fd2b3f.text: It is high time for thee, to understand that there is somewhat in thee, better and more divine than either thy passions, or thy sensual appetites and affections.
210f03d7-1a25-439d-880d-f6b990fd2b3f.author: Marcus Aurelius

6f0989c7-0fbe-4416-89c9-c0cc8c596486.text: It is in our power to have no opinion about a thing and not to be disturbed in our soul; for things themselves have no natural power to form our judgments.
6f0989c7-0fbe-4416-89c9-c0cc8c596486.author: Marcus Aurelius

e91e0d18-9314-4353-bd44-1f6b0537daec.text: It is in your own power to maintain the beauty of your soul, or to be a decent human being.
e91e0d18-9314-4353-bd44-1f6b0537daec.author: Marcus Aurelius

77cab892-2562-4008-8fef-7cc387c40a79.text: It is in your power to withdraw yourself whenever you desire. Perfect tranquility within consists in the good ordering of the mind, the realm of your own.
77cab892-2562-4008-8fef-7cc387c40a79.author: Marcus Aurelius

78099d24-0e2f-45bf-89af-fb644f7d6206.text: It is man's peculiar duty to love even those who wrong him.
78099d24-0e2f-45bf-89af-fb644f7d6206.author: Marcus Aurelius

2ac7ed25-9c80-4201-a280-32632d529b8a.text: It is no evil for things to undergo change, and no good for things to subsist in consequence of change.
2ac7ed25-9c80-4201-a280-32632d529b8a.author: Marcus Aurelius

34eea02f-7bbf-4efc-9757-089e2596d5d3.text: It is not death that a man should fear, but he should fear never beginning to live.
34eea02f-7bbf-4efc-9757-089e2596d5d3.author: Marcus Aurelius

92c4d90d-2c32-444a-86ac-c7c5d5907ffb.text: It is not death that a man should fear, but rather he should fear never beginning to live.
92c4d90d-2c32-444a-86ac-c7c5d5907ffb.author: Marcus Aurelius

43c36964-a106-4fb6-88cf-366050430406.text: It is not fit that I should give myself pain, for I have never intentionally given pain even to another.
43c36964-a106-4fb6-88cf-366050430406.author: Marcus Aurelius

5dfccb30-4840-434b-93f9-557a7a5ccc85.text: It is only this present, a moment of time, that a man lives: all the rest either has been lived or may never be.
5dfccb30-4840-434b-93f9-557a7a5ccc85.author: Marcus Aurelius

1859ef8e-e7d2-4ee1-8529-0e34bab2d801.text: It is only this present, a moment of time, that a man lives: all the rest either has been lived or may never.
1859ef8e-e7d2-4ee1-8529-0e34bab2d801.author: Marcus Aurelius

173a3d21-f37f-4e0f-8ead-9b96c0b3715b.text: It is ridiculous not to escape from one’s own vices, which is possible, while trying to escape the vices of others, which is impossible.
173a3d21-f37f-4e0f-8ead-9b96c0b3715b.author: Marcus Aurelius

6b37413f-09e8-4dd8-904f-2757c04a5aec.text: It is royal to do good and to be abused.
6b37413f-09e8-4dd8-904f-2757c04a5aec.author: Marcus Aurelius

200344df-ac51-424f-a103-55eb5c1352a9.text: It is the act of an ill-instructed man to blame others for his own bad condition; it is the act of one who has begun to be instructed, to lay the blame on himself; and of one whose instruction is completed, neither to blame another, nor himself.
200344df-ac51-424f-a103-55eb5c1352a9.author: Marcus Aurelius

28783ad8-49c5-43fe-9853-410e8a9ec1c4.text: It is within our power not to make a judgement about something, and so not disturb our minds; for nothing in itself possesses the power to form our judgements.
28783ad8-49c5-43fe-9853-410e8a9ec1c4.author: Marcus Aurelius

cd9d6744-99df-49a0-a7bb-d4b29b2d237a.text: It is, in other words, not objects and events but the interpretations we place on them that are the problem. Our duty is therefore to exercise stringent control over the faculty of perception, with the aim of protecting our mind from error.
cd9d6744-99df-49a0-a7bb-d4b29b2d237a.author: Marcus Aurelius

ed311334-ee2a-4ef4-8310-4aff2c47cb77.text: It isn't ceasing to live that I'm afraid of but never beginning to live properly.
ed311334-ee2a-4ef4-8310-4aff2c47cb77.author: Marcus Aurelius

0e3595c2-813a-4401-a2c9-2c1940806f3f.text: It never ceases to amaze me: we all love ourselves more than other people, but care more about their opinion than our own.
0e3595c2-813a-4401-a2c9-2c1940806f3f.author: Marcus Aurelius

ff5f7e17-a9d0-4030-bf18-8b2da5f4ce46.text: It never ceases to amaze me: we all love ourselves more than other people, but care more about their opinions than our own.
ff5f7e17-a9d0-4030-bf18-8b2da5f4ce46.author: Marcus Aurelius

b61396f2-be01-4b02-8ecb-59b57780ea1c.text: It should be a man's task, says the Imitation, 'to overcome himself, and every day to be stronger than himself.
b61396f2-be01-4b02-8ecb-59b57780ea1c.author: Marcus Aurelius

f226558d-58bc-4c37-92d9-8e2027605c83.text: It stares you in the face. No role is so well suited to philosophy as the one you happen to be in right now.
f226558d-58bc-4c37-92d9-8e2027605c83.author: Marcus Aurelius

4a69d124-53ff-4b0e-9f11-f580366fba33.text: It was my tutor who dissuaded me from patronizing Green or Blue at the races, or Light or Heavy in the ring.
4a69d124-53ff-4b0e-9f11-f580366fba33.author: Marcus Aurelius

86fec620-6a48-4ec5-9499-5648430a2188.text: Its a dream, a fearful dream, life is.
86fec620-6a48-4ec5-9499-5648430a2188.author: Marcus Aurelius

55dc7de8-320f-4f67-a12f-5e89a884ff36.text: It’s silly to try to escape other people’s faults. They are inescapable. Just try to escape your own.
55dc7de8-320f-4f67-a12f-5e89a884ff36.author: Marcus Aurelius

c3f7e3dd-b7d2-49ef-a863-a80454750294.text: It’s the truth I’m after, and the truth never harmed anyone. What harms us is to persist in self-deceit and ignorance.
c3f7e3dd-b7d2-49ef-a863-a80454750294.author: Marcus Aurelius

77eef87a-ead0-4ff4-8013-1ad515c63889.text: Keep thyself therefore, truly simple, good, sincere, grave, free from all ostentation, a lover of that which is just, religious, kind, tender-hearted, strong and vigorous to undergo anything that becomes thee.
77eef87a-ead0-4ff4-8013-1ad515c63889.author: Marcus Aurelius

670703f9-fdcb-4d23-b078-896388260c92.text: Keeps in mind that all rational things are related, and that to care for all human beings is part of being human.
670703f9-fdcb-4d23-b078-896388260c92.author: Marcus Aurelius

dab0edf5-46e2-4975-981a-c6c2f7b5d921.text: Kingship: to earn a bad reputation by good deeds.
dab0edf5-46e2-4975-981a-c6c2f7b5d921.author: Marcus Aurelius

78f9d6f8-9eec-43cb-b3f8-85e9f8d77130.text: Let it happen, if it wants, to whatever it can happen to. And what’s affected can complain about it if it wants. It doesn’t hurt me unless I interpret its happening as harmful to me. I can choose not to.
78f9d6f8-9eec-43cb-b3f8-85e9f8d77130.author: Marcus Aurelius

ba242360-de13-45bf-84f6-3c1286243b09.text: Let no act be done without a purpose, nor otherwise than according to the perfect principles of art.
ba242360-de13-45bf-84f6-3c1286243b09.author: Marcus Aurelius

c9894b46-b777-4612-99a4-112299d9b1a1.text: Let not the future trouble you; for you will come to it, if come you must, bearing with you the same reason which you are using now to meet the present.
c9894b46-b777-4612-99a4-112299d9b1a1.author: Marcus Aurelius

cd051557-ea2c-4648-b32d-63b9bcee3d40.text: Let not the general representation unto thyself of the wretchedness of this our mortal life, trouble thee.
cd051557-ea2c-4648-b32d-63b9bcee3d40.author: Marcus Aurelius

d3d93ead-561b-47be-8883-93239a3c54d4.text: Let nothing be done rashly, and at random, but all things according to the most exact and perfect rules of art.
d3d93ead-561b-47be-8883-93239a3c54d4.author: Marcus Aurelius

450ace03-6faf-47d2-a611-37f9371f9aae.text: Let the god that is within you be the champion of the being you are.
450ace03-6faf-47d2-a611-37f9371f9aae.author: Marcus Aurelius

88f7b45b-7671-4803-9f21-779953bd24f4.text: Life is a warfare and a stranger's sojourn, and after-fame is oblivion.
88f7b45b-7671-4803-9f21-779953bd24f4.author: Marcus Aurelius

fdbe3167-ae23-4530-a6ba-9e39d22d2c79.text: Life is neither good or evil, but only a place for good and evil.
fdbe3167-ae23-4530-a6ba-9e39d22d2c79.author: Marcus Aurelius

804e7a49-561e-40d5-97f3-82179c570e47.text: Life is short. That’s all there is to say. Get what you can from the present—thoughtfully, justly. Unrestrained moderation.
804e7a49-561e-40d5-97f3-82179c570e47.author: Marcus Aurelius

53e95a91-7985-40da-91ce-0960263218ca.text: Live as though today is your last day.
53e95a91-7985-40da-91ce-0960263218ca.author: Marcus Aurelius

0f18fb72-1266-4129-bde0-f1bc5a01dca6.text: Live every day as if they last.
0f18fb72-1266-4129-bde0-f1bc5a01dca6.author: Marcus Aurelius

e20f47b3-ca8a-4fe6-a856-5bbbad37188e.text: Live out your life in truth and justice, tolerant of those who are neither true nor just.
e20f47b3-ca8a-4fe6-a856-5bbbad37188e.author: Marcus Aurelius

93d4be36-0b39-4b7a-bda4-32efe654859a.text: Look at the past—empire succeeding empire—and from that, extrapolate the future: the same thing. No escape from the rhythm of events. Which is why observing life for forty years is as good as a thousand. Would you really see anything new?
93d4be36-0b39-4b7a-bda4-32efe654859a.author: Marcus Aurelius

65ca8286-2e9e-4f5e-8aa9-7a57aeaa37cc.text: Look back over the past, with its changing empires that rose and fell, and you can foresee the future too.
65ca8286-2e9e-4f5e-8aa9-7a57aeaa37cc.author: Marcus Aurelius

020b4f2a-7047-4ea0-83eb-1c1b00d42837.text: Look beneath the surface; let not the several quality of a thing nor its worth escape thee.
020b4f2a-7047-4ea0-83eb-1c1b00d42837.author: Marcus Aurelius

86395da6-0112-4270-b796-0db7e354a4cc.text: Look in, let not either the proper quality, or the true worth of anything pass thee, before thou hast fully it.
86395da6-0112-4270-b796-0db7e354a4cc.author: Marcus Aurelius

bb9f24f4-b723-4902-ba38-7c182123e8fe.text: Look to nothing, not even for a moment except to reason.
bb9f24f4-b723-4902-ba38-7c182123e8fe.author: Marcus Aurelius

9466e854-030a-45c4-97ae-178ea59883a2.text: Look well into thyself; there is a source of strength which will always spring up if thou wilt always look.
9466e854-030a-45c4-97ae-178ea59883a2.author: Marcus Aurelius

f85511b3-adb7-4297-9361-5cda028d0e42.text: Look within. Within is the fountain of good, and it will ever bubble up, if thou wilt ever dig.
f85511b3-adb7-4297-9361-5cda028d0e42.author: Marcus Aurelius

0a2efa27-82e8-431c-bb32-71ec62a3385f.text: Look within. Within is the fountain of good, and it will ever bubble up, if you will ever dig.
0a2efa27-82e8-431c-bb32-71ec62a3385f.author: Marcus Aurelius

7147472b-9c8a-4f14-8403-98d8e275c424.text: Loss is nothing else but change, and change is Nature's delight.
7147472b-9c8a-4f14-8403-98d8e275c424.author: Marcus Aurelius

30e2413e-672c-4c3f-8187-3531a5a02f2b.text: Love that only which happens to thee and is spun with the thread of thy destiny. For what is more suitable? In.
30e2413e-672c-4c3f-8187-3531a5a02f2b.author: Marcus Aurelius

37ca132e-3130-468f-8264-734442c7a8f0.text: Love the discipline you know, and let it support you.
37ca132e-3130-468f-8264-734442c7a8f0.author: Marcus Aurelius

88366662-fccf-4288-ba20-fc9cfd12cbb9.text: Man, what are you talking about? Me in chains? You may fetter my leg but my will, not even Zeus himself can overpower.
88366662-fccf-4288-ba20-fc9cfd12cbb9.author: Marcus Aurelius

177ba1cc-9ab3-4d1d-a0b7-d1fd80aba12b.text: Manage all your actions, words, and thoughts accordingly, since you may at any moment quit life.
177ba1cc-9ab3-4d1d-a0b7-d1fd80aba12b.author: Marcus Aurelius

dd4660fc-705d-4e44-bff6-10098bdecd64.text: Meditate upon what you ought to be in body and soul when death overtakes you; meditate on the brevity of life, and the measureless gulf of eternity behind it and before, and upon the frailty of everything material.
dd4660fc-705d-4e44-bff6-10098bdecd64.author: Marcus Aurelius

eaf9926b-731f-45fd-9d08-adc25aa4d25a.text: Men exist for the sake of one another.
eaf9926b-731f-45fd-9d08-adc25aa4d25a.author: Marcus Aurelius
