bfb57ab2-33c7-4bb1-8032-b72662ebc355.text: Always remember what is your own and what is not, and you’ll never be troubled.
bfb57ab2-33c7-4bb1-8032-b72662ebc355.author: Epictetus

d5691b93-8315-4777-8cba-aa8d7827436f.text: An ignorant person is inclined to blame others for his own misfortune. To blame oneself is proof of progress. But the wise man never has to blame another or himself.
d5691b93-8315-4777-8cba-aa8d7827436f.author: Epictetus

6edb95f0-2791-4e04-baaf-e0aa97528f48.text: An uninstructed person will lay the fault of his own bad condition upon others. Someone just starting instruction will lay the fault on himself. Some who is perfectly instructed will place blame neither on others nor on himself.
6edb95f0-2791-4e04-baaf-e0aa97528f48.author: Epictetus

c429bf97-9b7e-43d6-b6d9-8bb52ef9deee.text: And then we’ll be emulating Socrates,* once we’re able to write hymns of praise in prison.
c429bf97-9b7e-43d6-b6d9-8bb52ef9deee.author: Epictetus

97418deb-ce26-4f76-8e94-0469a360f5f2.text: And where there is ignorance, there is also want of learning and instruction in essentials.
97418deb-ce26-4f76-8e94-0469a360f5f2.author: Epictetus

a91411a5-f688-424d-8978-86bba5a49928.text: Any person capable of angering you becomes your master; he can anger you only when you permit yourself to be disturbed by him.
a91411a5-f688-424d-8978-86bba5a49928.author: Epictetus

0b5caa2a-ba6c-43fd-a228-d1a5b87709ca.text: As a man, casting off worn out garments taketh new ones, so the dweller in the body, entereth into ones that are new.
0b5caa2a-ba6c-43fd-a228-d1a5b87709ca.author: Epictetus

374cc0c4-1cfa-4c67-942f-6db5eda27f62.text: As long as you honour material things, direct your anger at yourself rather than the thief or adulterer.
374cc0c4-1cfa-4c67-942f-6db5eda27f62.author: Epictetus

fdcc2229-6c3a-4409-90b9-610a823f3b41.text: Asked how a man should best grieve his enemy, Epictetus replied, "By setting himself to live the noblest life himself."
fdcc2229-6c3a-4409-90b9-610a823f3b41.author: Epictetus

037baedb-c6b1-4651-8ec7-38c4f47982d4.text: Asked, Who is the rich man? Epictetus replied, "He who is content."
037baedb-c6b1-4651-8ec7-38c4f47982d4.author: Epictetus

72f1f0d8-c9c5-4c1c-8fd0-62c9e5a00f9c.text: Asked, Who is the rich man? Epictetus replied, He who is content.
72f1f0d8-c9c5-4c1c-8fd0-62c9e5a00f9c.author: Epictetus

78202e3e-f00f-4310-af96-78b2e450d305.text: At feasts, remember that you are entertaining two guests, body and soul. What you give to the body, you presently lose; what you give to the soul, you keep for ever.
78202e3e-f00f-4310-af96-78b2e450d305.author: Epictetus

ef00cc9f-d5a7-4e22-907b-4f60db08e66f.text: Attach yourself to what is spiritually superior, regardless of what other people think or do. Hold to your true aspirations no matter what is going on around you.
ef00cc9f-d5a7-4e22-907b-4f60db08e66f.author: Epictetus

2e2d6986-b919-490f-b8fd-af1769cf4b81.text: Avoid banquets which are given by strangers and by ignorant persons.
2e2d6986-b919-490f-b8fd-af1769cf4b81.author: Epictetus

b552e720-0485-4829-90c7-649f2c5deb5a.text: Be careful to leave your sons and daughters well instructed rather than rich, for the hopes of the instructed are better than the wealth of the ignorant."
b552e720-0485-4829-90c7-649f2c5deb5a.author: Epictetus

37d40b50-2784-4823-8210-ff5cc81c219b.text: Be careful to leave your sons well instructed rather than rich, for the hopes of the instructed are better than the wealth of the ignorant.
37d40b50-2784-4823-8210-ff5cc81c219b.author: Epictetus

356c7a1c-cd78-4482-8f09-c2c76a02798e.text: Be free from grief not through insensibility like the irrational animals, nor through want of thought like the foolish, but like a man of virtue by having reason as the consolation of grief.
356c7a1c-cd78-4482-8f09-c2c76a02798e.author: Epictetus

74831db0-7b54-4ab9-8c18-1af0ae5ff35d.text: But first consider how much more sparing and patient of hardship the poor are than we.
74831db0-7b54-4ab9-8c18-1af0ae5ff35d.author: Epictetus

2996b174-ec94-4315-8be6-dfd8f4872585.text: Can we avoid people? How is that possible? And if we associate with them, can we change them? Who gives us that power?
2996b174-ec94-4315-8be6-dfd8f4872585.author: Epictetus

5c30d020-0842-450b-b100-a1c1e1245d7a.text: Caretake this moment. Immerse yourself in its particulars. Respond to this person, this challenge, this deed. Quit evasions. Stop giving yourself needless trouble. It is time to really live; to fully inhabit the situation you happen to be in now.
5c30d020-0842-450b-b100-a1c1e1245d7a.author: Epictetus

408045b5-94ed-47c3-b5ed-08e7cdbb41e0.text: Check your passions that you may not be punished by them.
408045b5-94ed-47c3-b5ed-08e7cdbb41e0.author: Epictetus

5dc3f1c6-bcae-4f09-96eb-0c9c0f8cc7e5.text: Circumstances do not rise to meet our expectations. Events happen as they do. People behave as they are. Embrace what you actually get.
5dc3f1c6-bcae-4f09-96eb-0c9c0f8cc7e5.author: Epictetus

1d9d4137-7b5f-4c3f-99b5-9e3ab539ee0a.text: Circumstances don't make the man, they only reveal him to himself.
1d9d4137-7b5f-4c3f-99b5-9e3ab539ee0a.author: Epictetus

66cbdc14-f339-489f-a154-3fae97158ee9.text: CIRCUMSTANCES DON’T MAKE THE MAN, THEY ONLY REVEAL HIM TO HIMSELF.
66cbdc14-f339-489f-a154-3fae97158ee9.author: Epictetus

35b72054-8d8f-4b25-9384-76d8af3d5173.text: Conduct yourself in all matters, grand and public or small and domestic, in accordance with the laws of nature. Harmonizing your will with nature should be your utmost ideal.
35b72054-8d8f-4b25-9384-76d8af3d5173.author: Epictetus

d5fd5b9a-833d-4bf6-85f3-52a7ab85daeb.text: Consider first, man, what the matter is, and what your own nature is able to bear. If you would be a wrestler, consider your shoulders, your back, your thighs; for different persons are made for different things.
d5fd5b9a-833d-4bf6-85f3-52a7ab85daeb.author: Epictetus

1e76ffa2-74b6-423e-b00e-03e8232d3726.text: Crows pick out the eyes of the dead, when the dead have no longer need of them; but flatterers mar the soul of the living, and her eyes they blind.
1e76ffa2-74b6-423e-b00e-03e8232d3726.author: Epictetus

4369837a-ddaf-4b20-a4d4-d9c85fc35cc1.text: Death is not dreadful or else it would have appeared dreadful to Socrates.
4369837a-ddaf-4b20-a4d4-d9c85fc35cc1.author: Epictetus

1fe450e0-f285-4cd3-a4c4-a836835fc17e.text: Demand not that events should happen as you wish; but wish them to happen as they do happen, and you will go on well.
1fe450e0-f285-4cd3-a4c4-a836835fc17e.author: Epictetus

adb864a0-4ae1-476c-a873-48238c86144b.text: Demand not that things happen as you wish, but wish them to happen as they do, and you will go on well.
adb864a0-4ae1-476c-a873-48238c86144b.author: Epictetus

3f6f9204-fd03-41aa-9a74-f784ad4e14a7.text: Destroy desire completely for the present. For if you desire anything which is not in our power, you must be unfortunate.
3f6f9204-fd03-41aa-9a74-f784ad4e14a7.author: Epictetus

b0d2dce4-8342-4d49-8e33-baf978782328.text: Do not get too attached to life for it is like a sailor's leave on the shore and at any time, the captain may sound the horn, calling you back to eternal darkness.
b0d2dce4-8342-4d49-8e33-baf978782328.author: Epictetus

dc215139-d391-4319-a013-9226ac1b8c66.text: Do not try to seem wise to others.
dc215139-d391-4319-a013-9226ac1b8c66.author: Epictetus

46699956-b778-4c17-a011-d09c9c426cd0.text: Do not try to seem wise to others. If you want to live a wise life, live it on your own terms and in your own eyes.
46699956-b778-4c17-a011-d09c9c426cd0.author: Epictetus

738e5a80-8315-4b53-b1d5-bd47682a7746.text: Do your best to rein in your desire. For if you desire something that isn’t within your own control, disappointment will surely follow; meanwhile, you will be neglecting the very things that are within your control that are worthy of desire.
738e5a80-8315-4b53-b1d5-bd47682a7746.author: Epictetus

5e11afc0-d0f0-429b-b06a-c68dcb735b41.text: Don't concern yourself with other people's business. It's his problem if he receives you badly. And you cannot suffer for another person's fault. So don't worry about the behavior of other.
5e11afc0-d0f0-429b-b06a-c68dcb735b41.author: Epictetus

794865a2-170a-45e2-8ce5-12aac9eff442.text: Don't hope that events will turn out the way you want, welcome events in whichever way they happen: this is the path to peace.
794865a2-170a-45e2-8ce5-12aac9eff442.author: Epictetus

4ce118e6-9ce2-4c35-85d4-46ab9946a57c.text: Don't live by your own rules, but in harmony with nature.
4ce118e6-9ce2-4c35-85d4-46ab9946a57c.author: Epictetus

3c4cefd5-63f5-407b-be27-b2984e1bc978.text: Don't put your purpose in one place and expect to see progress made somewhere else.
3c4cefd5-63f5-407b-be27-b2984e1bc978.author: Epictetus

a9139642-d183-4d03-bfaf-cef6f3974d4e.text: Don't seek to have events happen as you wish, but wish them to happen as they do happen, and all will be well with you.
a9139642-d183-4d03-bfaf-cef6f3974d4e.author: Epictetus

367553cb-53fb-42b2-9378-bd533032e1a0.text: Don’t seek that all that comes about should come about as you wish, but wish that everything that comes about should come about just as it does, and then you’ll have a calm and happy life.
367553cb-53fb-42b2-9378-bd533032e1a0.author: Epictetus

9c559cf4-09d0-4fae-8cdf-053380b84fb4.text: Either God wants to abolish evil, and cannot; or he can, but does not want to.
9c559cf4-09d0-4fae-8cdf-053380b84fb4.author: Epictetus

086421b5-d8cb-435e-8cb8-37fe1f12e377.text: Epictetus being asked how a man should give pain to his enemy answered, By preparing himself to live the best life that he can.
086421b5-d8cb-435e-8cb8-37fe1f12e377.author: Epictetus

c70bf7ec-6f5d-4e8c-a72a-8b6073e513ac.text: Events do not just happen, but arrive by appointment.
c70bf7ec-6f5d-4e8c-a72a-8b6073e513ac.author: Epictetus

3a860f83-d231-45ca-97fd-8d4ec59f4953.text: Every circumstance comes with two handles, which one of which you can hold it, while with the other conditions are insupportable.
3a860f83-d231-45ca-97fd-8d4ec59f4953.author: Epictetus

b0449c1d-b068-448e-af88-74abf1e28ac9.text: Everyone's life is a warfare, and that long and various.
b0449c1d-b068-448e-af88-74abf1e28ac9.author: Epictetus

64273804-fa20-4358-9c33-bbe44b0a68a7.text: Faced with pain, you will discover the power of endurance. If you are insulted, you will discover patience. In time, you will grow to be confident that there is not a single impression that you will not have the moral means to tolerate.
64273804-fa20-4358-9c33-bbe44b0a68a7.author: Epictetus

e5ca5672-b559-4270-a306-efcc259d1fb1.text: Faithfulness is the antidote to bitterness and confusion.
e5ca5672-b559-4270-a306-efcc259d1fb1.author: Epictetus

a824dde2-f208-4bce-97e7-a8142e5a3ab1.text: Finally, when he crowns it off by becoming a senator, then he becomes a slave in fine company, then he experiences the poshest and most prestigious form of enslavement.
a824dde2-f208-4bce-97e7-a8142e5a3ab1.author: Epictetus

b66fa099-7871-47a6-a560-497f972707d6.text: First learn the meaning of what you say, and then speak.
b66fa099-7871-47a6-a560-497f972707d6.author: Epictetus

98043480-7bb6-4a3f-ad13-b7ad4672ca90.text: First say to yourself what you would be, and then do what you have to do.
98043480-7bb6-4a3f-ad13-b7ad4672ca90.author: Epictetus

8f563a14-7f2c-40af-af6c-3a4fbdc32834.text: First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.
8f563a14-7f2c-40af-af6c-3a4fbdc32834.author: Epictetus

07795000-54c6-470b-8632-bdab12dbd9de.text: For if we had any sense, what else should we do, both in public and in private, than sing hymns and praise the deity, and recount all the favours that he has conferred!
07795000-54c6-470b-8632-bdab12dbd9de.author: Epictetus

7d9ff840-b24d-4629-85d4-0465cda5eb6a.text: For in this Case, we are not to give Credit to the Many, who say, that none ought to be educated but the Free; but rather to the Philosophers, who say, that the Well-educated alone are free.
7d9ff840-b24d-4629-85d4-0465cda5eb6a.author: Epictetus

474036e7-ee89-4679-9575-a741b5d1844b.text: For it is not death or pain that is to be feared, but the fear of pain or death.
474036e7-ee89-4679-9575-a741b5d1844b.author: Epictetus

c991a7be-bcde-4b3c-8189-9c745cb30358.text: For sheep don't throw up the grass to show the shepherds how much they have eaten; but, inwardly digesting their food, they outwardly produce wool and milk.
c991a7be-bcde-4b3c-8189-9c745cb30358.author: Epictetus

6b75c3b2-1f91-462a-83c2-2697ec915fa6.text: For what else is tragedy than the portrayal in tragic verse of the sufferings of men who have attached high value to external things?
6b75c3b2-1f91-462a-83c2-2697ec915fa6.author: Epictetus

65421302-93d0-47a4-a7fe-8d1f8534558f.text: For where you find unrest, grief, fear, frustrated desire, failed aversion, jealousy and envy, happiness has no room for admittance. And where values are false, these passions inevitably follow.
65421302-93d0-47a4-a7fe-8d1f8534558f.author: Epictetus

9a9482e1-170a-4e06-b60b-fc425198d9fa.text: For your part, do not desire to be a general, or a senator, or a consul, but to be free; and the only way to this is a disregard of things which lie not within our own power.
9a9482e1-170a-4e06-b60b-fc425198d9fa.author: Epictetus

b1802e42-dfa2-440b-a363-b3be8302b958.text: Fortify yourself with contentment for this is an impregnable fortress.
b1802e42-dfa2-440b-a363-b3be8302b958.author: Epictetus

d03cd34e-3eb9-457d-a22a-fd7d8af643fd.text: Free is the person who lives as he wishes and cannot be coerced, impeded or compelled, whose impulses cannot be thwarted, who always gets what he desires and never has to experience what he would rather avoid.
d03cd34e-3eb9-457d-a22a-fd7d8af643fd.author: Epictetus

3b78d5eb-0e7c-4308-b386-77feb806210d.text: Freedom is not archived by satisfying desire, but by eliminating it.
3b78d5eb-0e7c-4308-b386-77feb806210d.author: Epictetus

bf4cccf1-329e-47d3-b092-6d5d72497eff.text: Freedom is not procured by a full enjoyment of what is desired, but by controlling the desire.
bf4cccf1-329e-47d3-b092-6d5d72497eff.author: Epictetus

4385a409-b515-4f3f-a8ac-5dd593a6ef79.text: Freedom is secured not by the fulfilling of men's desires, but by the removal of desire.
4385a409-b515-4f3f-a8ac-5dd593a6ef79.author: Epictetus

6f13f1c8-fbb8-4ed3-9d22-ce274180411c.text: Freedom is the only worthy goal in life. It is won by disregarding things that lie beyond our control.
6f13f1c8-fbb8-4ed3-9d22-ce274180411c.author: Epictetus

a32cbf9e-2dab-4153-abc3-e044b7d1908c.text: Freedom, you see, is having events go in accordance with our will, never contrary to it.
a32cbf9e-2dab-4153-abc3-e044b7d1908c.author: Epictetus

167052bb-5944-4625-9f06-72602ea74ce9.text: Friend, lay hold with a desperate grasp, ere it is too late, on Freedom, on Tranquility, on Greatness of soul!
167052bb-5944-4625-9f06-72602ea74ce9.author: Epictetus

42606354-0062-4084-be2c-dd71f5fe8023.text: From this instant, then, choose to act like the worthy and capable person you are. Follow unwaveringly what reason tells you is the best course.
42606354-0062-4084-be2c-dd71f5fe8023.author: Epictetus

269f109b-81b8-4358-813d-6cdca36ec364.text: Give me by all means the shorter and nobler life, instead of one that is longer but of less account!
269f109b-81b8-4358-813d-6cdca36ec364.author: Epictetus

e4a05847-4b13-4d4a-b952-3283ba634a8f.text: God has entrusted me with myself. No man is free who is not master of himself. A man should so live that his happiness shall depend as little as possible on external things. The world turns aside to let any man pass who knows where he is going.
e4a05847-4b13-4d4a-b952-3283ba634a8f.author: Epictetus

8ca05b95-88d2-40ad-a796-37a28d50898c.text: God save me from fools with a little philosophy—no one is more difficult to reach.
8ca05b95-88d2-40ad-a796-37a28d50898c.author: Epictetus

26836566-2694-4562-bb9e-60f415bee936.text: Goodness exists independently of our conception of it. The good is out there and it always has been out there, even before we began to exist.
26836566-2694-4562-bb9e-60f415bee936.author: Epictetus

8c199618-ae24-4e01-9abb-50688b4876d6.text: Grammar will tell you how to write; but whether to write or not, grammar will not tell.
8c199618-ae24-4e01-9abb-50688b4876d6.author: Epictetus

4b75dff2-283c-4f49-a669-163e8f22e1cd.text: Greatness of reason is measured not by height or length, but by the quality of its judgements.
4b75dff2-283c-4f49-a669-163e8f22e1cd.author: Epictetus

d348e572-ba77-4d23-95df-7b6013ebadb2.text: Happiness and freedom begin with a clear understanding of one principle: Some things are within our control, and some things are not.
d348e572-ba77-4d23-95df-7b6013ebadb2.author: Epictetus

844f034e-cccc-4dfb-a0da-f222f12f5677.text: He is a wise man who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.
844f034e-cccc-4dfb-a0da-f222f12f5677.author: Epictetus

24a88179-08e9-40dd-8a7a-1d94033f4f49.text: He wants what he cannot have, and does not want what he can't refuse — and isn't aware of it. He doesn't know the difference between his own possessions and others'. Because, if he did, he would never be thwarted of disappointed. Or nervous.
24a88179-08e9-40dd-8a7a-1d94033f4f49.author: Epictetus

33031ca3-d164-48ee-b8a8-6868e677f7f4.text: He who exercises wisdom, exercises the knowledge which is about God.
33031ca3-d164-48ee-b8a8-6868e677f7f4.author: Epictetus

fc227f45-b057-4da9-a7d1-207c11e415ea.text: He who laughs at himself never runs out of things to laugh at.
fc227f45-b057-4da9-a7d1-207c11e415ea.author: Epictetus

67989a95-e609-4278-80ea-dff0f8e5bff3.text: Here are thieves and robbers and tribunals: and they that are called tyrants, who deem that they have after a fashion power over us, because of the miserable body and what appertains to it. Let us show them that they have power over none.
67989a95-e609-4278-80ea-dff0f8e5bff3.author: Epictetus

8eab7965-fa04-45ec-9c0e-9354a98e383d.text: I cannot call somebody ‘hard-working’ knowing only that they read and write. Even if ‘all night long’ is added, I cannot say it – not until I know the focus of all this energy.
8eab7965-fa04-45ec-9c0e-9354a98e383d.author: Epictetus

ca96aeb2-08b0-4d8e-84f5-144d0c89a905.text: I have learned to see that whatever comes about is nothing to me if it lies beyond the sphere of choice.
ca96aeb2-08b0-4d8e-84f5-144d0c89a905.author: Epictetus

e0be9994-792d-4b7d-b58b-15640f23bbd2.text: I laugh at those who think they can damage me. They do not know who I am, they do not know what I think, they cannot even touch the things which are really mine and with which I live.
e0be9994-792d-4b7d-b58b-15640f23bbd2.author: Epictetus

0603b437-6cba-49c3-9fae-dbb1f42b680c.text: I must die. Must I then die lamenting? I must be put in chains. Must I then also lament? I must go into exile. Does any man then hinder me from going with smiles and cheerfulness and contentment?
0603b437-6cba-49c3-9fae-dbb1f42b680c.author: Epictetus

e3bb5601-6172-4d81-af45-95d68d828189.text: I want to die, even though I don't have to.
e3bb5601-6172-4d81-af45-95d68d828189.author: Epictetus

b2e57dde-10eb-404b-9310-64414a985bce.text: If a man has reported to you, that a certain person speaks ill of you, do not make any defense to what has been told you: but reply, The man did not know the rest of my faults, for he would not have mentioned these only.
b2e57dde-10eb-404b-9310-64414a985bce.author: Epictetus

e1a9abac-d31b-4918-8f7c-861902e8c630.text: If a person gave your body to any stranger he met on his way, you would certainly be angry. And do you feel no shame in handing over your own mind to be confused and mystified by anyone who happens to verbally attack you?
e1a9abac-d31b-4918-8f7c-861902e8c630.author: Epictetus

32b4a24f-9d7e-48cd-a13b-6cf75585d561.text: If a person gave your body to any stranger he met on is way, you would certainly be angry. And do you feel no shame in handing over your own mind to be confused and mystified by anyone who happens to verbally attack you?
32b4a24f-9d7e-48cd-a13b-6cf75585d561.author: Epictetus

741f303e-6cc3-4b9e-bf76-1ee553003745.text: If any be unhappy, let him remember that he is unhappy by reason of himself alone. For God hath made all men to enjoy felicity and constancy of good.
741f303e-6cc3-4b9e-bf76-1ee553003745.author: Epictetus

c7fd5a96-9aa3-429a-b680-27d9b03743a4.text: If any one trusted your body to the first man he met, you would be indignant, but yet you trust your mind to the chance comer, and allow it to be disturbed and confounded if he revile you; are you not ashamed to do so?
c7fd5a96-9aa3-429a-b680-27d9b03743a4.author: Epictetus

64daac53-7693-45f6-a3e8-8659c9fcf2ff.text: If anyone tells you that a certain person speaks ill of you, do not make excuses about what is said of you but answer, "He was ignorant of my other faults, else he would not have mentioned these alone."
64daac53-7693-45f6-a3e8-8659c9fcf2ff.author: Epictetus

747e3191-38da-4458-8b13-4e6dd333adea.text: If anyone tells you that a certain person speaks ill of you, do not make excuses about what is said of you, but answer: “He was ignorant of my other faults, else he would not have mentioned these alone.“
747e3191-38da-4458-8b13-4e6dd333adea.author: Epictetus

75e4f7ad-aca0-4180-9068-d0230cb26a3c.text: If anyone tells you that such a person speaks ill of you, don’t make excuses about what is said of you, but answer: “He does not know my other faults, else he would not have mentioned only these.“
75e4f7ad-aca0-4180-9068-d0230cb26a3c.author: Epictetus

e3bfed0f-41b6-40bf-b603-349c953395d4.text: If evil be said of thee, and if it be true, correct thyself; if it be a lie, laugh at it.
e3bfed0f-41b6-40bf-b603-349c953395d4.author: Epictetus

29d96aea-67e6-420f-8f00-efe335fe9e0e.text: If someone speaks badly of you, do not defend yourself against the accusations, but reply; "you obviously don't know about my other vices, otherwise you would have mentioned these as well."
29d96aea-67e6-420f-8f00-efe335fe9e0e.author: Epictetus

20fffabd-77b5-4036-bd98-abbdb6c58c12.text: If the Divine is faithful, he also must be faithful; if free, he also must be free; if beneficent, he also must be beneficent; if magnanimous, he also must be magnanimous. Thus as an imitator of God must he follow Him in every deed and word.
20fffabd-77b5-4036-bd98-abbdb6c58c12.author: Epictetus

5e2a3838-18d1-4e32-9325-4c80b36ca265.text: If then you desire (aim at) such great things remember that you must not (attempt to) lay hold of them with a small effort.
5e2a3838-18d1-4e32-9325-4c80b36ca265.author: Epictetus

bb736338-52cf-45b5-a35f-8c63c3218b5d.text: If they are wise, do not quarrel with them; if they are fools, ignore them.
bb736338-52cf-45b5-a35f-8c63c3218b5d.author: Epictetus

ea17183a-48a3-44b6-9ee1-434126c97752.text: If thy brother wrongs thee, remember not so much his wrong-doing, but more than ever that he is thy brother.
ea17183a-48a3-44b6-9ee1-434126c97752.author: Epictetus

6e63052b-a018-41ea-b05c-020e41c1baf4.text: If what philosophers say of the kinship of God and Man be true, what remains for men to do but as Socrates did:—never, when asked one's country, to answer, "I am an Athenian or a Corinthian," but "I am a citizen of the world."
6e63052b-a018-41ea-b05c-020e41c1baf4.author: Epictetus

a28ffda6-94f8-47d6-9ef3-d66044977b2a.text: If you are told that such an one speaks ill of you, make no defense against what was said, but answer, "He surely knows not my other faults, else he would not have mentioned these only!"
a28ffda6-94f8-47d6-9ef3-d66044977b2a.author: Epictetus

b12bcdc2-bef5-4600-bad9-566ce743f716.text: If you choose, you are free; if you choose, you need blame no man—accuse no man. All things will be at once according to your mind and according to the Mind of God.
b12bcdc2-bef5-4600-bad9-566ce743f716.author: Epictetus

62ec71ab-2334-4469-ad08-5d76d37c8655.text: If you have assumed a character above your strength, you have both acted in this matter in an unbecoming way, and you have neglected that which you might have fulfilled.
62ec71ab-2334-4469-ad08-5d76d37c8655.author: Epictetus

6c31963c-1796-42fe-ae9b-37aaa10a8f0d.text: If you have assumed a character beyond your strength, you have both played a poor figure in that, and neglected one that is within your powers.
6c31963c-1796-42fe-ae9b-37aaa10a8f0d.author: Epictetus

69a9d440-ebd0-4d1a-87a3-39cb49001c9f.text: If you have assumed any character beyond your strength, you have both demeaned yourself ill in that and quitted one which you might have supported.
69a9d440-ebd0-4d1a-87a3-39cb49001c9f.author: Epictetus

7a86ed99-25e6-4426-ba9f-5450432c1d33.text: If you must be affected by other people's misfortunes, show them pity instead of contempt. Drop this readiness to hate and take offence.
7a86ed99-25e6-4426-ba9f-5450432c1d33.author: Epictetus

70199406-8975-47d3-9081-ca63dc348a4b.text: If you seek Truth, you will not seek to gain a victory by every possible means; and when you have found Truth, you need not fear being defeated.
70199406-8975-47d3-9081-ca63dc348a4b.author: Epictetus

828ea767-df2c-47eb-b4ff-1513c67cf6dd.text: If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid with regard to external things. Don't wish to be thought to know anything; and even if you appear to be somebody important to others, distrust yourself.
828ea767-df2c-47eb-b4ff-1513c67cf6dd.author: Epictetus

5106b00f-a533-49e9-9e40-db70fc2e2f25.text: If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid.
5106b00f-a533-49e9-9e40-db70fc2e2f25.author: Epictetus

cb7a52c6-ed0e-434f-bc99-b419071c34fb.text: If you want to improve, you must be content to be thought foolish and stupid.
cb7a52c6-ed0e-434f-bc99-b419071c34fb.author: Epictetus

2f8d7a3d-c6dd-4987-abac-5e14c6cc633b.text: If you wish it, you are free; if you wish it, you’ll find fault with no one, you’ll cast blame on no one, and everything that comes about will do so in accordance with your own will and that of God.
2f8d7a3d-c6dd-4987-abac-5e14c6cc633b.author: Epictetus

4a228d3e-c932-43a8-bb85-d33a4fa36fca.text: If you wish to be a writer, write.
4a228d3e-c932-43a8-bb85-d33a4fa36fca.author: Epictetus

9efb6183-16e3-4f9d-89a0-4914db33e891.text: If you wish to be a writer; write!
9efb6183-16e3-4f9d-89a0-4914db33e891.author: Epictetus

441c34fc-266b-43c6-b373-ad194c556f18.text: If you wish to be good, first believe that you are bad.
441c34fc-266b-43c6-b373-ad194c556f18.author: Epictetus

2aded183-d68c-4f15-af34-65b3030a63ea.text: If you would be a reader, read; if a writer, write.
2aded183-d68c-4f15-af34-65b3030a63ea.author: Epictetus

628a27c0-6af5-4c08-a85a-6d4ab85be81d.text: If you would cure anger, do not feed it. Say to yourself: 'I used to be angry every day; then every other day; now only every third or fourth day.' When you reach thirty days offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving to the gods.
628a27c0-6af5-4c08-a85a-6d4ab85be81d.author: Epictetus

3d842e61-a9df-4906-b6f8-f2833cfa1160.text: Imagine for yourself a character, a model personality, whose example you determine to follow, in private as well as in public.
3d842e61-a9df-4906-b6f8-f2833cfa1160.author: Epictetus

339764aa-672b-4d63-a336-6ac97c584841.text: In banquets remember that you entertain two guests, body and soul: and whatever you shall have given to the body you soon eject: but what you shall have given to the soul, you keep always.
339764aa-672b-4d63-a336-6ac97c584841.author: Epictetus

d065dedc-04c0-4519-9c4a-7183b7b3fd78.text: In literature, too, it is not great achievement to memorize what you have read while not formulating an opinion of your own.
d065dedc-04c0-4519-9c4a-7183b7b3fd78.author: Epictetus

285d9320-329b-4777-8440-7401bff3c836.text: In prosperity it is very easy to find a friend; but in adversity it is most difficult of all things.
285d9320-329b-4777-8440-7401bff3c836.author: Epictetus

98206477-753d-42fc-9885-c47b39a69999.text: In short, we do not abandon any discipline for despair of ever being the best in it.
98206477-753d-42fc-9885-c47b39a69999.author: Epictetus

08186376-aa19-4c98-9a9e-ff1f72eb901d.text: In the long run, every man will pay the penalty for his own misdeeds. The man who remembers this will be angry with no one, indignant with no one, revile no one, blame no one, offend no one, hate no one.
08186376-aa19-4c98-9a9e-ff1f72eb901d.author: Epictetus

547236f6-5047-49ff-8946-5fc60047ecf6.text: Is freedom anything else than the right to live as we wish? Nothing else.
547236f6-5047-49ff-8946-5fc60047ecf6.author: Epictetus

c5ab7976-3cba-42cf-8a44-d83bbca704bf.text: Is it not the same distance to God everywhere?
c5ab7976-3cba-42cf-8a44-d83bbca704bf.author: Epictetus

a716aa47-e5ce-4090-8615-4d024fc970d7.text: Is then the fruit of a fig-tree not perfect suddenly and in one hour, and would you possess the fruit of a man's mind in so short a time and so easily?
a716aa47-e5ce-4090-8615-4d024fc970d7.author: Epictetus

a6ee31a0-85e0-4f74-9962-3bcb4140d378.text: Is you naturally entitled, then, to a good father? No, only to a father.
a6ee31a0-85e0-4f74-9962-3bcb4140d378.author: Epictetus

4ed05a43-9fb5-4c77-9a68-e20f12481280.text: It has been ordained that there be summer and winter, abundance and dearth, virtue and vice, and all such opposites for the harmony of the whole, and (Zeus) has given each of us a body, property, and companions.
4ed05a43-9fb5-4c77-9a68-e20f12481280.author: Epictetus

97b5e06d-0ca7-416e-8c8a-39494a5b8c21.text: It is a universal law — have no illusion — that every creature alive is attached to nothing so much as to its own self-interest.
97b5e06d-0ca7-416e-8c8a-39494a5b8c21.author: Epictetus

f7804ae4-dbaf-4f9d-a5da-f0090295a472.text: It is always our choice whether or not we wish to pay the price for life's rewards. And often it is best for us not to pay the price, for the price might be our integrity.
f7804ae4-dbaf-4f9d-a5da-f0090295a472.author: Epictetus

5320369d-c164-4666-bad7-39aaffd99c89.text: It is better to die of hunger having lived without grief and fear, than to live with a troubled spirit, amid abundance.
5320369d-c164-4666-bad7-39aaffd99c89.author: Epictetus

45daf303-6095-41d5-9326-c2a83f05774a.text: It is better to do wrong seldom and to own it, and to act right for the most part, than seldom to admit that you have done wrong and to do wrong often.
45daf303-6095-41d5-9326-c2a83f05774a.author: Epictetus

9ed66658-f596-4057-88bd-3a06719ef421.text: It is impossible for a man to learn what he thinks he already knows.
9ed66658-f596-4057-88bd-3a06719ef421.author: Epictetus

e3eff15d-25e7-4edd-8b9e-02ee72a63bff.text: It is impossible to begin to learn that which one thinks one already knows.
e3eff15d-25e7-4edd-8b9e-02ee72a63bff.author: Epictetus

1537efb6-33ea-420e-8496-bb8f6a95663e.text: It is more necessary for the soul to be cured than the body; for it is better to die than to live badly.
1537efb6-33ea-420e-8496-bb8f6a95663e.author: Epictetus

9ec65f3a-e346-409f-bdb7-60cddd788b3d.text: It is much better to die of hunger unhindered by grief and fear than to live affluently beset with worry, dread, suspicion and unchecked desire.
9ec65f3a-e346-409f-bdb7-60cddd788b3d.author: Epictetus

4214a86e-7fef-4e24-b1ec-f8a8e42e79c2.text: It is not events that disturb people, it is their judgements concerning them.
4214a86e-7fef-4e24-b1ec-f8a8e42e79c2.author: Epictetus

ed9e6774-e83a-432c-9b61-d89950c64297.text: It is not so much what happens to you as how you think about what happens.
ed9e6774-e83a-432c-9b61-d89950c64297.author: Epictetus

8e7d05f6-51d8-4b20-ab62-acc9a495ffa5.text: It is our attitude toward events, not events themselves, which we can control. Nothing is by its own nature calamitous -- even death is terrible only if we fear it.
8e7d05f6-51d8-4b20-ab62-acc9a495ffa5.author: Epictetus

c947c5a9-4fc9-493a-9fdb-3a6105cba8ca.text: It is the act of an ill-instructed man to blame others for his own bad condition; it is the act of one who has begun to be instructed, to lay blame on himself; and of one whose instruction is completed, neither to blame another, nor himself.
c947c5a9-4fc9-493a-9fdb-3a6105cba8ca.author: Epictetus

2922bd17-2638-4ae9-8545-44c09d811be4.text: It is the act of an ill-instructed man to blame others for his own bad condition; it is the act of one who has begun to be instructed, to lay the blame on himself; and of one whose instruction is completed, neither to blame another, nor himself.
2922bd17-2638-4ae9-8545-44c09d811be4.author: Epictetus

7cb8fc9b-68f9-4689-a286-dd1f07ae82bd.text: It isn't death, pain, exile or anything else you care to mention that accounts for the way we act, only our opinion about death, pain and the rest.
7cb8fc9b-68f9-4689-a286-dd1f07ae82bd.author: Epictetus

6b025c88-942f-4602-acf7-7d0c2ff12993.text: It isn’t events themselves that disturb people, but only their judgments about them.
6b025c88-942f-4602-acf7-7d0c2ff12993.author: Epictetus

0ed6f361-7eb8-4938-aecf-f256735af66f.text: It's not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
0ed6f361-7eb8-4938-aecf-f256735af66f.author: Epictetus

0f4f420c-ac6d-464b-a33a-8c365c471952.text: Keep the prospect of death, exile and all such apparent tragedies before you every day – especially death – and you will never have an abject thought, or desire anything to excess.
0f4f420c-ac6d-464b-a33a-8c365c471952.author: Epictetus

83c6bac0-df96-4461-b4f4-8686cd23e2a9.text: Know you not that a good man does nothing for appearance sake, but for the sake of having done right?
83c6bac0-df96-4461-b4f4-8686cd23e2a9.author: Epictetus

c7758650-846e-4312-a3cd-5963b435f10b.text: Know, first, who you are, and then adorn yourself accordingly.
c7758650-846e-4312-a3cd-5963b435f10b.author: Epictetus

7f853bf6-c708-4997-9e77-a22020bfebc3.text: Let silence be your general rule; or say only what is necessary and in few words.
7f853bf6-c708-4997-9e77-a22020bfebc3.author: Epictetus

d46070cc-76d5-4feb-aa80-d22a5f8378b4.text: Let your will to avoid have no concern with what is not in man's power; direct it only to things in man's power that are contrary to nature.
d46070cc-76d5-4feb-aa80-d22a5f8378b4.author: Epictetus

c274d72d-4417-49d1-a3a3-69526f429cb4.text: Life is a piece of music, and you’re supposed to be dancing.
c274d72d-4417-49d1-a3a3-69526f429cb4.author: Epictetus

3f134304-db47-4089-a6f1-104b6c8928e9.text: Lucky is the man who dies at work.
3f134304-db47-4089-a6f1-104b6c8928e9.author: Epictetus

366f25a5-7dec-484f-ba65-d93db52cd367.text: Make it your goal never to fail in your desires or experience things you would rather avoid; try never to err in impulse and repulsion; aim to be perfect also in the practice of attention and withholding judgment.
366f25a5-7dec-484f-ba65-d93db52cd367.author: Epictetus

19e37c29-920a-4604-8048-b230f62d7701.text: Man is disturbed not by things, but by the views he takes of them.
19e37c29-920a-4604-8048-b230f62d7701.author: Epictetus

0fe0a056-ab1d-4e84-8296-7c0d2b0ba25b.text: Man is not worried by real problems so much as by his imagined anxieties about real problems.
0fe0a056-ab1d-4e84-8296-7c0d2b0ba25b.author: Epictetus

15b38513-4d96-4783-9fc2-921a5b297588.text: Man is troubled not by events, but by the meaning he gives to them.
15b38513-4d96-4783-9fc2-921a5b297588.author: Epictetus

bea62b39-e7a5-4359-9583-75fc96ecf433.text: Man, the rational animal, can put up with anything except what seems to him irrational; whatever is rational is tolerable.
bea62b39-e7a5-4359-9583-75fc96ecf433.author: Epictetus

4d3858df-3ff2-47d1-aea1-fdcb2e76ce12.text: Man, what are you talking about? Me in chains? You may fetter my leg but my will, not even Zeus himself can overpower.
4d3858df-3ff2-47d1-aea1-fdcb2e76ce12.author: Epictetus

1132682d-e4e2-4257-a514-680f8ce3bcd3.text: Men are disturbed not by the things that happen, but by their opinion of the things that happen.
1132682d-e4e2-4257-a514-680f8ce3bcd3.author: Epictetus

50a66b0a-38f5-416f-a6ca-7761bca8ea26.text: Men are disturbed not by the things which happen, but by the opinion about the things.
50a66b0a-38f5-416f-a6ca-7761bca8ea26.author: Epictetus

53e16ffe-ffc3-479b-8468-82019f7b72a3.text: Men are disturbed not by the things which happen, but by the opinions about the things.
53e16ffe-ffc3-479b-8468-82019f7b72a3.author: Epictetus

8ada86bf-c8dd-4a09-8d8f-ddb488f659a5.text: Men are disturbed not by things, but by the view which they take of them.
8ada86bf-c8dd-4a09-8d8f-ddb488f659a5.author: Epictetus

0982f5e5-34cc-4439-8ac9-341580d7f77f.text: Men are disturbed, not by things, but by the principles and notions which they form concerning things.
0982f5e5-34cc-4439-8ac9-341580d7f77f.author: Epictetus

b38acada-c4ab-4b49-9aa4-17f044d01dd5.text: Men are not afraid of things, but of how they view them.
b38acada-c4ab-4b49-9aa4-17f044d01dd5.author: Epictetus

6f8524b3-c8a0-4ce9-add1-1ebef00a5fd4.text: Most people are impulsive, however, and having committed to the thing, they persist, just making more confusion for themselves and others until it all end in mutual recrimination.
6f8524b3-c8a0-4ce9-add1-1ebef00a5fd4.author: Epictetus

d22e696b-bc66-4539-8c48-e141437abcd1.text: Nature hath given men one tongue but two ears, that we may hear from others twice as much as we speak.
d22e696b-bc66-4539-8c48-e141437abcd1.author: Epictetus

408a3263-3261-452f-98a6-8519db173c5e.text: Neither should a ship rely on one small anchor, nor should life rest on a single hope.
408a3263-3261-452f-98a6-8519db173c5e.author: Epictetus

621bbd1e-00a0-4c0b-af1b-315b93343317.text: Never call yourself a philosopher, nor talk a great deal among the unlearned about theorems, but act conformably to them. Thus, at an entertainment, don’t talk how persons ought to eat, but eat as you ought.
621bbd1e-00a0-4c0b-af1b-315b93343317.author: Epictetus

cb3b05ec-31a1-476c-bace-1b0ba9b0e739.text: Never praise or blame people on common grounds; look to their judgements exclusively. Because that is the determining factor, which makes everyone's actions either good or bad.
cb3b05ec-31a1-476c-bace-1b0ba9b0e739.author: Epictetus

1c599171-cf8e-4827-8ca9-f69e8770737f.text: Never say about anything, I have lost it, but only I have given it back.
1c599171-cf8e-4827-8ca9-f69e8770737f.author: Epictetus

47423522-cd45-405d-974e-a0baca05e2ef.text: Never say of anything that I've lost it, only that I've given it back.
47423522-cd45-405d-974e-a0baca05e2ef.author: Epictetus

407de51e-5008-413e-a14d-964362cea7fe.text: Never say of anything that I've lost it, only that Ive given it back.
407de51e-5008-413e-a14d-964362cea7fe.author: Epictetus

79cff916-93ed-46df-abd4-693b3c7c44b2.text: Never say that I have taken it, only that I have given it back.
79cff916-93ed-46df-abd4-693b3c7c44b2.author: Epictetus

6735c60d-8e36-4003-8693-23949624426a.text: No great thing is created suddenly, any more than a bunch of grapes or a fig. If you tell me that you desire a fig, I answer that there must be time. Let it first blossom, then bear fruit, then ripen.
6735c60d-8e36-4003-8693-23949624426a.author: Epictetus

49ff273c-3cc5-47f7-828c-e3efca6e89cb.text: No great thing is created suddenly.
49ff273c-3cc5-47f7-828c-e3efca6e89cb.author: Epictetus

a1b171f6-1984-440f-ac86-042f4f8f8d91.text: No man can rob us of our Will—no man can lord it over that!
a1b171f6-1984-440f-ac86-042f4f8f8d91.author: Epictetus

7fab9aa2-6a02-4cb7-a387-9c8a3aa94c70.text: No man is free unless he is the master of himself.
7fab9aa2-6a02-4cb7-a387-9c8a3aa94c70.author: Epictetus

bcd05bf5-99b4-4873-913e-c4459b90db46.text: No man is free until he is a master of himself!!
bcd05bf5-99b4-4873-913e-c4459b90db46.author: Epictetus

52de232f-999d-4f48-9444-9e20bff2fc1d.text: No man is free who is not master of himself.
52de232f-999d-4f48-9444-9e20bff2fc1d.author: Epictetus

609858aa-e145-402c-89f6-564a9dea7051.text: No one is ever unhappy because of someone else.
609858aa-e145-402c-89f6-564a9dea7051.author: Epictetus

7add31d3-ab9b-4039-89e3-c915578f976d.text: No person is free who is not master of themselves.
7add31d3-ab9b-4039-89e3-c915578f976d.author: Epictetus

f1960442-4217-48c3-99b0-a4e85c1e7195.text: Nothing great comes into being all at once, for that is not the case even with a bunch of grapes or a fig. If you tell me now, ‘I want a fig,’ I’ll reply, ‘That takes time.
f1960442-4217-48c3-99b0-a4e85c1e7195.author: Epictetus

0d5c07fd-64f1-4096-82a6-c356a1e00954.text: On the occasion of every accident (event) that befalls you, remember to turn to yourself and inquire what power you have for turning it to use.
0d5c07fd-64f1-4096-82a6-c356a1e00954.author: Epictetus

745b0292-e336-4a31-84c2-0e30f5c3b161.text: On the occasion of every accident that befalls you, remember to turn to yourself and inquire what power you have for turning it to use.
745b0292-e336-4a31-84c2-0e30f5c3b161.author: Epictetus

af16b8e1-8210-40f3-80bb-4d503fa1e30d.text: Once I was liable to the same mistakes, but, thanks to God, no longer …’ Well, isn’t it just as worthwhile to have devoted and applied yourself to this goal as to have read or written fifty pages?
af16b8e1-8210-40f3-80bb-4d503fa1e30d.author: Epictetus

7210f31a-f4d6-486f-a6f3-95cb547809c4.text: Only consider at what price you sell your own will: if for no other reason, at least for this, that you sell it not for a small sum.
7210f31a-f4d6-486f-a6f3-95cb547809c4.author: Epictetus

05ef2045-1cbf-49a5-926e-3ba6721efae1.text: Other people's views and troubles can be contagious. Don't sabotage yourself by unwittingly adopting negative, unproductive attitudes through your associations with others.
05ef2045-1cbf-49a5-926e-3ba6721efae1.author: Epictetus

78c7242e-d487-40ce-a3dc-dba78f594963.text: People are not disturbed by things, but by the views they take of them.
78c7242e-d487-40ce-a3dc-dba78f594963.author: Epictetus

11a29a6a-1694-4c2a-9e2e-32560cc756dc.text: People are ready to acknowledge some of their faults, but will admit to others only with reluctance.
11a29a6a-1694-4c2a-9e2e-32560cc756dc.author: Epictetus

d3d08742-129a-4158-bfa1-ec051c9d54c9.text: People find particular things, however, frightening; and it's when someone is able to threaten or entice us with those that the man himself becomes frightening.
d3d08742-129a-4158-bfa1-ec051c9d54c9.author: Epictetus

1728f3cf-8d8c-472f-b91c-495b032b856e.text: People with a strong physical constitution can tolerate extremes of hot and cold; people of strong mental health can handle anger, grief, joy and the other emotions.
1728f3cf-8d8c-472f-b91c-495b032b856e.author: Epictetus

cb4f0388-c270-40f5-897c-f84a93b7b85c.text: Preach not to others what they should eat, but eat as becomes you and be silent.
cb4f0388-c270-40f5-897c-f84a93b7b85c.author: Epictetus

48369c66-2636-4f75-8e63-c991c939a332.text: Prefer enduring satisfaction to immediate gratification.
48369c66-2636-4f75-8e63-c991c939a332.author: Epictetus

369fa7d2-9406-4f38-80a7-fd03bc1561b5.text: Protect what belongs to you at all costs; don't desire what belongs to another.
369fa7d2-9406-4f38-80a7-fd03bc1561b5.author: Epictetus

6d08b095-9e0b-4321-bb74-b32df601944f.text: Reading should serve the goal of attaining peace; if it doesn’t make you peaceful, what good is it?
6d08b095-9e0b-4321-bb74-b32df601944f.author: Epictetus

e09ffc2b-a2e3-4d37-96bc-0ec47897524a.text: Remember from now on whenever something tends to make you unhappy, draw on this principle: 'This is no misfortune; but bearing with it bravely is a blessing.
e09ffc2b-a2e3-4d37-96bc-0ec47897524a.author: Epictetus

fc0d18bb-1c79-4b22-b5b0-dfffb624f606.text: Remember that the divine order is intelligent and fundamentally good. Life is not a series of random, meaningless episodes, but an ordered, elegant whole that follows ultimately comprehensible laws.
fc0d18bb-1c79-4b22-b5b0-dfffb624f606.author: Epictetus

2aba4aba-55d4-456f-b827-9af1604e8e40.text: Remember that you are an actor in a drama, of such a kind as the author pleases to make it. If short, of a short one; if long, of a long one.
2aba4aba-55d4-456f-b827-9af1604e8e40.author: Epictetus

e24c63fd-5f3d-49b4-a7b8-071707028dfe.text: Remind thyself that he whom thou lovest is mortal  that what thou lovest is not thine own; it is given thee for the present, not irrevocably nor for ever, but even as a fig or a bunch of grapes at the appointed season of the year.
e24c63fd-5f3d-49b4-a7b8-071707028dfe.author: Epictetus

18317707-7a42-484a-9d68-c9c5414a25fd.text: Resistance is vain in any case; it only leads to useless struggle while inviting grief and sorrow.
18317707-7a42-484a-9d68-c9c5414a25fd.author: Epictetus

5fa5029c-93c4-4ca1-b4ca-23ad3876f26a.text: Restrict yourself to choice and refusal; and exercise them carefully, with discipline and detachment.
5fa5029c-93c4-4ca1-b4ca-23ad3876f26a.author: Epictetus

9b13a17f-c7d1-41c3-8d1c-b309c5e4ab5d.text: Seek not for events to happen as you wish but rather wish for events to happen as they do and your life will go smoothly.
9b13a17f-c7d1-41c3-8d1c-b309c5e4ab5d.author: Epictetus

3b48a85e-f6d8-4ca3-bea9-90eab3520e58.text: Seek not that the things which happen should happen as you wish; but wish the things which happen to be as they are, and you will have a tranquil flow of life.
3b48a85e-f6d8-4ca3-bea9-90eab3520e58.author: Epictetus

550cadf2-bf24-4175-8ad2-bdae06201148.text: Seek not the good in external things;seek it in yourselves.
550cadf2-bf24-4175-8ad2-bdae06201148.author: Epictetus

3eff1041-92f5-4a26-b817-c1cbf2aa4ebc.text: Show me a man who though sick is happy, who though in danger is happy, who though in prison is happy, and I'll show you a Stoic.
3eff1041-92f5-4a26-b817-c1cbf2aa4ebc.author: Epictetus

48e9d3fa-1544-4e1f-91fa-1471c553bf5d.text: Small-minded people blame others. Average people blame themselves. The wise see all blame as foolishness.
48e9d3fa-1544-4e1f-91fa-1471c553bf5d.author: Epictetus

7dd8f43d-ae22-4511-a716-9b66d066eff7.text: So don't make a show of your philosophical learning to the uninitiated, show them by your actions what you have absorbed.
7dd8f43d-ae22-4511-a716-9b66d066eff7.author: Epictetus

fc7b7883-88ab-46c4-85bc-6dc3b31a6736.text: So what oppresses and scares us? It is our own thoughts, obviously, What overwhelms people when they are about to leaves friends, family, old haunts and their accustomed way of life? Thoughts.
fc7b7883-88ab-46c4-85bc-6dc3b31a6736.author: Epictetus

0cc21fed-0914-4759-a3f2-3770c9415664.text: Some things are up to us, and some things are not up to us.
0cc21fed-0914-4759-a3f2-3770c9415664.author: Epictetus

8c31bd41-2612-4c29-b789-2161600d9293.text: Stop honouring externals, quit turning yourself into the tool of mere matter, or of people who can supply you or deny you those material things.
8c31bd41-2612-4c29-b789-2161600d9293.author: Epictetus

33fbf5cc-584d-4c68-95fc-0c9ba994aa8f.text: Take care not to hurt the ruling faculty of your mind. If you were to guard against this in every action, you should enter upon those actions more safely.
33fbf5cc-584d-4c68-95fc-0c9ba994aa8f.author: Epictetus

93c41082-9253-4184-a22e-da36d2c97364.text: Taking account of the value of externals, you see, comes at some cost to the value of one's own character.
93c41082-9253-4184-a22e-da36d2c97364.author: Epictetus

faa1cf4d-b7d3-45c5-baa5-6861c181ce6d.text: Tell yourself what you want to be, then act your part accordingly.
faa1cf4d-b7d3-45c5-baa5-6861c181ce6d.author: Epictetus

e89f87dc-924a-40aa-a267-7db2a8cb5f22.text: That is the way things are weighed and disagreements settled — when standards are established. Philosophy aims to test and set such standards. And the wise man is advised to make use of their findings right way.
e89f87dc-924a-40aa-a267-7db2a8cb5f22.author: Epictetus

da3df28e-c753-4a40-adc3-52b5e7383123.text: The essence of philosophy is that a man should so live that his happiness shall depend as little as possible on external things.
da3df28e-c753-4a40-adc3-52b5e7383123.author: Epictetus

e33da70d-2384-4a46-b1c1-9d26c85fcdf1.text: The good of man, and likewise his ill, lies in how he exercises his choice, while everything else is nothing to us.
e33da70d-2384-4a46-b1c1-9d26c85fcdf1.author: Epictetus

b21dd865-263e-4431-af3b-cdb74141862d.text: The greater the difficulty, the more glory in surmounting it. Skillful pilots gain their reputation from storms and tempests.
b21dd865-263e-4431-af3b-cdb74141862d.author: Epictetus

d85b32f3-747c-463f-8164-03505783e736.text: The husbandman deals with land; physicians and trainers with the body; the wise man with his own Mind.
d85b32f3-747c-463f-8164-03505783e736.author: Epictetus

d45f5b56-ccf3-44e2-85b4-0839f31be49a.text: The key is to keep company only with people who uplift you, whose presence calls forth your best.
d45f5b56-ccf3-44e2-85b4-0839f31be49a.author: Epictetus

1b04a32f-c711-4058-9ab2-af12fc432ad4.text: The knowledge of what is mine and what is not mine, what I can and cannot do. I must die. But must I die bawling? I must be exiled; but is there anything to keep me from going with a smile, calm and self-composed?
1b04a32f-c711-4058-9ab2-af12fc432ad4.author: Epictetus

317b3ff0-c602-4fd2-a185-915287c10ab6.text: The more we value things outside our control, the less control we have.
317b3ff0-c602-4fd2-a185-915287c10ab6.author: Epictetus

5028b7ab-35f8-4018-b3c6-9975e4ec4372.text: The philosopher's lecture room is a 'hospital': you ought not to walk out of it in a state of pleasure, but in pain; for you are not in good condition when you arrive.
5028b7ab-35f8-4018-b3c6-9975e4ec4372.author: Epictetus

88c31cb9-fd3f-4301-b192-b59fb3b88c74.text: The philosopher's school, ye men, is a surgery: you ought not to go out of it with pleasure, but with pain. For you are not in sound health when you enter.
88c31cb9-fd3f-4301-b192-b59fb3b88c74.author: Epictetus

2405986c-740a-4a0e-985b-22009b0c9831.text: The wise person knows it is fruitless to project hopes and fears on the future. This only leads to forming melodramatic representations in your mind and wasting time.
2405986c-740a-4a0e-985b-22009b0c9831.author: Epictetus

266fce7f-2fe0-4fea-98d5-aff9b1fc1a54.text: There are two things that must be rooted out in human beings - arrogant opinion and mistrust. Arrogant opinion expects that there is nothing further needed, and mistrust assumes that under the torrent of circumstance there can be no happiness.
266fce7f-2fe0-4fea-98d5-aff9b1fc1a54.author: Epictetus

1343109c-130b-4836-a5c6-fe3e3042729e.text: There is a time and place for diversion and amusements, but you should never allow them to override your true purposes.
1343109c-130b-4836-a5c6-fe3e3042729e.author: Epictetus

81ed1078-16bf-4f11-9248-110ea6185974.text: There is but one way to tranquility of mind and happiness, and that is to account no external things thine own, but to commit all to God.
81ed1078-16bf-4f11-9248-110ea6185974.author: Epictetus

c905835d-ecc2-4a20-8aa6-1039ba3ba6f0.text: There is no shame in making an honest effort.
c905835d-ecc2-4a20-8aa6-1039ba3ba6f0.author: Epictetus

6a629cbd-ddc0-4855-9012-849519b99539.text: There is only one way to happiness and that is to cease worrying about things which are beyond the power of our will.
6a629cbd-ddc0-4855-9012-849519b99539.author: Epictetus

4885d726-f7ba-4af9-bd04-6cb607476a66.text: There is only one way to happiness and that is to cease worrying about things which are beyond the power or our will.
4885d726-f7ba-4af9-bd04-6cb607476a66.author: Epictetus

d32917e3-9df1-45e6-a236-93f569c91f61.text: This is your business—to act well the given part, but to choose it belongs to another.
d32917e3-9df1-45e6-a236-93f569c91f61.author: Epictetus

3da31d2c-567b-499c-a29b-e866ee82ce45.text: Those proficient praise no one, blame no one, and accuse no one. They say nothing concerning their self as being anybody or knowing anything.
3da31d2c-567b-499c-a29b-e866ee82ce45.author: Epictetus

3f682b93-b182-4c97-9030-7d0e0fe54acd.text: Those who are well constituted in the body endure both heat and cold: and so those who are well constituted in the soul endure both anger and grief and excessive joy and the other affects.
3f682b93-b182-4c97-9030-7d0e0fe54acd.author: Epictetus

fae53012-6384-455e-b304-42fb74f91adb.text: Thus Socrates became perfect, improving himself by everything. attending to nothing but reason. And though you are not yet a Socrates, you ought, however, to live as one desirous of becoming a Socrates.
fae53012-6384-455e-b304-42fb74f91adb.author: Epictetus

91f76ff1-97c4-468c-93fa-e107a400d1d3.text: Times relieves the foolish from sorrow, but reason relieves the wise.
91f76ff1-97c4-468c-93fa-e107a400d1d3.author: Epictetus

85dc72cb-bdb3-4e90-8596-1b24021b8106.text: Tis true I know what evil I shall do but passion overpowers the better council.
85dc72cb-bdb3-4e90-8596-1b24021b8106.author: Epictetus

44d4970e-d30e-4604-9ddc-ecf49b5d3d91.text: To accuse others for one's own misfortune is a sign of want of education. To accuse oneself shows that one's education has begun. To accuse neither oneself nor others shows that one's education is complete.
44d4970e-d30e-4604-9ddc-ecf49b5d3d91.author: Epictetus

0bdf995a-4e85-472f-8c7e-a04b776532a9.text: To admonish is better than to reproach for admonition is mild and friendly, but reproach is harsh and insulting; and admonition corrects those who are doing wrong, but reproach only convicts them.
0bdf995a-4e85-472f-8c7e-a04b776532a9.author: Epictetus

e99688de-25fc-4bda-8dbf-f1ee58839a17.text: Try to enjoy the great festival of life with other men.
e99688de-25fc-4bda-8dbf-f1ee58839a17.author: Epictetus

b02a3974-23a6-40a2-9c0d-59b9bd64fb58.text: Understand that every event is indifferent and nothing to you, of whatever sort it may be; for it will be in your power to make a right use of it, and this no one can hinder.
b02a3974-23a6-40a2-9c0d-59b9bd64fb58.author: Epictetus

5c88467c-35dd-40f0-9d3a-309a8276c114.text: Understand what words you use first, then use them.
5c88467c-35dd-40f0-9d3a-309a8276c114.author: Epictetus

18ba12c2-14bd-4dd4-bf68-63d7234fed66.text: Very little is needed for everything to be upset and ruined, only a slight lapse in reason.
18ba12c2-14bd-4dd4-bf68-63d7234fed66.author: Epictetus

3fb958d7-5dd7-4d30-806a-1df0b189ceba.text: We are at the mercy of whoever wields authority over the things we either desire or detest. If you would be free, then, do not wish to have, or avoid, things that other people control, because then you must serve as their slave.
3fb958d7-5dd7-4d30-806a-1df0b189ceba.author: Epictetus

377cb980-716b-4a3a-8ec0-3f5615a7ca6d.text: We are not disturbed by what happens to us, but by our thoughts about what happens to us.
377cb980-716b-4a3a-8ec0-3f5615a7ca6d.author: Epictetus

ba7b381f-5d7d-4c24-916f-a69b9b57d514.text: We aren't filled with fear except by things that are bad; and not by them, either, as long as it is in our power to avoid them.
ba7b381f-5d7d-4c24-916f-a69b9b57d514.author: Epictetus

148e09ea-3b42-41f3-bd72-5a098ca8a0d5.text: We cannot choose our external circumstances, but we can always choose how we respond to them.
148e09ea-3b42-41f3-bd72-5a098ca8a0d5.author: Epictetus

0d969de0-9c22-4064-a9b7-d92f28df12c6.text: We have two ears and one mouth so that we can listen twice as much as we speak.
0d969de0-9c22-4064-a9b7-d92f28df12c6.author: Epictetus

0f8c412f-d063-40da-9c4b-df426fcd90bd.text: We must not believe the many, who say that only free people ought to be educated, but we should rather believe the philosophers who say that only the educated are free.
0f8c412f-d063-40da-9c4b-df426fcd90bd.author: Epictetus

76d937c8-fef8-4656-9f38-d8ec67e881c5.text: We should put our trust not in the crowd, who say that only free men can be educated, but rather in the philosophers, who say that none but the educated can be free.
76d937c8-fef8-4656-9f38-d8ec67e881c5.author: Epictetus

d6101e1f-ffa8-4aed-a41b-b6334f1302ec.text: We should realize that an opinion is not easily formed unless a person says and hears the same things every day and practises them in real life.
d6101e1f-ffa8-4aed-a41b-b6334f1302ec.author: Epictetus

8db5d143-93b3-40e9-96fb-02a140aa4722.text: We suffer not from the events in our lives but from our judgement about them.
8db5d143-93b3-40e9-96fb-02a140aa4722.author: Epictetus

fc645020-0312-4cc1-8245-72f54d2a6168.text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
fc645020-0312-4cc1-8245-72f54d2a6168.author: Epictetus

a8bf293b-1abb-478d-bbd0-71be3972b012.text: What are we to do, then? To make the best of what lies within our power, and deal with everything else as it comes. ‘How does it come, then?’ As God wills.
a8bf293b-1abb-478d-bbd0-71be3972b012.author: Epictetus

3d56d359-7a76-418c-a422-d2e82caa6187.text: What concerns me is not the way things are, but the way people think things are.
3d56d359-7a76-418c-a422-d2e82caa6187.author: Epictetus

ed1b3c54-db26-4275-a414-76ca07358e71.text: What makes for freedom and fluency in the practice of writing? Knowledge of how to write. The same goes for the practice of playing an instrument. It follows that, in the conduct of life, there must be a science to living well.
ed1b3c54-db26-4275-a414-76ca07358e71.author: Epictetus

590d061c-ee32-42cf-85ab-f20c30cd1250.text: What really frightens and dismays us is not external events themselves, but the way in which we think about them. It is not things that disturb us, but our interpretation of their significance.
590d061c-ee32-42cf-85ab-f20c30cd1250.author: Epictetus

9991a2db-1294-4ce5-b44d-f94ca9d17fd5.text: What saith Antisthenes? Hast thou never heard?— It is a kingly thing, O Cyrus, to do well and to be evil spoken of.
9991a2db-1294-4ce5-b44d-f94ca9d17fd5.author: Epictetus

4fadb89a-4ced-4329-b512-e9f0698a5f2b.text: What upsets people is not things themselves but their judgements about these things.
4fadb89a-4ced-4329-b512-e9f0698a5f2b.author: Epictetus

02c312ec-fce0-4925-966f-97574598b784.text: Whatever moral rules you have deliberately proposed to yourself. abide by them as they were laws, and as if you would be guilty of impiety by violating any of them. Don’t regard what anyone says of you, for this, after all, is no concern of yours.
02c312ec-fce0-4925-966f-97574598b784.author: Epictetus

3c3e10b3-d99c-42c1-a705-4a02b7625117.text: Whatever your mission, stick by it as if it were a law and you would be committing sacrilege to betray it. Pay no attention to whatever people might say; this no longer should influence you.
3c3e10b3-d99c-42c1-a705-4a02b7625117.author: Epictetus

af8a8cd4-511a-4a9a-b918-99a23a014e3d.text: When a man is proud because he can understand and explain the writings of Chrysippus, say to yourself, if Chrysippus had not written obscurely, this man would have had nothing to be proud of.
af8a8cd4-511a-4a9a-b918-99a23a014e3d.author: Epictetus

edecff73-cb1d-4f29-ba49-5bb8ba6b57ed.text: When a youth was giving himself airs in the Theatre and saying, 'I am wise, for I have conversed with many wise men,' Epictetus replied, 'I too have conversed with many rich men, yet I am not rich!’.
edecff73-cb1d-4f29-ba49-5bb8ba6b57ed.author: Epictetus

ac75a41d-658a-4399-a008-5c95ddc5006c.text: When someone is properly grounded in life, they shouldn't have to look outside themselves for approval.
ac75a41d-658a-4399-a008-5c95ddc5006c.author: Epictetus

071c2e7d-67b9-4d61-94be-dff8537200d4.text: When something happens, the only thing in your power is your attitude toward it; you can either accept it or resent it.
071c2e7d-67b9-4d61-94be-dff8537200d4.author: Epictetus

8171247f-ab84-4971-bb1c-dd05c9d88171.text: When then any man assents to that which is false, be assured that he did not intend to assent to it as false, for every soul is unwillingly deprived of the truth, as Plato says; but the falsity seemed to him to be true.
8171247f-ab84-4971-bb1c-dd05c9d88171.author: Epictetus

e174d667-76f5-44a3-91a7-c941f0534017.text: When things seem to have reached that stage, merely say “I won’t play any longer”, and take your departure; but if you stay, stop lamenting.
e174d667-76f5-44a3-91a7-c941f0534017.author: Epictetus

328a9ff3-f724-4eff-b82f-c09e4d0ed9b5.text: When you are feeling upset, angry, or sad, don’t blame another for your state of mind. Your condition is the result of your own opinions and interpretations.
328a9ff3-f724-4eff-b82f-c09e4d0ed9b5.author: Epictetus

597cb901-6fe1-48ea-ac58-45d28163b1fd.text: When you find your direction, check to make sure that it is the right one.
597cb901-6fe1-48ea-ac58-45d28163b1fd.author: Epictetus

8483352c-bf3d-4795-aff3-afbd5f831c21.text: Who are those people by whom you wish to be admired? Are they not these whom you are in the habit of saying that they are mad? What then? Do you wish to be admired by the mad?
8483352c-bf3d-4795-aff3-afbd5f831c21.author: Epictetus

902f7102-0ea6-44d8-8af5-ec6de6b7dba0.text: Who is your master? Whoever has authority over anything that you’re anxious to gain or avoid.
902f7102-0ea6-44d8-8af5-ec6de6b7dba0.author: Epictetus

02322d46-364b-4f11-aeb4-0d064cbeca2f.text: Who then is invincible? The one who cannot be upset by anything outside their reasoned choice.
02322d46-364b-4f11-aeb4-0d064cbeca2f.author: Epictetus

e44cabd9-d80a-46d9-b077-aa69c64fb4c1.text: Who, then, is the invincible human being? One who can be disconcerted by nothing that lies outside the sphere of choice.
e44cabd9-d80a-46d9-b077-aa69c64fb4c1.author: Epictetus

a0ee0767-0d37-4e3b-8668-83661b41b6f0.text: Whoever chafes at the conditions dealt by fate is unskilled in the art of life; whoever bears with them nobly and makes wise use of the results is a man who deserves to be considered good.
a0ee0767-0d37-4e3b-8668-83661b41b6f0.author: Epictetus

92e390c0-c52c-44df-9265-baebd2169aa0.text: Whoever is going to listen to the philosophers needs a considerable practice in listening.
92e390c0-c52c-44df-9265-baebd2169aa0.author: Epictetus

0e788060-2ed1-4540-90ac-1735fb8e35e4.text: Whoever then would be free, let him wish for nothing, let him decline nothing, which depends on others; else he must necessarily be a slave.
0e788060-2ed1-4540-90ac-1735fb8e35e4.author: Epictetus

deb94379-b6ef-4f04-a3b1-62a7ffedf66f.text: Whoever then would be free, let him wish nothing, let him decline nothing, which depends on others; else he must necessarily be a slave.
deb94379-b6ef-4f04-a3b1-62a7ffedf66f.author: Epictetus

2c5b3b9b-2cd3-49ca-a8da-4be90469c70e.text: Why are you pestering me, pal? My own evils are enough for me.
2c5b3b9b-2cd3-49ca-a8da-4be90469c70e.author: Epictetus

979edfb9-753a-4d2f-87f7-319d4cffb670.text: Why do you want to read anyway – for the sake of amusement or mere erudition? Those are poor, fatuous pretexts.  Reading should serve the goal of attaining peace; if it doesn’t make you peaceful, what good is it?
979edfb9-753a-4d2f-87f7-319d4cffb670.author: Epictetus

a5f56b14-6629-467d-ab48-9a8a6ba97397.text: Working within our sphere of control, we are naturally free, independent, and strong. Beyond that sphere, we are weak, limited, and dependent.
a5f56b14-6629-467d-ab48-9a8a6ba97397.author: Epictetus

dc232fef-57ee-4351-81d3-925de4700a2d.text: Yes, but my nose is running.’ Then what do you have hands for, you slave?
dc232fef-57ee-4351-81d3-925de4700a2d.author: Epictetus

58a3c9f4-9fb8-4c0c-942f-7a8f54cc9bf5.text: You are a little soul carrying a dead body, as Epictetus said.
58a3c9f4-9fb8-4c0c-942f-7a8f54cc9bf5.author: Epictetus

9f459ccd-bd66-4947-afce-b0f119521950.text: You are a little soul carrying around a corpse.
9f459ccd-bd66-4947-afce-b0f119521950.author: Epictetus

db20391e-60fc-4963-af2d-6f2bc6426db6.text: You are the one who knows yourself - which is to say, you know how much you are worth in your own estimation, and therefore at what price you will sell yourself; because people sell themselves at different rates.
db20391e-60fc-4963-af2d-6f2bc6426db6.author: Epictetus

8457d5e4-6154-4c97-a5da-a29a1a26a6b8.text: You become what you give your attention to.
8457d5e4-6154-4c97-a5da-a29a1a26a6b8.author: Epictetus

65a977fd-2302-4192-a02a-37216380e5b8.text: You may fetter my leg, but Zeus himself cannot get the better of my free will.
65a977fd-2302-4192-a02a-37216380e5b8.author: Epictetus

fe49f090-e902-40e8-98b4-c91a10f0b94c.text: You must be one man, either good or bad. You must cultivate either your own ruling faculty or externals, and apply yourself either to things within or without you; that is, be either a philosopher, or one of the vulgar.
fe49f090-e902-40e8-98b4-c91a10f0b94c.author: Epictetus

3fb78a53-ef65-4eac-9809-88205cbaafb1.text: You only have to doze a moment, and all is lost. For ruin and salvation both have their source inside you.
3fb78a53-ef65-4eac-9809-88205cbaafb1.author: Epictetus

279f5cf1-4dba-4d8a-894a-eceda9137db9.text: You see, then, that it is necessary for you to become a student, that creature which every one laughs at, if you really desire to make an examination of your judgements. But this, as you are quite aware, is not the work of a single hour or day.
279f5cf1-4dba-4d8a-894a-eceda9137db9.author: Epictetus

daf8efd1-1c8b-42f1-8ef5-793af2315038.text: You will do the greatest services to the state, if you shall raise not the roofs of the houses, but the souls of the citizens: for it is better that great souls should dwell in small houses than for mean slaves to lurk in great houses.
daf8efd1-1c8b-42f1-8ef5-793af2315038.author: Epictetus

28c6a95c-b3b4-493d-9c07-71d6ea4cd6e5.text: You will never have to experience defeat if you avoid contests whose outcome is outside your control.
28c6a95c-b3b4-493d-9c07-71d6ea4cd6e5.author: Epictetus

d8c876f5-a118-4bdc-84d3-e98bc1516f4c.text: You'd have a better chance persuading someone to change their sexual orientation than reaching people who have rendered themselves so deaf and blind.
d8c876f5-a118-4bdc-84d3-e98bc1516f4c.author: Epictetus

aa5195a5-60a0-4ca7-8ee1-124327b60bee.text: You're not yet Socrates, but you can still live as if you want to be him.
aa5195a5-60a0-4ca7-8ee1-124327b60bee.author: Epictetus

1d03f0f5-97bc-4a90-8b43-244a455a7904.text: Your happiness depends on three things, all of which are within your power: your will, your ideas concerning the events in which you are involved, and the use you make of your ideas.
1d03f0f5-97bc-4a90-8b43-244a455a7904.author: Epictetus

305691d1-a77f-4579-9627-8b72b84ce8e5.text: You’re unable to make someone change his views, recognize that he is a child, and clap as he does. Or if you don’t care to act in such a way, you have only to keep quiet.
305691d1-a77f-4579-9627-8b72b84ce8e5.author: Epictetus

2146e41d-0649-41ae-92c4-7d46b9e19b90.text: “I am richer than you, therefore my property is greater than yours;” “I am more eloquent than you, therefore my style is better than yours.” But you, after all, are neither property nor style.
2146e41d-0649-41ae-92c4-7d46b9e19b90.author: Epictetus

c57f8fb4-5353-405e-b92c-c7780bb508aa.text: "No one," he says, "leaves this world in a different manner from one who has just been born." That is not true; for we are worse when we die than when we were born; but it is our fault, and not that of Nature.
c57f8fb4-5353-405e-b92c-c7780bb508aa.author: Seneca

13136051-c614-4417-8913-c09bf848e1db.text: "Non est ad astra mollis e terris via" - "There is no easy way from the earth to the stars."
13136051-c614-4417-8913-c09bf848e1db.author: Seneca

7d29ebb4-dcee-4540-804c-5e6815077b6a.text: "Well then, shall we act like other men? Shall there be no distinction between ourselves and the world?" Yes, a very great one; let men find that we are unlike the common herd, if they look closely.
7d29ebb4-dcee-4540-804c-5e6815077b6a.author: Seneca

f4dce70f-9335-43ed-a51d-e6d80abdf82d.text: "What progress, you ask, have I made? I have begun to be a friend to myself." That was indeed a great benefit; such a person can never be alone. You may be sure that such a man is a friend to all mankind.
f4dce70f-9335-43ed-a51d-e6d80abdf82d.author: Seneca

25b919be-e282-4049-808f-37f4134b6905.text: 'It is unbearable to be deprived of your country.' Come now, look at this mass of people whom the buildings of huge Rome can scarcely hold: most of that crowd are deprived of their country.
25b919be-e282-4049-808f-37f4134b6905.author: Seneca

fc5b781d-34ee-4372-ac9c-13182c54c7cc.text: A family formed by crime must be broken by more crime.
fc5b781d-34ee-4372-ac9c-13182c54c7cc.author: Seneca

526ccdf9-39c4-418c-b197-8d9ba845bf93.text: A gift consists not in what is done or given, but in the intention of the giver or doer.
526ccdf9-39c4-418c-b197-8d9ba845bf93.author: Seneca

b892b8f8-0103-42c3-b0e0-b8bf6cf7a90b.text: A good man will not waste himself upon mean and discreditable work or be busy merely for the sake of being busy.
b892b8f8-0103-42c3-b0e0-b8bf6cf7a90b.author: Seneca

bfbe9a84-603e-4778-a3ec-c1b6ebea1508.text: A great mind becomes a great fortune.
bfbe9a84-603e-4778-a3ec-c1b6ebea1508.author: Seneca

4320236f-1899-448c-992f-bae7cf0df7eb.text: A grey-haired wrinkled man has not necessarily lived long. More accurately, he has existed long.
4320236f-1899-448c-992f-bae7cf0df7eb.author: Seneca

b23f2583-217c-4b7b-b072-0d033febc179.text: A guilty person sometimes has the luck to escape detection, but never to feel sure of it.
b23f2583-217c-4b7b-b072-0d033febc179.author: Seneca

72d2a3ec-4542-4230-9000-a4c7896fec1a.text: A hungry people neither listens to reason nor is mollified by fair treatment or swayed by any appeals.
72d2a3ec-4542-4230-9000-a4c7896fec1a.author: Seneca

37068a87-64c9-45c7-b222-63e1c6e81519.text: A man should therefore grow accustomed to his state and complain about it as little as possible, seizing upon whatever good it may have.
37068a87-64c9-45c7-b222-63e1c6e81519.author: Seneca

42d22597-4908-492c-ae92-7a52a62667e8.text: A man who makes a decision without listening to both sides is unjust, even if his ruling is a fair one.
42d22597-4908-492c-ae92-7a52a62667e8.author: Seneca

72ce4b26-efcb-4b22-b32f-5c4ec6560cbd.text: A man's peace of mind does not depend upon Fortune; for, even when angry she grants enough for our needs.
72ce4b26-efcb-4b22-b32f-5c4ec6560cbd.author: Seneca

64d1efd5-f90f-4d01-b3e8-552f67c8212c.text: A man’s past is forever set in stone.
64d1efd5-f90f-4d01-b3e8-552f67c8212c.author: Seneca

9e901400-e8ab-4bb7-8a2f-b14813324f99.text: A multitude of books only gets in one's way. So if you are unable to read all the books in your possession, you have enough when you have all the books you are able to read.
9e901400-e8ab-4bb7-8a2f-b14813324f99.author: Seneca

c900250e-f495-4e07-a58f-26cf0ccdefe7.text: A person teaching and a person learning,' he said, 'should have the same end in view: the improvement of the latter.
c900250e-f495-4e07-a58f-26cf0ccdefe7.author: Seneca

6913d28c-c1b9-4bd6-864a-9ce91b50828d.text: A person's fears are lighter when the danger is at hand.
6913d28c-c1b9-4bd6-864a-9ce91b50828d.author: Seneca

b549b601-b571-436a-9378-a0d3753887ff.text: A pleasure that is ephemeral brings no true satisfaction to any man. How miserable must be the lives of those folk who labor so hard for something that once gained they must work even harder to keep.
b549b601-b571-436a-9378-a0d3753887ff.author: Seneca

86eb0dd9-185b-44c6-ad7e-342b6ca173ee.text: A sword never kills anybody; it is a tool in the killer's hand.
86eb0dd9-185b-44c6-ad7e-342b6ca173ee.author: Seneca

1b33f7fe-ba4e-486a-ad5a-8db04dd6497a.text: A wise man never asks what another man serves, for only his actions will speak the truth.
1b33f7fe-ba4e-486a-ad5a-8db04dd6497a.author: Seneca

53efc5e0-f78e-44c3-9a3f-9b28166c680a.text: A woman is not beautiful when her ankle or arm wins compliments, but when her total appearance diverts admiration from the individual parts of her body.
53efc5e0-f78e-44c3-9a3f-9b28166c680a.author: Seneca

4ecedb3c-bdda-432d-84cc-c2135da44217.text: Ab honesto virum bonum nihil deterret. (Nothing deters a good man from doing what is honorable.)-A Wrinkle in Time.
4ecedb3c-bdda-432d-84cc-c2135da44217.author: Seneca

0a833f68-da7d-4e39-ae07-690d83656329.text: Above all, my dear Lucilius, make this your business: learn how to feel joy.
0a833f68-da7d-4e39-ae07-690d83656329.author: Seneca

3b6f0586-4f97-4276-b07e-e16b979cd266.text: After friendship is formed you must trust, but before that you must judge.
3b6f0586-4f97-4276-b07e-e16b979cd266.author: Seneca

17b09779-9610-4864-97b8-4683b6ee6de3.text: After friendship is formed you must trust, but before that you must judge. Those people who, contrary to Theophrastus’ advice, judge a man after they have made him their friend instead of the other way round, certainly put the cart before the horse.
17b09779-9610-4864-97b8-4683b6ee6de3.author: Seneca

f90e630b-dfb8-434d-8193-ed31a13f8ff3.text: Again, when my mind is lifted up by the greatness of its thoughts, it becomes ambitious for words and longs to match its higher inspiration with its language, and so produces a style that conforms to the impressiveness of the subject matter.
f90e630b-dfb8-434d-8193-ed31a13f8ff3.author: Seneca

31066df6-c62f-4267-90e4-959176ad8b3d.text: All fools suffer the burden of dissatisfaction with themselves.
31066df6-c62f-4267-90e4-959176ad8b3d.author: Seneca

64113d32-4187-4d14-8929-811f61288ce2.text: All life is a servitude. So you have to get used to your circumstances, complain about them as little as possible, and grasp whatever advantage they have to offer: no condition is so bitter that a stable mind cannot find some consolation in it.
64113d32-4187-4d14-8929-811f61288ce2.author: Seneca

7bd12b3a-5d02-4fba-9b79-90a489276cc4.text: All outdoors may be bedlam, provided there is no disturbance within.
7bd12b3a-5d02-4fba-9b79-90a489276cc4.author: Seneca

52d477cd-72d0-480d-b67e-de7fdfcc134e.text: All that remains of our existence is not actually life but merely time.
52d477cd-72d0-480d-b67e-de7fdfcc134e.author: Seneca

cf3aa50c-3c49-4412-b52f-7e716bb2c6f0.text: All the greatest blessings are a source of anxiety, and at no time is fortune less wisely trusted than when it is best.
cf3aa50c-3c49-4412-b52f-7e716bb2c6f0.author: Seneca

1d0b78a3-53a5-4831-ab23-98921ff2f8f5.text: All the greatest blessings create anxiety, and Fortune is never less to be trusted than when it is fairest.
1d0b78a3-53a5-4831-ab23-98921ff2f8f5.author: Seneca

ef6dcfef-54f0-4053-ac66-fa13dd41d9b5.text: All the works of mortal man have been doomed to mortality, and in the midst of things which have been destined to die, we live!
ef6dcfef-54f0-4053-ac66-fa13dd41d9b5.author: Seneca

b154b263-6541-496d-8883-9d0adce637cc.text: All things that are still to come lie in uncertainty; live straightway!
b154b263-6541-496d-8883-9d0adce637cc.author: Seneca

1e9caba7-5ab1-4caf-94a6-21d2549b591f.text: All things were ready for us at our birth; it is we that have made everything difficult for ourselves, through our disdain for what is easy.
1e9caba7-5ab1-4caf-94a6-21d2549b591f.author: Seneca

83bb0df5-e9b0-4343-9777-894cd9bd4790.text: All this hurrying from place to place won’t bring you any relief, for you’re traveling in the company of your own emotions, followed by your troubles all the way.
83bb0df5-e9b0-4343-9777-894cd9bd4790.author: Seneca

93c8ed98-2ee2-4018-b005-af9804ddd625.text: All those who call you to themselves draw you away from yourself.
93c8ed98-2ee2-4018-b005-af9804ddd625.author: Seneca

06cb7103-54ba-47d5-9572-3e9694836d59.text: Although the sum and substance of the happy life is unalloyed freedom from care, and though the secret of such freedom is unshaken confidence... men gather together that which causes worry.
06cb7103-54ba-47d5-9572-3e9694836d59.author: Seneca

5fe181e7-3d4f-43b0-b4f6-6820688e9ce5.text: Am I not to inquire into the identity of the artist of this universe?
5fe181e7-3d4f-43b0-b4f6-6820688e9ce5.author: Seneca

ed7bcadd-d866-4077-ac68-d010e072e17f.text: An unpopular rule is never long maintained.
ed7bcadd-d866-4077-ac68-d010e072e17f.author: Seneca

09bcfc42-5da3-47b9-bc0f-144836dcee71.text: And I hold that no man has treated mankind worse than he who has studied philosophy as if it were some marketable trade, who lives in a different manner from that which he advises.
09bcfc42-5da3-47b9-bc0f-144836dcee71.author: Seneca

6933c4ce-5e08-4428-b6eb-6e5c445ccb02.text: And there’s no state of slavery more disgraceful than one which is self-imposed.
6933c4ce-5e08-4428-b6eb-6e5c445ccb02.author: Seneca

a6e70e92-e155-4bb8-9ee1-961218e4a07b.text: And what is more wretched than a man who forgets his benefits and clings to his injuries?
a6e70e92-e155-4bb8-9ee1-961218e4a07b.author: Seneca

90455db5-e7e8-4020-88da-e5a74a2e1b61.text: And what’s so bad about your being deprived of that? All things seem unbearable to people who have become spoilt, who have become soft through a life of luxury, ailing more in the mind than they ever are in the body.
90455db5-e7e8-4020-88da-e5a74a2e1b61.author: Seneca

471d4414-4137-4430-929d-658d58046340.text: And when the soul has yielded to pleasure, its functions and actions grow weak, and any undertaking comes from a nerveless and unsteady source.
471d4414-4137-4430-929d-658d58046340.author: Seneca

43c67d4e-68e5-4d4b-bb46-1cda663b4289.text: Anger will abate and become more controlled when it knows it must come before a judge each day.
43c67d4e-68e5-4d4b-bb46-1cda663b4289.author: Seneca

3f1ea5aa-a67c-4ef6-8ce1-1a8e274f0072.text: Anger, if not restrained, is frequently more hurtful to us than the injury that provokes it.
3f1ea5aa-a67c-4ef6-8ce1-1a8e274f0072.author: Seneca

c7b44eeb-8433-4049-b91c-7245f8fef42e.text: Any man, who does not think that what he has is more than ample, is an unhappy man, even if he is the master of the whole world.
c7b44eeb-8433-4049-b91c-7245f8fef42e.author: Seneca

d66b15ff-5a33-4ad0-af08-6cf87f80ce38.text: Any man,’ he says, ‘who does not think that what he has is more than ample, is an unhappy man, even if he is the master of the whole world.
d66b15ff-5a33-4ad0-af08-6cf87f80ce38.author: Seneca

1edb4c08-591e-4e63-8552-77774c7d80f0.text: Anyone who likes may make things easier for himself by viewing them with equanimity.
1edb4c08-591e-4e63-8552-77774c7d80f0.author: Seneca

6b324115-ed5a-42bd-9646-3a86c3c0c8df.text: Apparently, when the arrogant King of Persia beheld the vastness of his troops spread out across boundless plains, he shed copious tears when he realized that not one man amongst his prodigious army would be alive in a hundred years’ time.
6b324115-ed5a-42bd-9646-3a86c3c0c8df.author: Seneca

a24b3cf6-0917-42ae-97ef-60e9173d87d8.text: As is a tale, so is life: not how long it is, but how good it is, is what matters.
a24b3cf6-0917-42ae-97ef-60e9173d87d8.author: Seneca

7da5c5ea-6cf1-47ee-923e-c7a03fc9f138.text: As it is with a play, so it is with life - what matters is not how long the acting lasts, but how good it is.
7da5c5ea-6cf1-47ee-923e-c7a03fc9f138.author: Seneca

14d1907f-6397-409c-a3f4-e9886429b2b7.text: As long as you live, keep learning how to live.
14d1907f-6397-409c-a3f4-e9886429b2b7.author: Seneca

83cfa818-c58c-4f5d-9931-ef5b39de2346.text: As often as I have been amongst men, I have returned less a man.
83cfa818-c58c-4f5d-9931-ef5b39de2346.author: Seneca

0009c79c-7313-4389-a739-a64a8cb725e2.text: As things are, there is about wisdom a nobility and magnificence in the fact that she didn't just fall to a person's lot, that each man owes her to his own efforts, that one doesn't go to anyone other than oneself to find her.
0009c79c-7313-4389-a739-a64a8cb725e2.author: Seneca

3a86d740-abf3-4408-98f0-c06143359f57.text: As to what the future's uncertain lot has in store, why should I demand of Fortune that she give rather than demand of myself that I should not crave?
3a86d740-abf3-4408-98f0-c06143359f57.author: Seneca

a92101e6-03a0-4879-9784-5cfebae880fc.text: Ask about those whose names are learned by heart, and you will see that they have these distinguishing marks: X cultivates Y and Y cultivates Z – no one bothers about himself.
a92101e6-03a0-4879-9784-5cfebae880fc.author: Seneca
