64995c52-6ffb-4387-bf7e-2a9461da2290.text: Ask nature: she will tell you that she made both day and night.
64995c52-6ffb-4387-bf7e-2a9461da2290.author: Seneca

d9c3b95b-d284-4be4-a6af-54d18c6f0bee.text: Associate with people who are likely to improve you.
d9c3b95b-d284-4be4-a6af-54d18c6f0bee.author: Seneca

6d788aef-3c3a-426d-8240-f7015f8798b4.text: Associate with those who will make a better man of you. Welcome those whom you yourself can improve. The process is mutual; for men learn while they teach.
6d788aef-3c3a-426d-8240-f7015f8798b4.author: Seneca

7aa74e5f-8a08-4f45-8513-91bf377b3bd9.text: Associate with those who will make a better man of you. Welcome those whom yourself can improve. Men learn while they teach.
7aa74e5f-8a08-4f45-8513-91bf377b3bd9.author: Seneca

50d06d6c-0350-4e6c-a84c-173f4128ba9c.text: Awake, my heart, And do such deeds as in the time to come No tongue shall praise, but none refuse to tell.
50d06d6c-0350-4e6c-a84c-173f4128ba9c.author: Seneca

365b3267-eeee-4182-88a7-7db9e0a6bdd0.text: Be aware, then, that every human condition is subject to change, and that whatever mishap can befall any man can also happen to you.
365b3267-eeee-4182-88a7-7db9e0a6bdd0.author: Seneca

06af68a2-e7cd-491b-8324-d57388723653.text: Be deaf to those who love you most of all; they pray for bad things with good intentions. .
06af68a2-e7cd-491b-8324-d57388723653.author: Seneca

f71bf8a7-fc9d-4fb0-99e7-d05d6caab3a4.text: because it is natural to touch more often the parts that hurt.
f71bf8a7-fc9d-4fb0-99e7-d05d6caab3a4.author: Seneca

4c927fbd-808c-4a0d-bb3a-5da68f2575ee.text: Because thou writest me often, I thank thee. Never do I receive a letter from thee, but immediately we are together.
4c927fbd-808c-4a0d-bb3a-5da68f2575ee.author: Seneca

2d77c6db-ec07-4950-b94b-692732336498.text: Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.
2d77c6db-ec07-4950-b94b-692732336498.author: Seneca

f02be729-5003-4cb6-b567-ba8394a0e116.text: Being without your country is not misery: you have thoroughly taught yourself by your studies to know that to a wise man every place is his country.
f02be729-5003-4cb6-b567-ba8394a0e116.author: Seneca

44299c08-a955-4521-9f69-a23f5ed4e702.text: Believe me if you consult philosophy she will persuade you not to lit so long at your counting desk.
44299c08-a955-4521-9f69-a23f5ed4e702.author: Seneca

c108b735-3e38-42ab-9dd1-f0438984875b.text: Believe me, it is the sign of a great man, and one who is above human error, not to allow his time to be frittered away: he has the longest possible life simply because whatever time was available he devoted entirely to himself.
c108b735-3e38-42ab-9dd1-f0438984875b.author: Seneca

89145ae2-fde7-46f7-892d-74bd0f6d6e18.text: Believe me, it takes a great man and one who has risen far above human weaknesses not to allow any of his time to be filched from him.
89145ae2-fde7-46f7-892d-74bd0f6d6e18.author: Seneca

5603e3b1-c32f-4862-ae46-1d17dbd78b16.text: Besides, he who is feared, fears also; no one has been able to arouse terror and live in peace of mind.
5603e3b1-c32f-4862-ae46-1d17dbd78b16.author: Seneca

027b12d8-5708-4b70-9b16-819f830d32cb.text: Beyond all things is the sea.
027b12d8-5708-4b70-9b16-819f830d32cb.author: Seneca

65274e6a-d3be-4dc9-b578-afcd4d3bd901.text: Brave men rejoice in adversity, just as brave soldiers triumph in war.
65274e6a-d3be-4dc9-b578-afcd4d3bd901.author: Seneca

f4b85aac-d99b-409a-8d3d-38f99dc6dffb.text: But consider whether you may not get more help from the customary method than from that which is now commonly called a "breviary," though in the good old days, when real Latin was spoken, it was called a "summary".
f4b85aac-d99b-409a-8d3d-38f99dc6dffb.author: Seneca

32ff651f-dab0-4c18-b5ab-524975dc7a8a.text: But every great and overpowering grief must take away the capacity to choose words, since it often stifles the voice itself.
32ff651f-dab0-4c18-b5ab-524975dc7a8a.author: Seneca

e27dc3ea-2dd0-44ab-9085-a20427ca756f.text: But he must have richly dyed purple clothes, woven with gold thread and decorated with multicoloured patterns: it is his fault, not nature’s, if he feels poor.
e27dc3ea-2dd0-44ab-9085-a20427ca756f.author: Seneca

6e1066b4-fc89-41fc-a392-d222a637312d.text: But he who bestows all of his time on his own needs, who plans out every day as if it were his last, neither longs for nor fears the morrow.
6e1066b4-fc89-41fc-a392-d222a637312d.author: Seneca

525da2eb-0414-4faa-a437-f70e5cf2f224.text: But learning how to live takes a whole life, and, which may surprise you more, it takes a whole life to learn how to die.
525da2eb-0414-4faa-a437-f70e5cf2f224.author: Seneca

9cc5c379-b861-4bd2-aaee-b2b7839a15c7.text: But learning how to live takes a whole life, and, which may surprise you more, it takes a whole life to learn how to die. So many of the finest men have put aside all.
9cc5c379-b861-4bd2-aaee-b2b7839a15c7.author: Seneca

8bc3a507-7b59-4172-9ec5-315d5320f3c6.text: But let him consider that those disorders which are so dangerous that they have gained ground in spite of treatment can generally be treated by opposite methods.
8bc3a507-7b59-4172-9ec5-315d5320f3c6.author: Seneca

35c1de66-8ac4-4ac8-91c2-c21c766b6776.text: But life is very short and anxious for those who forget the past, neglect the present, and fear the future.
35c1de66-8ac4-4ac8-91c2-c21c766b6776.author: Seneca

c6c56afe-a5e8-47fe-8c21-e2c37feb732d.text: But only philosophy will wake us; only philosophy will shake us out of that heavy sleep. Devote yourself entirely to her. You're worthy of her, she's worthy of you-fall into each other's arms. Say a firm, plain no to every other occupation.
c6c56afe-a5e8-47fe-8c21-e2c37feb732d.author: Seneca

4a05a8e4-0a34-4bc7-903f-7ae176351d29.text: But our friend Bassus stays sharp minded. Philosophy furnishes him with this: to be cheerful when death comes in view, to stay strong and happy no matter what one’s bodily condition.
4a05a8e4-0a34-4bc7-903f-7ae176351d29.author: Seneca

514b5582-8b71-46ff-8c2a-6abce738e02c.text: But the man who is not puffed up in good times does not collapse either when they change.
514b5582-8b71-46ff-8c2a-6abce738e02c.author: Seneca

271d51bf-cf74-434c-a386-f3f46e05ddda.text: But when you are looking on anyone as a friend when you do not trust him as you trust yourself, you are making a grave mistake, and have failed to grasp sufficiently the full force of true friendship.
271d51bf-cf74-434c-a386-f3f46e05ddda.author: Seneca

957b1220-5d79-4261-946a-1a7c354730c2.text: But you never deign to look at yourself or listen to yourself. So you have no reason to claim credit from anyone for those attentions, since you showed them not because you wanted someone else’s company but because you could not bearyour own.
957b1220-5d79-4261-946a-1a7c354730c2.author: Seneca

137c8ad5-e412-4d9c-a1f4-2e7ba5c9d7f4.text: By overloading the body with food you strangle the soul and render it less active.
137c8ad5-e412-4d9c-a1f4-2e7ba5c9d7f4.author: Seneca

083d0db1-3635-42a1-8dfd-c946413cbde1.text: By the toil of others we are brought into the presence of things which have been brought from darkness into light.
083d0db1-3635-42a1-8dfd-c946413cbde1.author: Seneca

ddf9165a-d805-4999-bbe2-289770dd9771.text: By the toil of others we are led into the presence of things which have been brought from darkness into light. We are excluded from no age, but we have access to them all.
ddf9165a-d805-4999-bbe2-289770dd9771.author: Seneca

3c681e07-e6aa-4770-9fa1-c82ec9af7487.text: Can you no longer see a road to freedom? It's right in front of you. You need only turn over your wrists.
3c681e07-e6aa-4770-9fa1-c82ec9af7487.author: Seneca

678e9fd5-5c38-4e07-8cdf-2004704728e4.text: Certain people have good, ordinary blood and others have an animated, lively sort of blood that comes to the face quickly.
678e9fd5-5c38-4e07-8cdf-2004704728e4.author: Seneca

f42bbd4d-b05b-4794-a834-c3ed5d984b3e.text: Consider, too, that a man lifting his head from the very funeral pyre must need some novel vocabulary not drawn from ordinary everyday condolence to comfort his own dear ones.
f42bbd4d-b05b-4794-a834-c3ed5d984b3e.author: Seneca

50f7c8dc-6055-4043-856b-17565d10daf5.text: Conversation has a kind of charm about it, an insinuating and insidious something that elicits secrets just like love or liquor.
50f7c8dc-6055-4043-856b-17565d10daf5.author: Seneca

c55fe865-e9f7-44fa-98aa-0e928be5628e.text: Conversation has a kind of charm about it, an insuating and insidious something that elicits secrets from us just like love or liquor.
c55fe865-e9f7-44fa-98aa-0e928be5628e.author: Seneca

053edf8a-f497-4f51-99c9-9f77a25a8c43.text: Could anything be more stupid than to praise a person for something that is not his? Or more crazy than admiring things which in a single moment can be transferred to another?
053edf8a-f497-4f51-99c9-9f77a25a8c43.author: Seneca

c51f258a-2997-4e31-b066-ed32347fa772.text: Count your years, and you will be ashamed to desire and pursue the same things you desired in your boyhood days. .
c51f258a-2997-4e31-b066-ed32347fa772.author: Seneca

66696368-77af-4373-876e-0d848dfd2f1d.text: Democritus says: "One man means as much to me as a multitude, and a multitude only as much as one man."
66696368-77af-4373-876e-0d848dfd2f1d.author: Seneca

c93f60d7-ef0b-4c5b-8268-4853a82a4335.text: Despise everything that useless toil creates as an ornament and an object of beauty. And reflect that nothing except the soul is worthy of wonder; for to the soul, if it be great, naught is great.
c93f60d7-ef0b-4c5b-8268-4853a82a4335.author: Seneca

baaea062-7480-4e9e-a359-260691a3961d.text: Desultory reading is delightful, but to be beneficial, our reading must be carefully directed.
baaea062-7480-4e9e-a359-260691a3961d.author: Seneca

e63c339a-decf-46c2-9230-c338e996a6d3.text: Det ille veniam facile, cui venia est opus - the one who needs pardon should readily grant it.
e63c339a-decf-46c2-9230-c338e996a6d3.author: Seneca

ea9c2c28-b669-4249-8c1d-63759db8bde0.text: Different reasons roused different peoples to leave their homes; but this at least is clear, nothing has stayed where it was born. The human race is always on the move.
ea9c2c28-b669-4249-8c1d-63759db8bde0.author: Seneca

4ff5c600-9b1e-492e-b012-4547826c0582.text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
4ff5c600-9b1e-492e-b012-4547826c0582.author: Seneca

decd54c5-ffb9-40c2-b220-3e134ba31c3a.text: Disasters, therefore, and losses, and wrongs, have only the same power over virtue that a cloud has over the sun.
decd54c5-ffb9-40c2-b220-3e134ba31c3a.author: Seneca

ea65f8b9-5aec-4165-b490-7df1be3c45da.text: Distringit librorum multitudo  (the abundance of books is distraction).
ea65f8b9-5aec-4165-b490-7df1be3c45da.author: Seneca

ab8ce346-2ea1-47b5-8575-8c573783d3c7.text: Do not run hither and thither and distract yourself by changing your abode; for such restlessness is the sign of a disordered spirit.
ab8ce346-2ea1-47b5-8575-8c573783d3c7.author: Seneca

d24111cb-2afe-4745-94a9-01ceb86b6b28.text: Do the one thing that can render you really happy: cast aside and trample under foot all the things that glitter outwardly and are held out to you a by another or as obtainable from another.
d24111cb-2afe-4745-94a9-01ceb86b6b28.author: Seneca

5e5885f9-4489-4159-8451-c4cb92420ba0.text: Do you ask me what you should regard as especially to be avoided? I say, crowds; for as yet you cannot trust yourself to them with safety.
5e5885f9-4489-4159-8451-c4cb92420ba0.author: Seneca

652665d4-c7da-46d8-8837-da748075138d.text: Do you ask what is the foundation of a sound mind? It is, not to find joy in useless things. .
652665d4-c7da-46d8-8837-da748075138d.author: Seneca

461af756-3f76-4b8b-b831-3e1ed1c816f1.text: Do you ask what is the proper limit to wealth? It is, first, to have what is necessary, and, second, to have what is enough.
461af756-3f76-4b8b-b831-3e1ed1c816f1.author: Seneca

d8d6b2b1-3a72-465b-9909-ee41255ecae6.text: Does it serve any useful purpose to know that Pompey was the first to exhibit the slaughter of eighteen elephants in the Circus, pitting criminals against them in a mimic battle?
d8d6b2b1-3a72-465b-9909-ee41255ecae6.author: Seneca

b9db64f5-80be-42bd-9fdb-0c7812149561.text: Drunkenness is nothing but voluntary madness.
b9db64f5-80be-42bd-9fdb-0c7812149561.author: Seneca

3bd05355-2721-4789-ac28-6fec8f2c5c94.text: Each day acquire something that will fortify you against poverty, against death, indeed against other misfortunes as well; and after you have run over many thoughts, select one to be thoroughly digested that day.
3bd05355-2721-4789-ac28-6fec8f2c5c94.author: Seneca

d7ac59ba-a0c7-4a28-b9b5-f6a58378509c.text: Each day... acquire something which will help you to face poverty, or death, and other ills as well. After running over a lot of different thoughts, pick out one to be digested thoroughly that day.
d7ac59ba-a0c7-4a28-b9b5-f6a58378509c.author: Seneca

e1b06f26-ffe5-4fed-aec0-9a2da2bb8d56.text: Enjoy present pleasures in such a way as not to injure future ones.
e1b06f26-ffe5-4fed-aec0-9a2da2bb8d56.author: Seneca

f9a124b0-b80f-4de9-948b-1a638a9eb14f.text: Envy of other people shows how they are unhappy. Their continual attention to others behavior shows how they are boring.
f9a124b0-b80f-4de9-948b-1a638a9eb14f.author: Seneca

0463f4e8-0a48-4119-852f-db8267570bd5.text: Errare humanum est, sed perseverare diabolicum: 'to err is human, but to persist (in the mistake) is diabolical.
0463f4e8-0a48-4119-852f-db8267570bd5.author: Seneca

fe03a0b9-1485-4a2f-b561-1e99a3131a4c.text: Everlasting misfortune does have one blessing, that it ends up by toughening those whom it constantly afflicts.
fe03a0b9-1485-4a2f-b561-1e99a3131a4c.author: Seneca

5c8ef9c3-10a9-4376-bace-1da0411bc8c6.text: Every day as it comes should be welcomed and reduced forthwith into our own possession as if it were the finest day imaginable. What flies past has to be seized at.
5c8ef9c3-10a9-4376-bace-1da0411bc8c6.author: Seneca

8b7efc7a-5790-4b13-9b77-c7344297b87f.text: Every individual can make himself happy. External goods are of trivial importance and without much influence in either direction: prosperity does not elevate the sage and adversity does not depress him.
8b7efc7a-5790-4b13-9b77-c7344297b87f.author: Seneca

1447b1ad-b968-4db5-a133-607cd128bc8d.text: Every man, when he first sees light, is commanded to be content with milk and rags. Such is our beginning, and yet kingdoms are all too small for us!
1447b1ad-b968-4db5-a133-607cd128bc8d.author: Seneca

ef94d477-4b22-45b4-8465-f134bb16ffdd.text: Every new beginning comes from other beginning’s end.
ef94d477-4b22-45b4-8465-f134bb16ffdd.author: Seneca

c4aa4911-59cc-4fc2-8d93-eeff9c3d01d7.text: Every new beginning comes from some other beginning's end.
c4aa4911-59cc-4fc2-8d93-eeff9c3d01d7.author: Seneca

c1f26209-a7a2-4131-8e3f-41bc2447e117.text: Every pleasure is most valued when it is coming to an end.
c1f26209-a7a2-4131-8e3f-41bc2447e117.author: Seneca

977568ef-bfaa-4e42-a8d0-e48129bbc1e2.text: Every pleasure is most valued when it is coming to an end?
977568ef-bfaa-4e42-a8d0-e48129bbc1e2.author: Seneca

0b1daafb-b1f1-4f9a-948e-083c7a8b6213.text: Everyone goes out of life just as if he had but lately entered.
0b1daafb-b1f1-4f9a-948e-083c7a8b6213.author: Seneca

b7cc4d6c-9862-4498-bd70-83058fe62dbe.text: Everyone hurries his life on and suffers from a yearning for the future and a weariness of the present. But he who bestows all of his time on his own needs, who plans out every day as if it were his last, neither longs for nor fears the morrow.
b7cc4d6c-9862-4498-bd70-83058fe62dbe.author: Seneca

339f1775-6d55-4912-90b0-bd5d4a4a8fd1.text: Everyone hustles his life along, and is troubled by a longing for the future and weariness of the present.
339f1775-6d55-4912-90b0-bd5d4a4a8fd1.author: Seneca

57a136d7-d97e-4873-bf24-ee81fea7ad26.text: Everyone prefers belief to the exercise of judgement.
57a136d7-d97e-4873-bf24-ee81fea7ad26.author: Seneca

f5b4cd4e-ffde-418c-8eec-3204882f25e3.text: Everywhere means nowhere. When a person spends all his time in foreign travel, he ends by having many acquaintances, but no friends.
f5b4cd4e-ffde-418c-8eec-3204882f25e3.author: Seneca

300636c9-7bf2-4868-92de-2309fd3f5ac9.text: Everywhere the people are of mixed and imported stock. One group has followed another: one longed for what another scorned; one was driven out from where he had expelled others. So fate has decreed that nothing maintains the same condition forever.
300636c9-7bf2-4868-92de-2309fd3f5ac9.author: Seneca

ced688a8-b823-43e8-991b-6588df56af48.text: Expecting is the greatest impediment to living. In anticipation of tomorrow, it loses today.
ced688a8-b823-43e8-991b-6588df56af48.author: Seneca

f1926fea-b018-415e-91cf-163e69a21246.text: Fate leads the willing and drags along the reluctant.
f1926fea-b018-415e-91cf-163e69a21246.author: Seneca

a2b8ab23-481c-4c72-9f9f-7e45272fb2ef.text: Fidelity purchased with money, money can destroy.
a2b8ab23-481c-4c72-9f9f-7e45272fb2ef.author: Seneca

c00a0c32-5aa3-4434-b72b-05ece9d78bef.text: Finally, it is generally agreed that no activity can be successfully pursued by an individual who is preoccupied.
c00a0c32-5aa3-4434-b72b-05ece9d78bef.author: Seneca

4302bcdf-2ab3-4734-9042-36543e5eb201.text: Fire is the test of gold; adversity, of strong men.
4302bcdf-2ab3-4734-9042-36543e5eb201.author: Seneca

b14d4531-63ef-4eb6-8b34-01c0298be4a8.text: Fire tests gold and adversity tests the brave.
b14d4531-63ef-4eb6-8b34-01c0298be4a8.author: Seneca

d3590418-2d8b-4b08-b1b1-42384a349509.text: Fire tests gold, suffering tests brave men.
d3590418-2d8b-4b08-b1b1-42384a349509.author: Seneca

5a6aca19-7aad-446c-9d16-78af58a143c7.text: For a person who is not aware that he is doing anything wrong has no desire to be put right. You have to catch yourself doing it before you can reform.
5a6aca19-7aad-446c-9d16-78af58a143c7.author: Seneca

852ceade-a52a-4b50-b6d0-ab53b616ebaa.text: For Fate/ The willing leads, the unwilling drags along.
852ceade-a52a-4b50-b6d0-ab53b616ebaa.author: Seneca

1c50f0f4-33ac-4778-86a8-0dade14941c0.text: For how little have we lost, when the two finest things of all will accompany us wherever we go, universal nature and our individual virtue.
1c50f0f4-33ac-4778-86a8-0dade14941c0.author: Seneca

cffb3ad8-259d-4510-8a96-d47e32589e2c.text: For if we could be satisfied with anything, we should have been satisfied long ago.
cffb3ad8-259d-4510-8a96-d47e32589e2c.author: Seneca

fe2d5c5e-04b3-4c8c-92c9-45681a398872.text: For it is disheartening to inspire in a man the desire, and to take away from him the hope, of emulation.
fe2d5c5e-04b3-4c8c-92c9-45681a398872.author: Seneca

92159485-3328-4d39-a146-90ebddf92fa4.text: For love of bustle is not industry, —it is only the restlessness of a hunted mind.
92159485-3328-4d39-a146-90ebddf92fa4.author: Seneca

9803a879-c58e-4afd-8acc-e9dd919a0400.text: For manliness gains much strength by being challenged.
9803a879-c58e-4afd-8acc-e9dd919a0400.author: Seneca

773516fd-51b0-4ee6-8743-d58667ddba88.text: For many men, the acquisition of wealth does not end their troubles, it only changes them.
773516fd-51b0-4ee6-8743-d58667ddba88.author: Seneca

f1cc3e8d-fe08-4897-9313-3b89903f436e.text: For men cease to possess all things the moment they desire all things for their own.
f1cc3e8d-fe08-4897-9313-3b89903f436e.author: Seneca

963d9895-dc56-4ef6-87e7-e2e7f53a9b85.text: For only philosophy or honourable occupation can divert from its anguish a heart whose grief springs from love.
963d9895-dc56-4ef6-87e7-e2e7f53a9b85.author: Seneca

eab5d927-2170-4099-8af8-5cbb69b1006b.text: For some persons the remedy should be merely prescribed; in the case of others, it should be forced down their throats. .
eab5d927-2170-4099-8af8-5cbb69b1006b.author: Seneca

861ef8b6-1380-4759-a0cb-f7897f5b9694.text: For that is the people’s verdict, but wise men on the whole reject the people’s decrees.
861ef8b6-1380-4759-a0cb-f7897f5b9694.author: Seneca

d83ae0a4-bb10-4355-a06a-42894b508b02.text: For that love is greater which wins less through equal danger.
d83ae0a4-bb10-4355-a06a-42894b508b02.author: Seneca

6a1d6d33-e784-48b3-8237-9ee7782d6a55.text: For the only safe harbour in this life's tossing, troubled sea is to refuse to be bothered about what the future will bring and to stand ready and confident, squaring the breast to take without skulking or flinching whatever fortune hurls at us.
6a1d6d33-e784-48b3-8237-9ee7782d6a55.author: Seneca

74081207-3043-40b4-b081-1568de365ba9.text: For the wise man regards wealth as a slave, the fool as a master.
74081207-3043-40b4-b081-1568de365ba9.author: Seneca

9248b6ea-7d72-4154-92cf-111075eb9520.text: For this is what makes us wicked: that no one of us looks back over his own life. Our thoughts are devoted only to what we are about to do. And yet our plans for the future always depend on the past.
9248b6ea-7d72-4154-92cf-111075eb9520.author: Seneca

a7a1d24e-718e-40ca-835a-43269a74d488.text: For to be afflicted with endless sorrow at the loss of someone very dear is foolish self-indulgence, and to feel none is inhuman callousness.
a7a1d24e-718e-40ca-835a-43269a74d488.author: Seneca

6a6747dc-3b82-4719-9164-5fd0dba48141.text: For we are mistaken when we look forward to death; the major portion of death has already passed. Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.
6a6747dc-3b82-4719-9164-5fd0dba48141.author: Seneca

ed8501ec-62ee-46af-9682-b16f4361bade.text: For we are not summoned according to the paristi register And besides there is no man so old as to make it sinful to expect another day. Now every day is another step in life.
ed8501ec-62ee-46af-9682-b16f4361bade.author: Seneca

e1ceb682-e85c-4e50-a108-536b28bcbecc.text: For we must indeed have someone according to whom we may regulate our characters; you can never straighten that which is crooked unless you use a ruler.
e1ceb682-e85c-4e50-a108-536b28bcbecc.author: Seneca

83e9a71c-6179-40a2-8ba5-9ff9087329b6.text: For what can be above the man who is above fortune?
83e9a71c-6179-40a2-8ba5-9ff9087329b6.author: Seneca

b2b3e9d9-312d-43ec-a556-e396db88656e.text: For what purpose, then, do I make a man my friend? In order to have someone for whom I may die, whom I may follow into exile, against whose death I may stake my own life, and pay the pledge, too.
b2b3e9d9-312d-43ec-a556-e396db88656e.author: Seneca

7274ca6e-97ae-48fa-b4e3-041dd30adb09.text: For you have no reason to suppose that we come to grief more through the flattery of others than through our own.
7274ca6e-97ae-48fa-b4e3-041dd30adb09.author: Seneca

347a69fd-cbcf-443d-85c3-a17ff7166854.text: Fortune attacks us as often as we attack Fortune.  It.
347a69fd-cbcf-443d-85c3-a17ff7166854.author: Seneca

dd6ce297-df4e-4117-8e47-f0afd2bd4cbe.text: Fortune recently took away her mother, but your love will mean that she will only grieve over her mother’s loss but not suffer for it.
dd6ce297-df4e-4117-8e47-f0afd2bd4cbe.author: Seneca

72361379-745e-4237-aa40-81ad41630388.text: From this state also will he flee. If I should attempt to enumerate them one by one, I should not find a single one which could tolerate the wise man or which the wise man could tolerate.
72361379-745e-4237-aa40-81ad41630388.author: Seneca

9e130489-ba80-4fb6-b0c8-0a889e7f7d78.text: Furthermore, if you will pay close heed to the problem, you will find that the largest portion of our life passes while we are doing ill, a goodly share while we are doing nothing, and the whole while we are doing that which is not to the purpose.
9e130489-ba80-4fb6-b0c8-0a889e7f7d78.author: Seneca

ea0246a4-e0e3-4076-b6d6-9b4e72b0549b.text: Gold tests with fire, woman with gold, man with woman.
ea0246a4-e0e3-4076-b6d6-9b4e72b0549b.author: Seneca

eeb01037-471c-4dc5-b8e2-56df8c976754.text: Greed is satisfied by nothing, but nature finds satisfaction even in scant measure.
eeb01037-471c-4dc5-b8e2-56df8c976754.author: Seneca

ae5fef22-5f4c-4194-889b-066a70ba8298.text: Hang on to your youthful enthusiasms -- you’ll be able to use them better when you’re older.
ae5fef22-5f4c-4194-889b-066a70ba8298.author: Seneca

386ced59-8479-4926-b927-fff34d4c071e.text: Happy is the man who can make others better, not merely when he is in their company, but even when he is in their thoughts!
386ced59-8479-4926-b927-fff34d4c071e.author: Seneca

f8dc5c19-badc-4f8c-8321-c2f82b0e87dd.text: Harmony makes small things grow; lack of harmony makes great things decay.
f8dc5c19-badc-4f8c-8321-c2f82b0e87dd.author: Seneca

f60576b1-4083-43a7-a2b4-060177d04f7e.text: He is ungrateful who denies that he has received a kindness which has been bestowed upon him; he is ungrateful who conceals it; he is ungrateful who makes no return for it; most ungrateful of all is he who forgets it.
f60576b1-4083-43a7-a2b4-060177d04f7e.author: Seneca

3fc42424-8842-4f4e-8862-eecf083a6d74.text: He praised his own achievements, not without cause but without end.
3fc42424-8842-4f4e-8862-eecf083a6d74.author: Seneca

e8dfbd3b-ea84-4428-abb5-a73d36d36b63.text: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.
e8dfbd3b-ea84-4428-abb5-a73d36d36b63.author: Seneca

5a76d72a-71ea-42da-a732-939fce41f9b1.text: He who boasts of his descent, praises the deeds of another.
5a76d72a-71ea-42da-a732-939fce41f9b1.author: Seneca

25d818f0-64af-4d24-954d-af2106011099.text: He who has injured thee was either stronger or weaker than thee. If weaker, spare him; if stronger, spare thyself.
25d818f0-64af-4d24-954d-af2106011099.author: Seneca

e938202f-4a95-42bd-9eb6-07e9cadc5339.text: He who has made a fair compact with poverty is rich.
e938202f-4a95-42bd-9eb6-07e9cadc5339.author: Seneca

48681873-7ef2-46e1-88c2-18b7b6189092.text: He who is brave is free.
48681873-7ef2-46e1-88c2-18b7b6189092.author: Seneca

e71ec473-ba1f-452e-bd98-7a4f1161b30c.text: He who needs riches least, enjoys riches most.
e71ec473-ba1f-452e-bd98-7a4f1161b30c.author: Seneca

28cfd20d-14c0-4945-b7a7-973361570c16.text: He who restrains himself within the limits prescribed by nature, will not feel poverty; he who exceeds them will always be poor, however great his wealth may be.
28cfd20d-14c0-4945-b7a7-973361570c16.author: Seneca

f1031bc8-a601-403f-b81c-4a85ed4ef088.text: He who saw that everything depended on himself alone, who decided the fortune of individuals and nations, was happiest when thinking of that day on which he would lay aside his own greatness.
f1031bc8-a601-403f-b81c-4a85ed4ef088.author: Seneca

2414a7c6-562d-4b62-931a-4219b65e279e.text: He who spares the wicked injures the good.
2414a7c6-562d-4b62-931a-4219b65e279e.author: Seneca

d37b973d-0389-4e3e-b425-4223c90bb7f4.text: He will live ill who does not know how to die well.
d37b973d-0389-4e3e-b425-4223c90bb7f4.author: Seneca

7b1fc6e3-6379-4977-852e-7e3183ba8cde.text: Hence the dictum of the greatest of doctors:† ‘Life is short, art is long.
7b1fc6e3-6379-4977-852e-7e3183ba8cde.author: Seneca

b75138f2-7d23-472e-87bb-228416c36eec.text: Here is your great soul—the man who has given himself over to Fate; on the other hand, that man is a weakling and a degenerate who struggles and maligns the order of the universe and would rather reform the gods than reform himself.
b75138f2-7d23-472e-87bb-228416c36eec.author: Seneca

f8b0bbb2-c60e-4ce9-a721-55e6c4da8c2f.text: His last words heard on earth came after he'd let off a louder noise from his easiest channel of communication: 'Oh my! I think I've shit myself.' For all I know, he did. He certainly shat on everything else.
f8b0bbb2-c60e-4ce9-a721-55e6c4da8c2f.author: Seneca

923166f4-309d-4db6-a556-dc79808fa2ca.text: Hold fast, then, to this sound and wholesome rule of life - that you indulge the body only so far as is needful for good health. The body should be treated more rigorously, that it may not be disobedient to the mind.
923166f4-309d-4db6-a556-dc79808fa2ca.author: Seneca

7c352fce-616c-4b6a-8ed9-8391991d3a6a.text: Honours, monuments, whatever the ambitious have ordered by decrees or raised in public buildings are soon destroyed: there is nothing that the passage of time does not demolish and remove.
7c352fce-616c-4b6a-8ed9-8391991d3a6a.author: Seneca

161f9609-0e8f-490e-931e-90c85860f405.text: How can you wonder your travels do you no good, when you carry yourself around with you? You are saddled with the very thing that drove you away.
161f9609-0e8f-490e-931e-90c85860f405.author: Seneca

720d3705-eadd-48b4-a522-b8cd8ddac626.text: How closely flattery resembles friendship! It not only apes friendship, but outdoes it, passing it in the race; with wide-open and indulgent ears it is welcomed and sinks to the depths of the heart, and it is pleasing precisely wherein it does harm.
720d3705-eadd-48b4-a522-b8cd8ddac626.author: Seneca

4690ae13-6eb2-4094-8ac8-e015cdeb3a73.text: How late it is to begin living only when one must stop!
4690ae13-6eb2-4094-8ac8-e015cdeb3a73.author: Seneca

39773439-698c-41a3-89d3-c85476ea8412.text: How late it is to begin really to live just when life must end! How stupid to forget our mortality, and put off sensible plans to our fiftieth and sixtieth years, aiming to begin life from a point at which few have arrived!
39773439-698c-41a3-89d3-c85476ea8412.author: Seneca

6d2e6fcc-413e-43d1-aaa5-05fdd174f6ca.text: How long will this last?’ This feeling has caused kings to bewail their power, and they were not so much delighted by the greatness of their fortune as terrified by the thought of its inevitable end.
6d2e6fcc-413e-43d1-aaa5-05fdd174f6ca.author: Seneca

9f7d1f5d-6f63-4dad-9c41-031839e3b1af.text: How much better it is that you defeat anger than that it defeats itself!
9f7d1f5d-6f63-4dad-9c41-031839e3b1af.author: Seneca

4b78c5cf-0e55-4383-a19c-003b5c09fc96.text: How much better to follow a straight course and attain a goal where the words "pleasant" and "honourable" have the same meaning!
4b78c5cf-0e55-4383-a19c-003b5c09fc96.author: Seneca

0393f742-f856-449d-a46c-6737bf7f4273.text: How much happier is the man who owes nothing to anybody except the one he can most easily refuse, himself!
0393f742-f856-449d-a46c-6737bf7f4273.author: Seneca

e5add5d4-328f-43ea-9448-93a6a300f225.text: How silly then to imagine that the human mind, which is formed of the same elements as divine beings, objects to movement and change of abode, while the divine nature finds delight and even self-preservation in continual and very rapid change.
e5add5d4-328f-43ea-9448-93a6a300f225.author: Seneca

037ac8df-d8fb-4ed6-90ab-d021ec18da03.text: However much you possess there's someone else who has more, and you'll be fancying yourself to be short of things you need to exact extent to which you lag behind him.
037ac8df-d8fb-4ed6-90ab-d021ec18da03.author: Seneca

da82da3d-8efb-40da-99c7-0a98efc29b3d.text: Humanity is the quality which stops one being arrogant towards one's fellows, or being acrimonious.
da82da3d-8efb-40da-99c7-0a98efc29b3d.author: Seneca

004c4c69-526c-43ee-bc29-a9c7825db8c3.text: I am loath to call clemency what was, rather, the exhaustion of cruelty.
004c4c69-526c-43ee-bc29-a9c7825db8c3.author: Seneca

2692f978-5f69-4db1-8545-107cba99c4cf.text: I am not a ‘wise man,’ nor . . . shall I ever be. And so require not from me that I should be equal to the best, but that I should be better than the wicked. It is enough for me if every day I reduce the number of my vices, and blame my mistakes.
2692f978-5f69-4db1-8545-107cba99c4cf.author: Seneca

15b10ad6-3204-4125-aef1-f68fe498a2ef.text: I am, however, discussing with you troubles which concern us both, and sharing the remedy with you, just as if we were lying ill in the same hospital. Listen to me, therefore, as you would if I were talking to myself. .
15b10ad6-3204-4125-aef1-f68fe498a2ef.author: Seneca

bbe269a0-494d-42bb-884e-fc3000f6f60c.text: I can show you a philtre, compounded without drugs, herbs, or any witch's incantation: 'If you want to be loved, love.
bbe269a0-494d-42bb-884e-fc3000f6f60c.author: Seneca

cc469824-f220-480d-a3d4-0d1f75c85178.text: I do not regard a man as poor, if the little which remains is enough for him.
cc469824-f220-480d-a3d4-0d1f75c85178.author: Seneca

6f48b6a9-bbbd-454c-b0aa-d56bb1ae07fa.text: I have learned to be a friend to myself Great improvement this indeed Such a one can never be said to be alone for know that he who is a friend to himself is a friend to all mankind.
6f48b6a9-bbbd-454c-b0aa-d56bb1ae07fa.author: Seneca

e8bb9003-8a67-487d-a72d-6b2d3c73f619.text: I have never wished to cater to the crowd; for what I know, they do not approve, and what they approve, I do not know.
e8bb9003-8a67-487d-a72d-6b2d3c73f619.author: Seneca

f72a7733-5f4f-42a3-887c-f6d51dd37b97.text: I imagine many people could have achieved wisdom if they had not imagined they had already achieved it, if they had not dissembled about some of their own characteristics and turned a blind eye to others.
f72a7733-5f4f-42a3-887c-f6d51dd37b97.author: Seneca

dd09e0f7-ba52-4d4c-859c-bf908c46237f.text: I know that these mental disturbances of mine are not dangerous and give no promise of a storm; to express what I complain of in apt metaphor, I am distressed, not by a tempest, but by sea-sickness.
dd09e0f7-ba52-4d4c-859c-bf908c46237f.author: Seneca

c9b39acd-355e-421b-8c2a-5179cdb288c4.text: I never spend a day in idleness; I appropriate even a part of the night for study. I do not allow time for sleep but yield to it when I must, and when my eyes are wearied with waking and ready to fall shut, I keep them at their task.
c9b39acd-355e-421b-8c2a-5179cdb288c4.author: Seneca

20eb21f9-f44d-4a91-85aa-122f1f671668.text: I realize that these mental agitations of mine are not dangerous and won’t produce a storm. To express my complaint for you in a realistic metaphor, I am harried not by a tempest but by sea-sickness.
20eb21f9-f44d-4a91-85aa-122f1f671668.author: Seneca

521ce36c-1963-4e7e-a217-c2daa1a61d67.text: I shall expose and reopen all the wounds which have already healed.
521ce36c-1963-4e7e-a217-c2daa1a61d67.author: Seneca

05049bc3-4781-49c7-aef9-81e365ec8f78.text: I shall never be ashamed of citing a bad author if the line is good.
05049bc3-4781-49c7-aef9-81e365ec8f78.author: Seneca

88295248-9055-418e-8ca3-422957b05661.text: I shall never be ashamed to go to a bad author for a good quotation.
88295248-9055-418e-8ca3-422957b05661.author: Seneca

e327d913-413a-47cc-990d-af94fe3a9b5d.text: I think the pinnacle of misfortune is to be forced by chance to want things one should loathe.
e327d913-413a-47cc-990d-af94fe3a9b5d.author: Seneca

65c84d36-45c9-4a61-a37c-51389e17f3b8.text: I will storm the gods, and shake the universe.
65c84d36-45c9-4a61-a37c-51389e17f3b8.author: Seneca

673a1aa7-ec79-4c78-9cba-29a48942f389.text: I wish Lucilius you had been so happy as to have taken this resolution long ago I wish we had not deferred to think of an happy life till now we are come within light of death But let us delay no longer.
673a1aa7-ec79-4c78-9cba-29a48942f389.author: Seneca

c3f036ac-77a4-4e44-9a31-0e388254a949.text: If a great man falls and remains great as he lies, people no more despise him than they stamp on a fallen temple, which the devout still worship as much as when it was standing.
c3f036ac-77a4-4e44-9a31-0e388254a949.author: Seneca

6afa94ca-218e-4e82-aa57-1e4bf99bb43d.text: If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable.
6afa94ca-218e-4e82-aa57-1e4bf99bb43d.author: Seneca

01b635d6-aa2f-4a56-9ce2-c70e8676790f.text: If an evil has been pondered beforehand, the blow is gentle when it comes.
01b635d6-aa2f-4a56-9ce2-c70e8676790f.author: Seneca

49266208-ac5c-4dd7-8b7a-f900ff139066.text: If i had not been admitted to these studies it would not have been worth while to have been born.
49266208-ac5c-4dd7-8b7a-f900ff139066.author: Seneca

f50fefaa-4dfa-483c-baa3-61799b8d929d.text: If we could be satisfied with anything, we should have been satisfied long ago.
f50fefaa-4dfa-483c-baa3-61799b8d929d.author: Seneca

dd20fec3-c2a8-4b32-a4a6-2b3d4f42391c.text: If we do not want to be overwhelmed and struck numb by rare events as if they were unprecedented ones; fortune needs envisaging in a thoroughly comprehensive way.
dd20fec3-c2a8-4b32-a4a6-2b3d4f42391c.author: Seneca

2978ec5b-a58e-445f-ba36-70fa696da950.text: If what you have seems insufficient to you, then though you possess the world, you will yet be miserable.
2978ec5b-a58e-445f-ba36-70fa696da950.author: Seneca

948d2a37-0311-4439-844c-714322a773a7.text: If wisdom were offered me on the one condition that I should keep it shut away and not divulge it to anyone, I should reject it. There is no enjoying the possession of anything valuable unless one has someone to share it with.
948d2a37-0311-4439-844c-714322a773a7.author: Seneca

5b5c091a-9203-4d0e-ac77-db769eba0f30.text: If you gain from a crime, you did it.
5b5c091a-9203-4d0e-ac77-db769eba0f30.author: Seneca

5bfe5c33-0714-4219-acd8-5de64e3fb5a9.text: If you have nothing to stir you up and rouse you to action, nothing which will test your resolution by its threats and hostilities; if you recline in unshaken comfort, it is not tranquillity; it is merely a flat calm.
5bfe5c33-0714-4219-acd8-5de64e3fb5a9.author: Seneca

a9ed968e-8864-4483-9082-806093ffab80.text: If you live according to nature, you will never be poor; if you live according to opinion, you will never be rich.
a9ed968e-8864-4483-9082-806093ffab80.author: Seneca

cb6d9867-2715-40e4-b596-8f020abb5151.text: If you live in harmony with nature you will never be poor; if you live according what others think, you will never be rich.
cb6d9867-2715-40e4-b596-8f020abb5151.author: Seneca

27e0bb26-df6a-45f4-a7fc-b7d05ab18194.text: If you look on wealth as a thing to be valued your imaginary poverty will cause you torment.
27e0bb26-df6a-45f4-a7fc-b7d05ab18194.author: Seneca

2b298718-4c54-48a1-aa5d-fb60ae15a60e.text: If you look on wealth as a thing to be valued you’ll always fancy yourself to be short of the things you need to the extent to which you lag behind what others have.
2b298718-4c54-48a1-aa5d-fb60ae15a60e.author: Seneca

fc192aa9-4505-4c7f-80fe-3ca4c8036cdd.text: If you really want to escape the things that harass you, what you’re needing is not to be in a different place but to be a different person.
fc192aa9-4505-4c7f-80fe-3ca4c8036cdd.author: Seneca

e5ff63ec-7c65-4008-a378-4b6f22cec612.text: If you regard your last day not as a punishment but as a law of nature, the breast from which you have banished the dread of death no fear will dare to enter.
e5ff63ec-7c65-4008-a378-4b6f22cec612.author: Seneca

717008eb-eec5-46ac-9d28-fe05a8a99970.text: If you want to keep a secret, never share it.
717008eb-eec5-46ac-9d28-fe05a8a99970.author: Seneca

ec7eeffb-8f5b-4f5e-91a4-c17368928b8a.text: If you wish Pythocles to have pleasure for ever, do not add to his pleasures, but subtract from his desires.
ec7eeffb-8f5b-4f5e-91a4-c17368928b8a.author: Seneca

7b56b779-6b06-4574-9282-965122dbdcc6.text: If you wish to be loved, love.
7b56b779-6b06-4574-9282-965122dbdcc6.author: Seneca

e8493fc7-42ee-4483-a9b1-7d633d0efe14.text: If you wish to fear nothing, consider that all things are to be feared.
e8493fc7-42ee-4483-a9b1-7d633d0efe14.author: Seneca

de31879b-5e5c-495c-958a-bc16c16c2c25.text: If you wish to have leisure for your mind, either be a poor man, or resemble a poor man.
de31879b-5e5c-495c-958a-bc16c16c2c25.author: Seneca

dfb7cf1e-027c-4b58-b250-1ca16212ee6c.text: If you wish to make Pythocles an old man, filling his life to the full, do not add to his years, but subtract from his desires.
dfb7cf1e-027c-4b58-b250-1ca16212ee6c.author: Seneca

e0f46d62-3035-4b94-be98-31d424dbcb26.text: If you wish to put off all worry, assume that what you fear may happen is certainly going to happen.
e0f46d62-3035-4b94-be98-31d424dbcb26.author: Seneca

189bcde1-c33f-4724-a005-8d2c3d48c46c.text: If you would escape your troubles, you need not another place but another personality.
189bcde1-c33f-4724-a005-8d2c3d48c46c.author: Seneca

b7633a63-51ea-4374-a65d-f573f042c4b8.text: If you would not have a man flinch when the crisis comes, train him before it comes.
b7633a63-51ea-4374-a65d-f573f042c4b8.author: Seneca

7a2c16c0-814c-4ce5-9021-eb8752ee59b4.text: Ignis aurum probat, miseria fortes viros. Fire is the test of gold; adversity, of strong men.
7a2c16c0-814c-4ce5-9021-eb8752ee59b4.author: Seneca

2d6f8dcb-7141-46a2-a425-c0e1b34d1664.text: Ignorance is no cure for suffering.
2d6f8dcb-7141-46a2-a425-c0e1b34d1664.author: Seneca

3e2439ae-7cc6-433e-81ff-7036f111fece.text: Ignorance is the cause of fear.
3e2439ae-7cc6-433e-81ff-7036f111fece.author: Seneca

8bb9696d-a260-4241-98d0-c863db64b0a9.text: In every good person, there lives a god. Which god? We cannot be sure - but it is a god.
8bb9696d-a260-4241-98d0-c863db64b0a9.author: Seneca

ed2b7371-0f1c-4aa8-9afe-51cd8bd8948f.text: In guarding their fortune men are often closefisted, yet, when it comes to the matter of wasting time, in the case of the one thing in which it is right to be miserly, they show themselves most prodigal.
ed2b7371-0f1c-4aa8-9afe-51cd8bd8948f.author: Seneca

b63bc16d-a4ae-47b3-a057-75a555f825ac.text: In protecting their wealth men are tight-fisted, but when it comes to the matter of time, in the case of the one thing in which it is wise to be parsimonious, they are actually generous to a fault.
b63bc16d-a4ae-47b3-a057-75a555f825ac.author: Seneca

5bf5ce95-f344-4959-9f4d-7c9039d2ceb3.text: In the ashes all men are levelled. We're born unequal, we die equal.
5bf5ce95-f344-4959-9f4d-7c9039d2ceb3.author: Seneca

d94e00b7-6945-4127-bee7-92852b0d27f8.text: In the meantime, cling tooth and nail to the following rule: not to give in to adversity, not to trust prosperity, and always take full note of fortune’s habit of behaving just as she pleases.
d94e00b7-6945-4127-bee7-92852b0d27f8.author: Seneca

56a939d8-be77-4be0-b842-524ccbe2c8f0.text: In times of happiness, no point in shaking things up. But in a time of crisis, the safest thing is change.
56a939d8-be77-4be0-b842-524ccbe2c8f0.author: Seneca

10904040-f82b-4aac-af0d-086c2b151498.text: Inwardly, we ought to be different in all respects, but our exterior should conform to society.
10904040-f82b-4aac-af0d-086c2b151498.author: Seneca

91313342-6123-49d3-a781-d1bf1a85cad2.text: Inwardly, we ought to be different in every respect, but our outward dress should blend in with the crowd.
91313342-6123-49d3-a781-d1bf1a85cad2.author: Seneca

aa2fae46-97ed-4ced-a26b-8595a0d752f4.text: Is natural to touch more often the part that hurts.
aa2fae46-97ed-4ced-a26b-8595a0d752f4.author: Seneca

b0ade723-54ee-4ab2-adc6-3fab5eff97c2.text: Istam terra de fossam premat, gravisque terrus impio capiti incubet! (As for her, let her be buried deep in earth, and heavy may the soil lie on her unholy head.).
b0ade723-54ee-4ab2-adc6-3fab5eff97c2.author: Seneca

fa1c4e45-9d64-4ea3-baf5-83de444137e4.text: It does not make any difference what a man say; what matters is how he feels, and not how he feels on one particular day but how he feels at all times.
fa1c4e45-9d64-4ea3-baf5-83de444137e4.author: Seneca

a7e5a1dd-ef0e-4802-a096-e66256178438.text: It does not matter how many books you have, but how good the books are which you have.
a7e5a1dd-ef0e-4802-a096-e66256178438.author: Seneca

75217938-7ff6-4ff9-b588-921dca6df558.text: It is a denial of justice not to stretch out a helping hand to the fallen; that is the common right of humanity.
75217938-7ff6-4ff9-b588-921dca6df558.author: Seneca

74879e46-02fd-4f16-b426-6f4b5906752c.text: It is a great man that can treat his earthenware as if it was silver, and a man who treats his silver as if it was earthenware is no less great.
74879e46-02fd-4f16-b426-6f4b5906752c.author: Seneca

524725ea-d4e9-43c3-a017-9d033263d09e.text: It is a great thing to know the season for speech and the season for silence.
524725ea-d4e9-43c3-a017-9d033263d09e.author: Seneca

1040a453-0a6a-4a58-98fe-2dc10c2ab887.text: It is a question whether he died by his own hand; for he fell from a sudden wound received in his groin, some doubting whether his death was voluntary, no one, whether it was timely.
1040a453-0a6a-4a58-98fe-2dc10c2ab887.author: Seneca

3fd77583-053d-404d-a96c-35829cb33145.text: It is a rough road that leads to the heights of greatness.
3fd77583-053d-404d-a96c-35829cb33145.author: Seneca

ff9c4662-78ca-48b7-aa04-8e1b84cb7f8d.text: It is a small part of life we really live.’ Indeed, all the rest is not life but merely time.
ff9c4662-78ca-48b7-aa04-8e1b84cb7f8d.author: Seneca

b0028b5b-91e9-4610-b02b-cdefd0af5f08.text: It is better to conquer our grief than to deceive it.
b0028b5b-91e9-4610-b02b-cdefd0af5f08.author: Seneca

74e26ada-0e2d-426d-8f9c-a55d21505f09.text: It is better to understand the balance-sheet of one’s own life than of the corn trade.
74e26ada-0e2d-426d-8f9c-a55d21505f09.author: Seneca

b455b401-6432-4d66-919f-58c95b647ea4.text: It is in no man's power to have whatever he wants, but he has it in his power not to wish for what he hasn't got, and cheerfully make the most of the things that do come his way.
b455b401-6432-4d66-919f-58c95b647ea4.author: Seneca

aee74265-290f-4ef7-aa1d-792b4af1566d.text: It is in times of security that the spirit should be preparing itself for difficult times; while fortune is bestowing favors on it is then is the time for it to be strengthened against her rebuffs.
aee74265-290f-4ef7-aa1d-792b4af1566d.author: Seneca

42077b5e-80d4-4366-9f3c-eb22c7b8231b.text: It is more civilized to make fun of life than to bewail it.
42077b5e-80d4-4366-9f3c-eb22c7b8231b.author: Seneca

9c2bb73d-4511-4233-9f76-9d47d2f0758d.text: It is not because things are difficult that we do not dare, it is because we do not dare that they are difficult.
9c2bb73d-4511-4233-9f76-9d47d2f0758d.author: Seneca

95f534d4-1731-4897-8f52-d31d49410d4f.text: It is not because things are difficult, that we do not dare, it is because we do not dare that Things are difficult.
95f534d4-1731-4897-8f52-d31d49410d4f.author: Seneca

dbc0e178-04e0-442f-8215-038ecc63a270.text: It is not that we have a short time to live but that we waste a lot of it.
dbc0e178-04e0-442f-8215-038ecc63a270.author: Seneca

f1851f14-3c36-4692-811e-ec30ed0a63ad.text: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it. Life is long enough, and a sufficiently generous amount has been given to us for the highest achievements if it were all well invested.
f1851f14-3c36-4692-811e-ec30ed0a63ad.author: Seneca

211c35ad-da7c-4196-8706-dee877ec8bd6.text: It is not that we have so little time but that we lose so much. The life we receive is not short but we make it so; we are not ill provided but use what we have wastefully.
211c35ad-da7c-4196-8706-dee877ec8bd6.author: Seneca

c36a976c-f24f-4239-adab-fa70647acc85.text: It is not the man who has too little that is poor, but the one who hankers after more.
c36a976c-f24f-4239-adab-fa70647acc85.author: Seneca

2dda2c11-9b44-48a9-8bbe-fe0f40269eba.text: It is not the man who has too little who is poor, but the one who hankers after more.
2dda2c11-9b44-48a9-8bbe-fe0f40269eba.author: Seneca

158faf8f-af3c-47f1-84dd-bfec15850bb5.text: It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.
158faf8f-af3c-47f1-84dd-bfec15850bb5.author: Seneca

3ca03013-bce7-47cd-8500-615d84fb3ea4.text: It is not what you endure that matters, but how you endure it.
3ca03013-bce7-47cd-8500-615d84fb3ea4.author: Seneca

e803ca47-472f-4302-8854-7478e638e064.text: It is of course better to know useless things than to know nothing.
e803ca47-472f-4302-8854-7478e638e064.author: Seneca

c94c5c41-ef66-4f09-8003-c2010875097c.text: It is only in the ideal or perfect state that the virtues of the good citizen and the good man are identical.
c94c5c41-ef66-4f09-8003-c2010875097c.author: Seneca

5ae4d001-f60c-42ea-9be1-b76053800735.text: It is our conscience, not our pride, that has put doorkeepers at our doors.
5ae4d001-f60c-42ea-9be1-b76053800735.author: Seneca

4b3133ff-1f7a-4fa2-9c7b-c010a18a6bdc.text: It is precisely in times of immunity from care that the soul should toughen itself beforehand for occasions of greater stress, and it is while Fortune is kind that it should fortify itself against her violence.
4b3133ff-1f7a-4fa2-9c7b-c010a18a6bdc.author: Seneca

c12b1345-ad62-42ca-a5a8-dda9add8ca23.text: It is quality rather than quantity that matters.
c12b1345-ad62-42ca-a5a8-dda9add8ca23.author: Seneca

208cbed2-2770-4f77-903b-0900624fd186.text: It is shameful to hate a person who deserves your praises; but how much more shameful it is to hate someone for the very cause that makes him deserve your pity.
208cbed2-2770-4f77-903b-0900624fd186.author: Seneca

3264634d-f6fd-42bc-b721-a322c57c868f.text: It is so, my dear Lucilius; there are a few men whom slavery holds fast, but there are many more who hold fast to slavery.
3264634d-f6fd-42bc-b721-a322c57c868f.author: Seneca

c8ab5b54-f8af-4e37-b3d2-b429bfbe0d7b.text: It is sweet to draw the world down with you when you are perishing.
c8ab5b54-f8af-4e37-b3d2-b429bfbe0d7b.author: Seneca

e5ad2b24-8def-4a86-84dc-41e8a13db941.text: It is the evil mind that gets first hold on all of us.  Learning virtue means unlearning vice.  We.
e5ad2b24-8def-4a86-84dc-41e8a13db941.author: Seneca

5f961e2e-e0eb-4033-a179-6c08ef010130.text: It is the mind that creates our wealth, and this goes with us into exile, and in the harshest desert places it finds sufficient to nourish the body and revels in the enjoyment of its own goods.
5f961e2e-e0eb-4033-a179-6c08ef010130.author: Seneca

af60ca49-7cb9-4477-a285-3f88ff007311.text: It is the power of the mind to be unconquerable.
af60ca49-7cb9-4477-a285-3f88ff007311.author: Seneca

de5e1753-bb5b-4299-a099-759dbdef04f5.text: It is the quality of a great soul to scorn great things and to prefer that which is ordinary rather than that which is too great.
de5e1753-bb5b-4299-a099-759dbdef04f5.author: Seneca

c7324cb0-15cc-4a14-a64f-46fe34f4c828.text: It is the sign of a weak mind to be unable to bear wealth.
c7324cb0-15cc-4a14-a64f-46fe34f4c828.author: Seneca

3f9f3eca-a0d8-40bf-9687-dc1975660af2.text: It is the superfluous things for which men sweat, – the superfluous things that wear our togas threadbare, that force us to grow old in camp, that dash us upon foreign shores. That which is enough is ready to our hands.
3f9f3eca-a0d8-40bf-9687-dc1975660af2.author: Seneca

a7e7a737-9aae-465d-8249-ff2da6669330.text: It is uncertain where Death will await you; there expect it everywhere.
a7e7a737-9aae-465d-8249-ff2da6669330.author: Seneca

328e802a-c54a-4a0f-921f-9afaebf23ef3.text: It is while Fortune is kind that it should fortify itself against her violence.
328e802a-c54a-4a0f-921f-9afaebf23ef3.author: Seneca

123038b8-3f95-406f-843a-732ac1edeecb.text: It is wrong not to stretch out your hand to the fallen: that is a common law of the human race.
123038b8-3f95-406f-843a-732ac1edeecb.author: Seneca

3c50ccec-1770-4c5d-9e1c-4b63241e4972.text: It is wrong to live under constraint; but no man is constrained to live under constraint.
3c50ccec-1770-4c5d-9e1c-4b63241e4972.author: Seneca

d0c10e65-3dd6-4617-a58e-4087937cbe37.text: It makes no difference how important the provocation may be, but into what kind of soul it penetrates. Similarly with fire; it does not matter how great is the flame, but what it falls upon.
d0c10e65-3dd6-4617-a58e-4087937cbe37.author: Seneca

46dd8a66-f538-4fd0-8d1d-b39de5a20d35.text: It should be our care not so much to live a long life as a satisfactory one.
46dd8a66-f538-4fd0-8d1d-b39de5a20d35.author: Seneca

2ad5e93e-5b12-4263-b290-bc8cd5c1ada4.text: It takes all of our life to learn how to live, and – something that may surprise you more – it takes just as long to learn how to die.
2ad5e93e-5b12-4263-b290-bc8cd5c1ada4.author: Seneca

4dbb36e0-460e-40a4-87b1-7d8e60e3bc9f.text: It takes the whole of life to learn how to live, and — what will perhaps make you wonder more — it takes the whole of life to learn how to die.
4dbb36e0-460e-40a4-87b1-7d8e60e3bc9f.author: Seneca

fa180eef-d86e-405d-bd9f-d3b49c80e486.text: It takes the whole of life to learn how to live, and--what will perhaps make you wonder more--it takes the whole of life to learn how to die.
fa180eef-d86e-405d-bd9f-d3b49c80e486.author: Seneca

66962ab3-945d-41a0-b670-9c49c546b017.text: It takes the whole of life to learn how to live, and—what will perhaps make you wonder more—it takes the whole of life to learn how to die.
66962ab3-945d-41a0-b670-9c49c546b017.author: Seneca

d4e9f836-9f7f-42f2-9964-355222bb8a47.text: It takes you more time to solve a problem than to set it.
d4e9f836-9f7f-42f2-9964-355222bb8a47.author: Seneca

f667d258-5b79-4b98-a13c-2a776273eb4d.text: It was nature’s intention that there should be no need of great equipment for a good life: every individual can make himself happy.
f667d258-5b79-4b98-a13c-2a776273eb4d.author: Seneca

22bf1bd1-3b23-49e7-8c70-0b9446aff4f9.text: It's easier to get philosophers to agree than clocks.
22bf1bd1-3b23-49e7-8c70-0b9446aff4f9.author: Seneca

e99a4236-d32f-4dd4-bd19-e7ffb2911ce7.text: It's not because things are difficult that we dare not venture. It's because we dare not venture that they are difficult.
e99a4236-d32f-4dd4-bd19-e7ffb2911ce7.author: Seneca

cf5d4abd-88d9-472f-845b-1ba0ae7c6aba.text: It's not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste much of it. Life is long enough, and it's been given to us in generous measure for accomplishing the greatest things, if the whole of it is well invested.
cf5d4abd-88d9-472f-845b-1ba0ae7c6aba.author: Seneca

2bcd7eb0-8a9d-432e-a32e-f536b4821991.text: It's not that we have little time, but more that we waste a good deal of it.
2bcd7eb0-8a9d-432e-a32e-f536b4821991.author: Seneca

521356e0-52d6-48f3-b39b-61c7d1a1845e.text: It’s not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.” -Lucius Annaeus Seneca.
521356e0-52d6-48f3-b39b-61c7d1a1845e.author: Seneca

248a3337-b4c5-494e-84cb-d4faaa6bd803.text: Just as great and princely wealth is scattered in a moment when it comes into the hands of a bad owner, while wealth however limited, if it is entrusted to a good guardian, increases by use, so our life is amply long for him who orders it properly.
248a3337-b4c5-494e-84cb-d4faaa6bd803.author: Seneca

219dfb35-409b-4055-84f2-bdd9ea602b12.text: Kingdoms which act unjustly never last.
219dfb35-409b-4055-84f2-bdd9ea602b12.author: Seneca

363869d9-ac61-4c1e-b8e7-0973352a48c9.text: Kings hate to hear the things they order spoken.
363869d9-ac61-4c1e-b8e7-0973352a48c9.author: Seneca

8a0a6c3c-ae53-46df-8f5a-31ca1c0734a0.text: Lay hold of today's task, and you will not need to depend so much upon to-morrow's.
8a0a6c3c-ae53-46df-8f5a-31ca1c0734a0.author: Seneca

6e9f1885-6c5b-4d3c-a9fe-e72a8e5ddd79.text: Lay hold of today's task, and you will not need to depend so much upon to-morrow's. While we are postponing, life speeds by.
6e9f1885-6c5b-4d3c-a9fe-e72a8e5ddd79.author: Seneca

5f37e235-752b-4f0e-a00d-1411141d2e45.text: Learning how to live takes a whole life, and, which may surprise you more, it takes a whole life to learn how to die.
5f37e235-752b-4f0e-a00d-1411141d2e45.author: Seneca

d43edde9-9371-4d32-b81b-44853e1a782e.text: Leisure without books is death, and burial of a man alive.
d43edde9-9371-4d32-b81b-44853e1a782e.author: Seneca

7ab9830e-78e4-45d7-aa7c-9bebdcff7cef.text: Leisure without study is death; it is a tomb for the living man.
7ab9830e-78e4-45d7-aa7c-9bebdcff7cef.author: Seneca

3accd3a7-1fcd-47a4-a54e-337f86d7b362.text: Let all your efforts be directed to something, let it keep that end in view. It's not activity that disturbs people, but false conceptions of things that drive them mad.
3accd3a7-1fcd-47a4-a54e-337f86d7b362.author: Seneca

34e36f89-ef3e-4903-a2d1-6f83ee9d1657.text: Let my mind be fixed on itself, cultivate itself, have no external interest – nothing that seeks the approval of another; let it cherish the tranquillity that has no part in public or private concerns.
34e36f89-ef3e-4903-a2d1-6f83ee9d1657.author: Seneca

75d76e74-d660-41f8-a4d6-462bb0327651.text: Let tears flow of their own accord: their flowing is not inconsistent with inward peace and harmony.
75d76e74-d660-41f8-a4d6-462bb0327651.author: Seneca

1cbfca8a-ed62-4e98-8c9e-01471ccea957.text: Let us be brave in the face of hazards. Let us not fear wrongs, or wounds, or bonds, or poverty. And what is death? It is either the end, or a process of change.
1cbfca8a-ed62-4e98-8c9e-01471ccea957.author: Seneca

b760fc27-5b3c-4e04-95a1-b4223ef9991d.text: Let us keep to the way which Nature has mapped out for us, and let us not swerve therefrom. If we follow Nature, all is easy and unobstructed; but if we combat Nature, our life differs not a whit from that of men who row against the current.
b760fc27-5b3c-4e04-95a1-b4223ef9991d.author: Seneca

5b47141f-f200-4fa2-8940-1fd1284f972c.text: Let us say what we feel, and feel what we say; let speech harmonize with life.
5b47141f-f200-4fa2-8940-1fd1284f972c.author: Seneca

a1a3f987-d39b-42e6-83b5-f7a6eebe4505.text: Let us take pleasure in what we have received and make no comparison; no man will ever be happy if tortured by the greater happiness of another.
a1a3f987-d39b-42e6-83b5-f7a6eebe4505.author: Seneca

06672cbd-3389-47c8-83fd-d44b02fe3161.text: Life is divided into three parts: what was, what is and what shall be. Of these three periods, the present is short, the future is doubtful and the past alone is certain.
06672cbd-3389-47c8-83fd-d44b02fe3161.author: Seneca

909c04fa-16cf-4d77-b125-7cb7357e2b86.text: Life is like a play: it's not the length, but the excellence of the acting that matters.
909c04fa-16cf-4d77-b125-7cb7357e2b86.author: Seneca

8d3322be-66d2-48f8-9c02-0c799de5d11d.text: Life is long and there is enough of it for satisfying personal accomplishments if we use our hours well.
8d3322be-66d2-48f8-9c02-0c799de5d11d.author: Seneca

ff9d9dc9-d904-45a5-8c25-bd92f3b0c500.text: Life is long enough, and it has been given in sufficiently generous measure to allow the accomplishment of the very greatest things if the whole of it is well invested.
ff9d9dc9-d904-45a5-8c25-bd92f3b0c500.author: Seneca

67d082e5-c36b-46ce-866f-ccb27d143c2e.text: Life is long if you know how to use it.
67d082e5-c36b-46ce-866f-ccb27d143c2e.author: Seneca

68d5c61e-1237-4146-8977-aedfca21cb08.text: Life is long, if only you knew how to use it.
68d5c61e-1237-4146-8977-aedfca21cb08.author: Seneca

a9e2ebc3-f0de-4e4e-b5f1-f936d539de9b.text: Life is long, if you know how to use it.
a9e2ebc3-f0de-4e4e-b5f1-f936d539de9b.author: Seneca

2ac662f1-f8d4-4426-b38f-e6e72aff98d0.text: Life is not worth living, and there is no limit to our sorrows, if we indulge our fears to the greatest possible extent.
2ac662f1-f8d4-4426-b38f-e6e72aff98d0.author: Seneca

771dad0d-3b90-4d3b-adc9-ad5845fcdb2c.text: Life is slavery if the courage to die is absent.
771dad0d-3b90-4d3b-adc9-ad5845fcdb2c.author: Seneca

3d1e9ed7-e930-4639-a29b-7453f07f59e0.text: Life, if you know how to use it, is long; but…many, following no fixed aim, shifting and… dissatisfied, are plunged by their fickleness into plans that are ever new; some have no fixed principle by which to direct their course.
3d1e9ed7-e930-4639-a29b-7453f07f59e0.author: Seneca

3d38afcc-e4e7-4a19-8a27-340950c0b936.text: Life’s finest day for wretched mortals here Is always first to flee.
3d38afcc-e4e7-4a19-8a27-340950c0b936.author: Seneca

d2b22570-800f-41c5-bfe7-0bad6a15746b.text: Life’s like a play. It’s not the length but the excellence of the acting that matters.
d2b22570-800f-41c5-bfe7-0bad6a15746b.author: Seneca

3e63b09a-a864-4963-98a4-1dd7e3f8789a.text: Light griefs are loquacious, but the great are dumb.
3e63b09a-a864-4963-98a4-1dd7e3f8789a.author: Seneca

5d24fb3a-2df7-451a-8df2-59de2e3ae305.text: Linger among a limited number of master thinkers, and digest their works.
5d24fb3a-2df7-451a-8df2-59de2e3ae305.author: Seneca

43b4227b-ad23-43d0-bc6a-a42a9f130fa9.text: Living is the least important activity of the preoccupied man.
43b4227b-ad23-43d0-bc6a-a42a9f130fa9.author: Seneca

b08243c2-b8e7-4b94-a216-f204e72c7abf.text: Long association brings love of evil as well as good.
b08243c2-b8e7-4b94-a216-f204e72c7abf.author: Seneca

d06076cd-e555-499a-bb6f-8aec2e000887.text: Longing for the future and weariness of the present.
d06076cd-e555-499a-bb6f-8aec2e000887.author: Seneca

9d63d74f-152d-4a8e-a1a1-8b1e84191496.text: Love of bustle is not industry.
9d63d74f-152d-4a8e-a1a1-8b1e84191496.author: Seneca

3263ef89-a13a-4c60-9678-ec261a294e61.text: Love sometimes injures. Friendship always benefits, After friendship is formed you must trust, but before that you must judge.
3263ef89-a13a-4c60-9678-ec261a294e61.author: Seneca

839895b4-6172-4c60-89ea-289775b4cb2e.text: Love sometimes injures. Friendship always benefits.
839895b4-6172-4c60-89ea-289775b4cb2e.author: Seneca

876de852-2ffd-4a92-b92c-f8854dfadc6c.text: Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity!
876de852-2ffd-4a92-b92c-f8854dfadc6c.author: Seneca

87872754-6e03-403b-889a-bf1f283516bc.text: Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.
87872754-6e03-403b-889a-bf1f283516bc.author: Seneca

4a3678bb-5284-4f7b-8270-d429055faaf7.text: Making noble resolutions is not as important as keeping the resolutions you have made already.
4a3678bb-5284-4f7b-8270-d429055faaf7.author: Seneca

eadf7ad8-a270-4c9b-9e3c-37b28a674813.text: Mankind is perpetually the victim of a pointless and futile martydom, fretting life away in fruitless worries though failure to realise what limit is set to acquisition and to the growth of genuine pleasure.
eadf7ad8-a270-4c9b-9e3c-37b28a674813.author: Seneca

bc1edf12-8af1-4229-b0a1-f52522a14950.text: Many pursue no fixed goal, but are tossed about in ever-changing designs by a fickleness which is shifting, inconstant and never satisfied with itself.
bc1edf12-8af1-4229-b0a1-f52522a14950.author: Seneca

0de69b2d-f96f-4b10-81e9-1ebe32758d7e.text: Meanwhile, as they rob and are robbed, as they disturb each other’s peace, as they make each other miserable, their lives pass without satisfaction, without pleasure, without mental improvement.
0de69b2d-f96f-4b10-81e9-1ebe32758d7e.author: Seneca

31fef36f-9279-4adb-adcb-2c0534dc85dd.text: Men are not made restless by activity but driven to madness by false impressions of reality.
31fef36f-9279-4adb-adcb-2c0534dc85dd.author: Seneca

4a8974ec-5a08-487b-bd89-d94fb52a11c7.text: Men are so thoughtless, nay, so mad, that some, through fear of death, force themselves to die.
4a8974ec-5a08-487b-bd89-d94fb52a11c7.author: Seneca

cbfbca9e-589a-4b87-98a9-880a9d492419.text: Men are tight-fisted in keeping control of their fortunes, but when it comes to the matter of wasting time, they are positively extravagant in the one area where there is honour in being miserly.
cbfbca9e-589a-4b87-98a9-880a9d492419.author: Seneca

e2d26577-27f4-48f9-99c2-0e28cd675589.text: Men do not care how nobly they live, but only for how long, although it is within the reach of every man to live nobly, but within no man’s power to live long.
e2d26577-27f4-48f9-99c2-0e28cd675589.author: Seneca

c3e4155c-4db7-4298-ba78-9f1c5898661e.text: Men do not care how nobly they live, but only how long, although it is within the reach of every man to live nobly, but within no man's power to live long.
c3e4155c-4db7-4298-ba78-9f1c5898661e.author: Seneca

bbb0a0d3-afc4-4fe5-a6d7-47a29e22268d.text: Men love their country, not because it is great, but because it is their own.
bbb0a0d3-afc4-4fe5-a6d7-47a29e22268d.author: Seneca

54202705-b6e3-4c35-9d19-b0241ecc80cc.text: Men whose spirit has grown arrogant from the great favor of fortune have this most serious fault—those whom they have injured they also hate.
54202705-b6e3-4c35-9d19-b0241ecc80cc.author: Seneca

8fda49b9-be6c-4393-bdf6-7232ef322f59.text: Most men ebb and flow in wretchedness between the fear of death and the hardships of life; they are unwilling to live, and yet they do not know how to die.
8fda49b9-be6c-4393-bdf6-7232ef322f59.author: Seneca

779f7025-ad7b-4a4c-b389-b1dfbb1c29ba.text: Most men ebb and flow in wretchedness between the fear of death and the hardships of life; they are unwilling to live, and yet they do not know how to die. .
779f7025-ad7b-4a4c-b389-b1dfbb1c29ba.author: Seneca

ca5e176f-a9e4-4c83-bde2-ab091a896cd8.text: Most men ebb and flow in wretchedness between the fear of death and the hardships of life; they are unwilling to live, and yet they do not know how to die. For this reason, make life as a whole agreeable to yourself by banishing all worry about it.
ca5e176f-a9e4-4c83-bde2-ab091a896cd8.author: Seneca

1726eb09-0c93-440f-bc23-0607900d3f0e.text: Most powerful is he who has himself in his own power.
1726eb09-0c93-440f-bc23-0607900d3f0e.author: Seneca

51ec7409-0c95-42c6-9192-01b1901911ce.text: Most powerful is he who has himself in his power.
51ec7409-0c95-42c6-9192-01b1901911ce.author: Seneca

0aacef77-8a8d-42ea-9a2a-1784a6fe6092.text: Natural abilities do not respond well to compulsion; when Nature is in opposition, labour is fruitless.
0aacef77-8a8d-42ea-9a2a-1784a6fe6092.author: Seneca

8d21a1e9-9d50-49b8-af02-4926d64a87e9.text: Nature does not reveal her mysteries once and for all.
8d21a1e9-9d50-49b8-af02-4926d64a87e9.author: Seneca

2f71f5c5-3c1b-4132-9b34-95e0ff45b030.text: Nero: "Am I forbidden to do what all may do?" Seneca: "From high rank high example is expected."
2f71f5c5-3c1b-4132-9b34-95e0ff45b030.author: Seneca

167c9cdf-e2ec-4a04-a1dc-df9b82fb2f6a.text: Never will there be a shortage of reasons for anxiety, whether born of happiness or misery; life will press on its way from one pursuit to another; leisure will never be enjoyed, though the prayer is constantly on our lips.
167c9cdf-e2ec-4a04-a1dc-df9b82fb2f6a.author: Seneca

86cf4a3e-9322-4fd4-8e29-b9792b3a147e.text: New preoccupations take the place of the old, hope excites more hope and ambition more ambition. They do not look for an end to their misery, but simply change the reason for it.
86cf4a3e-9322-4fd4-8e29-b9792b3a147e.author: Seneca

bb862c78-c2f7-4dac-96b4-a811507ae59c.text: Night brings our troubles to the light rather than banishes them.
bb862c78-c2f7-4dac-96b4-a811507ae59c.author: Seneca

8d7fed91-fc27-474e-8c81-fd759b67a114.text: No condition is so distressing that a balanced mind cannot find some comfort in it.
8d7fed91-fc27-474e-8c81-fd759b67a114.author: Seneca

408088fa-38b8-4fab-9fcc-5dec7c0b09be.text: No delicate breeze brings comfort with icy breath of wind to the hearts which pant on the flames.
408088fa-38b8-4fab-9fcc-5dec7c0b09be.author: Seneca

00234c1b-493b-4b3c-b8c0-faadfe2034c7.text: No genius that ever won acclaim did so without a measure of indulgence. Name me any man you like who had a celebrated reputation, and I’ll tell you what the age he lived in forgave him, what it turned a blind eye to in his work.
00234c1b-493b-4b3c-b8c0-faadfe2034c7.author: Seneca

45bc6504-adde-4444-a0d5-9e69a3e7062b.text: No good thing renders its possessor happy, unless his mind is reconciled to the possibility of loss.
45bc6504-adde-4444-a0d5-9e69a3e7062b.author: Seneca

e01f63f9-d791-4a85-9ad7-f24045f8de6d.text: No good thing renders its possessor happy, unless his mind is reconciled to the possibility of loss; nothing, however, is lost with less discomfort than that which, when lost, cannot be missed.
e01f63f9-d791-4a85-9ad7-f24045f8de6d.author: Seneca

65ac5d10-9045-4f76-9c90-3a5914597efc.text: No man can be sane who searches for what will injure him in place of what is best.
65ac5d10-9045-4f76-9c90-3a5914597efc.author: Seneca

3d73cf0d-7edb-42d0-bd0e-0f027fa7d2ea.text: No man can have a peaceful life who thinks too much about lengthening it.
3d73cf0d-7edb-42d0-bd0e-0f027fa7d2ea.author: Seneca

868bd517-d6c5-4334-9d02-adab6f89a026.text: No man can live a happy life, or even a supportable life, without the study of wisdom.
868bd517-d6c5-4334-9d02-adab6f89a026.author: Seneca

df02180c-ac3c-4dc4-8d25-e2da1909da89.text: No man finds it difficult to return to nature, except the man who has deserted nature.  We.
df02180c-ac3c-4dc4-8d25-e2da1909da89.author: Seneca

bb7ca049-0d4d-4c53-adf4-7bf09343ae51.text: No man has been shattered by the blows of Fortune unless he was first deceived by her favours.
bb7ca049-0d4d-4c53-adf4-7bf09343ae51.author: Seneca

f423e846-30b5-4466-84af-0ef3a4ec415d.text: No man has escaped paying the penalty for being born.
f423e846-30b5-4466-84af-0ef3a4ec415d.author: Seneca

c6e323e1-4dc6-4397-b050-2d793650832f.text: No man is crushed by misfortune unless he has first been deceived by prosperity.
c6e323e1-4dc6-4397-b050-2d793650832f.author: Seneca

564982fa-db55-44cb-bf22-204e80a25356.text: No man is despised by another unless he is first despised by himself.
564982fa-db55-44cb-bf22-204e80a25356.author: Seneca

a26a9154-9368-40d2-a3b0-7476ac328aad.text: No man is more unhappy than he who never faces adversity. For he is not permitted to prove himself.
a26a9154-9368-40d2-a3b0-7476ac328aad.author: Seneca

c1e7643d-1170-40e0-a4c1-46c014dadca4.text: No man is so faint-hearted that he would rather hang in suspense for ever than drop once for all.
c1e7643d-1170-40e0-a4c1-46c014dadca4.author: Seneca

ae52399d-c7f1-4071-b2ae-46fd0c47af31.text: No man was ever wise by chance
ae52399d-c7f1-4071-b2ae-46fd0c47af31.author: Seneca

82cd01bc-856f-43de-9d7d-0ab72bfed773.text: No man was ever wise by chance.
82cd01bc-856f-43de-9d7d-0ab72bfed773.author: Seneca

ccab72e3-862e-4fa5-8301-7c5a6ed4f5c5.text: No man will ever be happy if tortured by the greater happiness of another.
ccab72e3-862e-4fa5-8301-7c5a6ed4f5c5.author: Seneca

34c33bba-2886-488f-8db6-8341bf43c68c.text: No man, if he be ungrateful, will be unhappy in the future. I allow him no day of grace; he is unhappy forthwith.
34c33bba-2886-488f-8db6-8341bf43c68c.author: Seneca

a5470e45-76ad-4a28-b910-b66b0752ef79.text: No man’s good by accident. Virtue has to be learnt.
a5470e45-76ad-4a28-b910-b66b0752ef79.author: Seneca

f534d147-c0d6-4c84-b598-9224ceff539b.text: No one becomes a laughingstock who laughs at himself.
f534d147-c0d6-4c84-b598-9224ceff539b.author: Seneca

bb294658-116d-441c-a2c8-c6f826c8a8be.text: No one can live happily who has regard for himself alone and transforms everything into a question of his own utility.
bb294658-116d-441c-a2c8-c6f826c8a8be.author: Seneca

b53638d7-7422-4ca2-bbb7-adfa228438eb.text: No one can merely go wrong by himself, but he must become both the cause and adviser of another's wrong doing.
b53638d7-7422-4ca2-bbb7-adfa228438eb.author: Seneca

01f3d78c-2fae-4645-bd70-b34ebfbc8d84.text: No one dies except on his own day. You are throwing away none of your own time; for what you leave behind does not belong to you.
01f3d78c-2fae-4645-bd70-b34ebfbc8d84.author: Seneca

41f3f22f-750d-4ea8-8741-f845a8c98e82.text: No one is the object of another man's contempt, unless he is first the object of his own.
41f3f22f-750d-4ea8-8741-f845a8c98e82.author: Seneca

12905949-84b1-439f-9e1a-b9a49da97933.text: No one keeps himself waiting; and yet the greatest cure for anger is to wait, so that the initial passion it engenders may die down, and the fog that shrouds the mind may subside, or become less thick.
12905949-84b1-439f-9e1a-b9a49da97933.author: Seneca

2635f38a-e6e9-4734-95ac-991c1ed97e63.text: No one willingly reverts to the past unless all his actions have passed his own censorship, which is never deceived.
2635f38a-e6e9-4734-95ac-991c1ed97e63.author: Seneca

3187aa07-85b3-4827-a8d5-bc96bc2af26a.text: No past life has been lived to lend us glory, and that which has existed before us is not ours.
3187aa07-85b3-4827-a8d5-bc96bc2af26a.author: Seneca

6fa29bcf-7474-4d64-97b2-20cf6da3b680.text: None of these will force you to die, but all will teach you how to die. None of them will exhaust your years, but each will contribute his years to yours.
6fa29bcf-7474-4d64-97b2-20cf6da3b680.author: Seneca

e1d5ea1b-4aef-4a0e-86b9-65a11bd0e8f1.text: Not all men are wounded in the same place; and so you ought to know what part of you is weak, so you can give it the most protection.
e1d5ea1b-4aef-4a0e-86b9-65a11bd0e8f1.author: Seneca

926bf744-76be-415c-9da6-c827ba00f63a.text: Not single is the death which comes; the death Which takes us off is but the last of all.
926bf744-76be-415c-9da6-c827ba00f63a.author: Seneca

d98d0e0b-7a75-49e9-9a05-ed59d65464b5.text: Nothing happens to the wise man against his expectation.
d98d0e0b-7a75-49e9-9a05-ed59d65464b5.author: Seneca

cf0eda3c-ac18-44d9-9fca-4be930d92412.text: Nothing hinders a cure so much as frequent changes of treatment.
cf0eda3c-ac18-44d9-9fca-4be930d92412.author: Seneca

a0ee69e1-8966-496c-b415-49ff7ff892d2.text: Nothing is burdensome if taken lightly, and nothing need arouse one's irritation so long as one doesn't make it bigger than it is by getting irritated.
a0ee69e1-8966-496c-b415-49ff7ff892d2.author: Seneca

b365b0df-53a3-4f66-91c8-4909082c5922.text: Nothing is more dishonourable than an old man, heavy with years, who has no other evidence of his having lived long except his age.
b365b0df-53a3-4f66-91c8-4909082c5922.author: Seneca

65afd88b-2bf8-4c88-8471-fa5e6aef2b21.text: Nothing is more honorable than a grateful heart.
65afd88b-2bf8-4c88-8471-fa5e6aef2b21.author: Seneca

15f607a4-90f9-4c54-8285-b9fad059c33b.text: Nothing satisfies greed, but even a little satisfies nature.
15f607a4-90f9-4c54-8285-b9fad059c33b.author: Seneca

7caf787c-8bdb-4f6d-b457-8de3766473ee.text: Nothing, Lucilius, is ours, except time. We were entrusted by nature with the ownership of this single thing, so fleeting and slippery that anyone who will can oust us from possession.
7caf787c-8bdb-4f6d-b457-8de3766473ee.author: Seneca

d3bbd609-dbff-42e3-8f82-97cf118ebcb2.text: Nothing, to my way of thinking, is a better proof of a well ordered mind than a man’s ability to stop just where he is and pass some time in his own company.
d3bbd609-dbff-42e3-8f82-97cf118ebcb2.author: Seneca

2f421748-2ba9-4eaa-813b-5c36499eb143.text: Nūllum magnum ingenium sine mixtūrā dēmentiae fuit No great talent without an element of madness.
2f421748-2ba9-4eaa-813b-5c36499eb143.author: Seneca

82149bfd-59e0-4697-96dd-7343e8e60083.text: O how many noble deeds of women are lost in obscurity!
82149bfd-59e0-4697-96dd-7343e8e60083.author: Seneca

7bf37ea7-36e8-48ec-b11d-f678ac8825cf.text: Of all men, only those who find time for philosophy are at leisure; only they are truly alive; for it is not only their own lifetime they guard well: they add every age to their own.
7bf37ea7-36e8-48ec-b11d-f678ac8825cf.author: Seneca

0c2ade27-c4ba-42c4-aa65-cfa55b8c94a3.text: Of this one thing make sure against your dying day - that your faults die before you do.
0c2ade27-c4ba-42c4-aa65-cfa55b8c94a3.author: Seneca

34ceac30-935d-4610-a36c-59b085f74801.text: Offer new prayers; pray for a sound mind and for good health, first of soul and then of body.
34ceac30-935d-4610-a36c-59b085f74801.author: Seneca

90de8b11-a95d-4b40-9ecc-aae39d0ad6b8.text: Often a very old man has no other proof of his long life than his age.
90de8b11-a95d-4b40-9ecc-aae39d0ad6b8.author: Seneca

4740cbe8-ab24-401d-92f4-11d99c801767.text: Often it is better to hide an illness from the patient, because just the mere awareness of a disease can bring about death.
4740cbe8-ab24-401d-92f4-11d99c801767.author: Seneca

3bea7360-7be1-421d-9a57-05d26828955a.text: On Epicurus; He says: "Contended poverty is an honourable estate." Indeed, if it is contented, it is not poverty at all. It is not the man who has little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.
3bea7360-7be1-421d-9a57-05d26828955a.author: Seneca

1fc883e2-5ae6-44bd-8f0b-c72f16e42de0.text: Once we have driven away all that excites or affrights us, there ensues unbroken tranquility and enduring freedom.
1fc883e2-5ae6-44bd-8f0b-c72f16e42de0.author: Seneca

548187b0-bf38-465c-b920-db2b74b278a7.text: One can expect an agreement between philosophers sooner than between clocks.
548187b0-bf38-465c-b920-db2b74b278a7.author: Seneca

b25808c2-23f9-4ed2-a998-99c08fd9de87.text: One cannot sincerely weep over getting what one wanted.
b25808c2-23f9-4ed2-a998-99c08fd9de87.author: Seneca

a56ba05c-7021-4ec6-a412-a0e8c153b9b5.text: One hand washes the other. (Manus Manum Lavat).
a56ba05c-7021-4ec6-a412-a0e8c153b9b5.author: Seneca

b1715c5f-0814-45ee-bc7a-852737e67721.text: One of the causes of the troubles that beset us is the way our lives are guided by the example of others; instead of being set to rights by reason we’re seduced by convention.
b1715c5f-0814-45ee-bc7a-852737e67721.author: Seneca

55056960-72ee-497c-a668-fedc533d5022.text: Only a mind that is deeply stirred can utter something noble and beyond the power of others.
55056960-72ee-497c-a668-fedc533d5022.author: Seneca

33c1482f-b91a-49ac-8917-57cddc552a9b.text: Only an absolute fool values a man according to his clothes, or according to his social position, which after all is only something that we wear like clothing.
33c1482f-b91a-49ac-8917-57cddc552a9b.author: Seneca

ed5b6c56-a54e-4267-9c90-919d0553a0e1.text: Only the wise man is content with what is his. All foolishness suffers the burden of dissatisfaction with itself.
ed5b6c56-a54e-4267-9c90-919d0553a0e1.author: Seneca

bd3a6a6a-d18a-4237-9df0-542cb614cca8.text: Only time can heal what reason cannot.
bd3a6a6a-d18a-4237-9df0-542cb614cca8.author: Seneca

ebf3aa59-5de1-4f68-bda4-c1124f35629d.text: Our universe is a sorry little affair unless it has in it something for every age to investigate.
ebf3aa59-5de1-4f68-bda4-c1124f35629d.author: Seneca

6cbabfc9-eb90-40e0-8288-466ee083a154.text: Pain is slight if opinion has added nothing to it; ... in thinking it slight, you will make it slight. Everything depends on opinion. It is according to opinion that we suffer. A man is as wretched as he has convinced himself that he is.
6cbabfc9-eb90-40e0-8288-466ee083a154.author: Seneca

883556c4-ba42-4adf-984b-5733cc1aa0a1.text: Part of my joy in learning is that it puts me in a position to teach; nothing, however outstanding and however helpful, will ever give me any pleasure if the knowledge is for my benefit alone.
883556c4-ba42-4adf-984b-5733cc1aa0a1.author: Seneca

c0b0a0c8-f1cb-4227-b6c9-b17afdb686d5.text: Peace you can claim for yourself without being disliked by anyone, without any sense of loss, and without any pangs of spirit.
c0b0a0c8-f1cb-4227-b6c9-b17afdb686d5.author: Seneca

ae7074e5-5ad4-4dc1-bd94-2e0e4f7eb682.text: People are frugal in guarding their personal property; but as soon as it comes to squandering time they are most wasteful of the one thing in which it is right to be stingy.
ae7074e5-5ad4-4dc1-bd94-2e0e4f7eb682.author: Seneca

e1aa3f69-3778-4f9f-9e8a-a1226ccf5039.text: People who know no self-restraint lead stormy and disordered lives, passing their time in a state of fear commensurate with the injuries they do to others, never able to relax.
e1aa3f69-3778-4f9f-9e8a-a1226ccf5039.author: Seneca

211cbfe3-c96d-4e2a-855e-caf23795eb5c.text: Philosophy calls for simple living, not for doing penance, and the simple way of life need not be a crude one.
211cbfe3-c96d-4e2a-855e-caf23795eb5c.author: Seneca

b05d9402-bc89-4b79-9a0c-553632c28d2b.text: Philosophy is good advice; and no one can give advice at the top of his lungs.
b05d9402-bc89-4b79-9a0c-553632c28d2b.author: Seneca

8c7b120f-08b7-41d4-bb14-4a862e49ff6a.text: Philosophy teaches us to act, not to speak.
8c7b120f-08b7-41d4-bb14-4a862e49ff6a.author: Seneca

26d58a87-d024-4dd2-9c25-a6dbde297552.text: Plague on it! what madness this is, to punish one's self because one is unfortunate, and not to lessen, but to increase one's ills!
26d58a87-d024-4dd2-9c25-a6dbde297552.author: Seneca
