1e35df38-d96f-4d00-8254-09cff0fd0915.text: Plato says: "Every king springs from a race of slaves, and every slave has had kings among his ancestors." The flight of time, with its vicissitudes, has jumbled all such things together, and Fortune has turned them upside down.
1e35df38-d96f-4d00-8254-09cff0fd0915.author: Seneca

6c9a4a6f-624f-46ff-bd26-d00299d60b1c.text: Pleasure, unless it has been kept within bounds, tends to rush headlong into the abyss of sorrow.
6c9a4a6f-624f-46ff-bd26-d00299d60b1c.author: Seneca

24c71404-c12a-4389-b7e0-5955b922b4c5.text: Poor woman, do you want to know where hatred ends? Look to love.
24c71404-c12a-4389-b7e0-5955b922b4c5.author: Seneca

e22124a8-f05a-40a0-b2aa-2758e3a37d74.text: Possession of a friend should be with the spirit: the spirit's never absent: it sees daily whoever it likes.
e22124a8-f05a-40a0-b2aa-2758e3a37d74.author: Seneca

f3668fde-4461-4a9b-b148-dbd01ceca4d2.text: Poverty will keep for you your true and tried friends; you will be rid of the men who were not seeking you for yourself, but for something which you have.
f3668fde-4461-4a9b-b148-dbd01ceca4d2.author: Seneca

595897d0-f9ff-4ed6-97d5-a9f1550044c3.text: Preserve a sense of proportion in your attitude to everything that pleases you, and make the most of them while they are at their best.
595897d0-f9ff-4ed6-97d5-a9f1550044c3.author: Seneca

45e7d7bc-3765-4412-9f89-6e3c290241e7.text: Prosperity does not elevate the sage and adversity does not depress him. For he has always made the effort to rely as much as possible on himself and to derive all delight from himself.
45e7d7bc-3765-4412-9f89-6e3c290241e7.author: Seneca

c36fd2df-1ce7-4764-8767-9eb828f63cb8.text: Prove - and an easy task it is - that so-called pleasures, when they go beyond a certain limit, are but punishments...
c36fd2df-1ce7-4764-8767-9eb828f63cb8.author: Seneca

d9eddea6-0c68-4e45-a804-52656448db58.text: Providence which could be spoken of, almost according to choice or context, under a variety of names or descriptions including the divine reason, creative reason, nature.
d9eddea6-0c68-4e45-a804-52656448db58.author: Seneca

2179ad28-325a-4086-aeca-7d70e6b4767a.text: Read good books many times, rather than many books.
2179ad28-325a-4086-aeca-7d70e6b4767a.author: Seneca

e8c8d907-17b3-4d28-8154-15dec35ab1b4.text: Reading of many books is distraction.
e8c8d907-17b3-4d28-8154-15dec35ab1b4.author: Seneca

5bcee390-25fe-4e9e-89a3-04201c09f75e.text: Reason shows us there is nothing either good or bad but thinking makes it so.
5bcee390-25fe-4e9e-89a3-04201c09f75e.author: Seneca

e3a1e0db-254c-436a-8901-9dde9215f212.text: Reasons for anxiety will never be lacking, whether born of prosperity or of wretchedness; life pushes on in a succession of engrossments. We shall always pray for leisure, but never enjoy it.
e3a1e0db-254c-436a-8901-9dde9215f212.author: Seneca

af1fcad1-7312-437d-9ef4-803904c0c0ed.text: Reflect how pleasant it is to demand nothing, how noble it is to be contented and not to be dependent upon Fortune.
af1fcad1-7312-437d-9ef4-803904c0c0ed.author: Seneca

5326dfea-c08e-4ca0-8cb0-451b08f33617.text: Reflect that nothing merits admiration except the spirit, the impressiveness of which prevents it from being impressed by anything.
5326dfea-c08e-4ca0-8cb0-451b08f33617.author: Seneca

dfb51619-f9b5-4eb6-abb0-f329bde3762c.text: Regard a friend as loyal, and you will make him loyal.
dfb51619-f9b5-4eb6-abb0-f329bde3762c.author: Seneca

a24a2232-e87f-4af5-a8b1-28022ab0f8e4.text: Religion is regarded by the common people as true, by the wise as false, and by rulers as useful.
a24a2232-e87f-4af5-a8b1-28022ab0f8e4.author: Seneca

603ef924-1c18-4789-9598-485f99cc6013.text: Religion is regarded by the common people as true, by the wise as false, and by the rulers as useful.
603ef924-1c18-4789-9598-485f99cc6013.author: Seneca

d6b916eb-20e5-4bff-9dce-2ac08d8e59d6.text: Religion is regarded by the ignorant as true, by the wise as false, and by the rulers as useful.
d6b916eb-20e5-4bff-9dce-2ac08d8e59d6.author: Seneca

49ed3b30-05ec-4f1b-8a1e-2cdcd9675889.text: Restless people often pretend to be calm.
49ed3b30-05ec-4f1b-8a1e-2cdcd9675889.author: Seneca

a9e87d3b-1f05-4533-8e5f-39ec4845f3c1.text: Revenge is an admission that we have been hurt. That cannot be a great mind which is disturbed by injury. He who has hurt you must be either stronger or weaker than yourself. If he be weaker, spare him: if he be stronger, spare yourself.
a9e87d3b-1f05-4533-8e5f-39ec4845f3c1.author: Seneca

049ebe58-e696-44aa-a155-71ad4748048e.text: Set aside a certain number of days, during which you shall be content with the scantiest and cheapest fare, with coarse and rough dress, saying to yourself the while: "Is this the condition that I feared?"
049ebe58-e696-44aa-a155-71ad4748048e.author: Seneca

d875fe4a-afb1-40dd-b4e2-4c40b692b98d.text: Set aside a certain number of days, during which you shall be content with the scantiest and cheapest fare, with course and rough dress, saying to yourself the while: 'Is this the condition that I feared?
d875fe4a-afb1-40dd-b4e2-4c40b692b98d.author: Seneca

185f3c0d-c636-4e53-86fa-78f3b73907b8.text: Shall I tell you what philosophy holds out to humanity? Counsel.
185f3c0d-c636-4e53-86fa-78f3b73907b8.author: Seneca

90c08abc-1510-4e80-bc68-7e5972d80f27.text: Silently time sneaks up on you, each hour  gone is followed by a worse one.
90c08abc-1510-4e80-bc68-7e5972d80f27.author: Seneca

14358722-d950-4cc3-99ca-928f8f09aab8.text: Similarly, too rich a soil makes the grain fall flat, branches break down under too heavy a load, excessive productiveness does not bring fruit to ripeness.
14358722-d950-4cc3-99ca-928f8f09aab8.author: Seneca

5c754ff5-3aed-4813-a39c-62d3636e99b6.text: Since nature allows us to enter into a partnership with every age, why not turn from this brief and transient spell of time and give ourselves wholeheartedly to the past, which is limitless and eternal and can be shared with better men than we?
5c754ff5-3aed-4813-a39c-62d3636e99b6.author: Seneca

2869a709-d7fc-4ec7-9731-77b90ed99e25.text: Since the mind when distracted absorbs nothing deeply, but rejects everything which is, so to speak, crammed into it.
2869a709-d7fc-4ec7-9731-77b90ed99e25.author: Seneca

759402a7-e594-4c78-bc54-5b2445be49a8.text: So I have never believed that there was any genuine good in the things which everyone prays for; what is more, I have found them empty and daubed with showy and deceptive colours, with nothing inside to match their appearance.
759402a7-e594-4c78-bc54-5b2445be49a8.author: Seneca

5fe73ddb-91d6-41ab-8f57-ac4cfced88d0.text: So it is inevitable that life will be not just very short but very miserable for those who acquire by great toil what they must keep by greater toil.
5fe73ddb-91d6-41ab-8f57-ac4cfced88d0.author: Seneca

19b1ced5-453d-4332-b1a2-a4fc08c22d75.text: So it is: we are not given a short life but we make it short, and we are not Ill-supplied but wasteful of it.
19b1ced5-453d-4332-b1a2-a4fc08c22d75.author: Seneca

11ca5b9d-4c5c-4306-9eed-10429603cbfb.text: So long as you live, keep learning how to live.
11ca5b9d-4c5c-4306-9eed-10429603cbfb.author: Seneca

cf547461-39bc-4571-9656-bb324fb45aae.text: So the life of a philosopher extends widely: he is not confined by the same boundary as are others. He alone is free from the laws that limit the human race, and all ages serve him as though he were a god.
cf547461-39bc-4571-9656-bb324fb45aae.author: Seneca

b74ab40b-ec5a-4686-9e18-ddbac990f2fa.text: So the man who restrains himself within the bounds set by nature will not notice poverty; the man who exceeds these bounds will be pursued by poverty however rich he.
b74ab40b-ec5a-4686-9e18-ddbac990f2fa.author: Seneca

70da239e-4a2d-4fa3-b353-9174fdd17fa8.text: So you must match time’s swiftness with your speed in using it, and you must drink quickly as though from a rapid stream that will not always flow.
70da239e-4a2d-4fa3-b353-9174fdd17fa8.author: Seneca

3164b8d8-fd5c-4b36-94a4-e8e5e6a33dde.text: Socrates made the same remark to one who complained; he said: "Why do you wonder that globe-trotting does not help you, seeing that you always take yourself with you? The reason which set you wandering is ever at your heels."
3164b8d8-fd5c-4b36-94a4-e8e5e6a33dde.author: Seneca

dd024d4b-8f06-47a4-b68e-ea043cfe595e.text: Soft living imposes on us the penalty of debility; we cease to be able to do the things we've long been grudging about doing.
dd024d4b-8f06-47a4-b68e-ea043cfe595e.author: Seneca

7dcf1221-8820-4154-b81b-d9cb1269c9d9.text: Some men have shrunk so far into dark corners that objects in bright daylight seem quite blurred to them.’ A.
7dcf1221-8820-4154-b81b-d9cb1269c9d9.author: Seneca

b10b5092-9d04-4708-82d4-ba50e7a5f8c7.text: Some vices delight them as being proofs of their prosperity; it seems the part of a man who is very lowly and despicable to know what he is doing.
b10b5092-9d04-4708-82d4-ba50e7a5f8c7.author: Seneca

c53555d3-d0db-4a9b-9f76-76771188f312.text: Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.
c53555d3-d0db-4a9b-9f76-76771188f312.author: Seneca

688d19b7-5024-4bc7-b6d6-941d1d6b3cda.text: Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.”   Anger.
688d19b7-5024-4bc7-b6d6-941d1d6b3cda.author: Seneca

85b1914b-0251-4d2b-9105-ad98153fe5d7.text: Sometimes, even to live is an act of courage.
85b1914b-0251-4d2b-9105-ad98153fe5d7.author: Seneca

d53fdd32-a265-46c2-b7ac-adab15cf1dfb.text: Sorrowers tend to avoid what they are most fond of and try to give vent to their grief.
d53fdd32-a265-46c2-b7ac-adab15cf1dfb.author: Seneca

e81636f9-1f6b-473b-9e83-fe63b6290e9d.text: Speak ill of yourself when by yourself; then you will become accustomed both to speak and to hear the truth.
e81636f9-1f6b-473b-9e83-fe63b6290e9d.author: Seneca

5ed08a59-1aa6-4e94-a8fd-c0d47d759041.text: Spurn everything that is added by way of decoration and display by unneccesary labour. Relect that nothing merits admiration except the spirit, the impressiveness of which prevents it from being impressed by anything.
5ed08a59-1aa6-4e94-a8fd-c0d47d759041.author: Seneca

50023499-73a2-49d7-b3e5-51a9673f6c83.text: Stolid pack-animals are much more fit for carrying loads than thoroughbred horses: who ever subdued their noble speed with a heavy burden?
50023499-73a2-49d7-b3e5-51a9673f6c83.author: Seneca

b22ada8c-73e3-4b2b-b81c-712ad046bb67.text: Stop preventing philosophers from possessing money; no one has condemned wisdom to poverty. I will despise whatever lies in the domain of Fortune, but if a choice is offered, I will choose the better half.
b22ada8c-73e3-4b2b-b81c-712ad046bb67.author: Seneca

44132f0b-2210-4f47-a6a0-fdd696a382f5.text: That advocate is lionized throughout the whole forum, and fills all the place with a great crowd that stretches farther than he can be heard, yet he says: “When will vacation time come?”
44132f0b-2210-4f47-a6a0-fdd696a382f5.author: Seneca

5dd18d40-e9ea-42d8-84cf-3ac233bfd48b.text: That day, which you fear as being the end of all things, is the birthday of your eternity.
5dd18d40-e9ea-42d8-84cf-3ac233bfd48b.author: Seneca

20a3c565-e1d0-44db-aadc-e96e7533921c.text: That deed and word should be in accord, that a man should be equal to himself under all conditions, and always the same.
20a3c565-e1d0-44db-aadc-e96e7533921c.author: Seneca

f96555bd-1034-46ec-831b-edfb0bb537fc.text: That man who had prayed for the fasces, when he attains them, desires to lay them aside and says over and over: “When will this year be over!”
f96555bd-1034-46ec-831b-edfb0bb537fc.author: Seneca

f207ceda-e08a-412d-8714-f70d5926d42a.text: That which Fortune has not given, she cannot take away.
f207ceda-e08a-412d-8714-f70d5926d42a.author: Seneca

c34a0b0b-13e2-4c59-bf11-6b140c7f7706.text: That which takes effect by chance is not an art.
c34a0b0b-13e2-4c59-bf11-6b140c7f7706.author: Seneca

593c31ca-e8b8-4d6a-b569-81520e92b4f9.text: The acquisition of riches has been for many men, not an end, but a change, of troubles.
593c31ca-e8b8-4d6a-b569-81520e92b4f9.author: Seneca

601424fa-4526-4859-ab9f-8df06314cb62.text: The amount of life we truly live is small. For our existence on Earth is not Life, but merely Time.
601424fa-4526-4859-ab9f-8df06314cb62.author: Seneca

eecd079f-6f93-45e6-8604-35bf5a0e0668.text: The belly will not listen to advice; it makes demands, it importunes. And yet it is not a troublesome creditor; you can send it away at small cost, provided only that you give it what you owe, not merely all you are able to.
eecd079f-6f93-45e6-8604-35bf5a0e0668.author: Seneca

248adae2-6ee7-4cb5-b6af-fbc3357ceb17.text: The best compromise between love and good sense is both to feel longing and to conquer it.
248adae2-6ee7-4cb5-b6af-fbc3357ceb17.author: Seneca

6a6b8db8-0e4c-47ba-a89d-2e3e7d7eb9d8.text: The best ideas are common property.
6a6b8db8-0e4c-47ba-a89d-2e3e7d7eb9d8.author: Seneca

843b2659-3a75-4aaf-96dc-80207690d542.text: The body’s needs are few: it wants to be free from cold, to banish hunger and thirst with nourishment; if we long for anything more we are exerting ourselves to serve our vices, not our needs.
843b2659-3a75-4aaf-96dc-80207690d542.author: Seneca

30e17c31-6431-4661-a8ed-b12757bb3db0.text: The boon that could be given can be withdrawn.
30e17c31-6431-4661-a8ed-b12757bb3db0.author: Seneca

7fefb78b-2b03-42c6-bcdf-68ec83c36a53.text: The bravest sight in the world is to see a great man struggling against adversity.
7fefb78b-2b03-42c6-bcdf-68ec83c36a53.author: Seneca

424243b6-6f58-41be-b525-d9e391c46f40.text: The busy man is busy with everything except living; there is nothing that is more difficult to learn how to do right.
424243b6-6f58-41be-b525-d9e391c46f40.author: Seneca

89ae971a-d92b-46d7-b3b5-40150e80b246.text: The busy man remains rooted to the ground, ever stuck in the present, a time so brief that it cannot be grasped, and thus it is stolen from him, busy as he is with so many things.
89ae971a-d92b-46d7-b3b5-40150e80b246.author: Seneca

f99d3b63-f2d8-4116-8061-e0bfd474618b.text: The day which we fear as our last  is but the birthday of eternity.
f99d3b63-f2d8-4116-8061-e0bfd474618b.author: Seneca

04ac00fc-759a-40d9-9061-99ea43e2ca44.text: The day which we fear as our last is but the birthday of eternity.
04ac00fc-759a-40d9-9061-99ea43e2ca44.author: Seneca

156de4d1-6200-4885-84dc-487ae2c6f330.text: The day which we fear is out last is buth the birthday of eternity.
156de4d1-6200-4885-84dc-487ae2c6f330.author: Seneca

73610c64-bc38-481c-9082-56ae5bf9d58f.text: The difficulty comes from our lack of confidence.
73610c64-bc38-481c-9082-56ae5bf9d58f.author: Seneca

6475a609-57d1-4a17-b240-cadfa952acf7.text: The fates lead those who will those who won't they drag.
6475a609-57d1-4a17-b240-cadfa952acf7.author: Seneca

e224836c-cbe9-4e5e-b66f-172060f7bbbe.text: The final hour when we cease to exist does not itself bring death; it merely of itself completes the death-process. We reach death at that moment, but  we have been a long time on the way.
e224836c-cbe9-4e5e-b66f-172060f7bbbe.author: Seneca

8ce8205e-3195-443b-82b8-aee22f34eb0f.text: The first thing which philosophy undertakes to give is fellow-feeling with all men; in other words, sympathy and sociability.
8ce8205e-3195-443b-82b8-aee22f34eb0f.author: Seneca

96340194-067f-4652-97d7-e5209fe9c97e.text: The fool's life is empty of gratitude and full of fears; its course lies wholly toward the future.
96340194-067f-4652-97d7-e5209fe9c97e.author: Seneca

50634cad-f8c7-4f01-8d51-c977fd2060fa.text: The fool, with all his other faults, has this also, he is always getting ready to live.
50634cad-f8c7-4f01-8d51-c977fd2060fa.author: Seneca

c32889dd-71ee-415d-b303-d464d165b754.text: The geat blessing of mankind are within us and within our reach; but we shut our eyes, and like people in the dark, we fall foul upon the very thing we search for, without finding it.
c32889dd-71ee-415d-b303-d464d165b754.author: Seneca

a67202c9-a517-409b-9f8f-049b684df436.text: The geometrician teaches me how I may avoid losing any fraction of my estates, but what I really want to learn is how to lose the lot and still keep smiling.
a67202c9-a517-409b-9f8f-049b684df436.author: Seneca

d572f461-2ce1-424a-b78f-21b9d519ab8f.text: The greatest hindrance to living is expectancy, which depends upon the morrow and wastes to-day.
d572f461-2ce1-424a-b78f-21b9d519ab8f.author: Seneca

e40d69c3-6375-4dda-b242-8d0f7336d7cc.text: The greatest loss of time is delay and expectation, which depend upon the future. We let go the present, which we have in our power, and look forward to that which depends upon chance, and so relinquish a certainty for an uncertainty.
e40d69c3-6375-4dda-b242-8d0f7336d7cc.author: Seneca

95fe8c2c-c5cd-44c4-b49d-a27b1bd95ad8.text: The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow and loses today.
95fe8c2c-c5cd-44c4-b49d-a27b1bd95ad8.author: Seneca

8ba6687d-b39b-47bf-9d3a-dd1bb5e3a787.text: The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow and loses today. You are arranging what is in Fortune's control and abandoning what lies in yours.
8ba6687d-b39b-47bf-9d3a-dd1bb5e3a787.author: Seneca

609f5056-143c-4011-ad02-9e580701cb9a.text: The grief that has been conquered by reason is calmed for ever.
609f5056-143c-4011-ad02-9e580701cb9a.author: Seneca

6c00fb47-e3ef-4f39-98c2-4dfe17c8217f.text: The happy life is a life that is in harmony with its own nature.
6c00fb47-e3ef-4f39-98c2-4dfe17c8217f.author: Seneca

ce6e1b24-1d85-4f35-8984-76cfd82157d3.text: The happy man is satisfied with his present situation, no matter what it is, and eyes his fortune with contentment; the happy man is the one who permits reason to evaluate every condition of his existence.
ce6e1b24-1d85-4f35-8984-76cfd82157d3.author: Seneca

51fb6467-a8a8-4e9d-ae2c-1aeb3b6f597a.text: The highest good is a mind that scorns the happenings of chance, and rejoices only in virtue.
51fb6467-a8a8-4e9d-ae2c-1aeb3b6f597a.author: Seneca

fccd51b8-91b0-48f8-9f76-18d5e8888df5.text: The liberal arts do not conduct the soul all the way to virtue, but merely set it going in that direction.
fccd51b8-91b0-48f8-9f76-18d5e8888df5.author: Seneca

b5a306ad-3e3f-4bf3-b6e1-04d3e074abc5.text: The man who fears death will never do anything worthy of a man who is alive.
b5a306ad-3e3f-4bf3-b6e1-04d3e074abc5.author: Seneca

451ccb9b-8921-4d3e-bc1f-aa0ebd53536c.text: The man who has anticipated the coming of troubles takes away their power when they arrive.
451ccb9b-8921-4d3e-bc1f-aa0ebd53536c.author: Seneca

6658b912-3382-4e39-b311-792a1506283d.text: The man who looks for the morrow without worrying over it knows a peaceful independence and a happiness beyond all others. Whoever has said, "I have lived" receives a windfall every day he gets up in the morning.
6658b912-3382-4e39-b311-792a1506283d.author: Seneca

75fa1f4f-4ba1-4173-95c2-d8ed39c40b53.text: The man who spends all his time on his own needs, who organizes every day as though it were his last, neither longs for nor fears the next day.
75fa1f4f-4ba1-4173-95c2-d8ed39c40b53.author: Seneca

391dbf51-d3f9-4d75-9789-1265e7144d75.text: The man who spends his time choosing one resort after another in a hunt for peace and quiet will in every place he visits find something to prevent him from relaxing.
391dbf51-d3f9-4d75-9789-1265e7144d75.author: Seneca

6085dc6c-50a3-4350-be25-e1281cb1be90.text: The man who tries to find out what has been said against him, who seeks to unearth spiteful gossip, even when engaged in privately, is destroying his own peace of mind.
6085dc6c-50a3-4350-be25-e1281cb1be90.author: Seneca

962dc194-4d7a-4426-b78d-a824f278eb90.text: The mind is never right but when it is at peace with itself.
962dc194-4d7a-4426-b78d-a824f278eb90.author: Seneca

3c634b3d-3572-4f08-be18-bd18be6fb980.text: The mind that is anxious about future events is miserable.
3c634b3d-3572-4f08-be18-bd18be6fb980.author: Seneca

0889049c-5127-4d79-a8c5-4d367c1aa5d7.text: The mind when distracted absorbs nothing deeply.
0889049c-5127-4d79-a8c5-4d367c1aa5d7.author: Seneca

fe5159ea-8160-4976-a270-c4413f743302.text: The more a mind takes in the more it expands.
fe5159ea-8160-4976-a270-c4413f743302.author: Seneca

5b5a10a6-1b30-4197-9694-3ba765184431.text: The one to whom nothing was refused, whose tears were always wiped away by an anxious mother, will not abide being offended.
5b5a10a6-1b30-4197-9694-3ba765184431.author: Seneca

a71e0f34-683f-4dd6-bcd1-346b9766bde1.text: The only really leisured people are those who devote time to acquiring true knowledge rather than trivia. .
a71e0f34-683f-4dd6-bcd1-346b9766bde1.author: Seneca

c7006251-96b4-4cc9-9d5b-db7454e22195.text: The other side shall be heard as well.
c7006251-96b4-4cc9-9d5b-db7454e22195.author: Seneca

c69119e9-0455-4866-bac5-2d804585776a.text: The part of life we really live is small. For all the rest of existence is not life, but merely time.
c69119e9-0455-4866-bac5-2d804585776a.author: Seneca

34fa4a02-8fa1-4b60-a7dc-3f297dab19f0.text: The past is ours, and there is nothing more secure for us than that which has been. We are ungrateful for past gains, because we hope for the future, as if the future – if so be that any future is ours – will not be quickly blended with the past.
34fa4a02-8fa1-4b60-a7dc-3f297dab19f0.author: Seneca

342960e3-f8c7-44a5-948d-ed1b6d43c6cd.text: The preoccupied become aware of it only when it is over.
342960e3-f8c7-44a5-948d-ed1b6d43c6cd.author: Seneca

3683751d-85a0-40b6-a8df-733bbc31641e.text: The present alone can make no man wretched.
3683751d-85a0-40b6-a8df-733bbc31641e.author: Seneca

7145bfa3-6b92-401f-b27e-6fd8a2041e9b.text: The primary indication, to my thinking, of a well-ordered mind is a man's ability to remain in one place and linger in his own company.
7145bfa3-6b92-401f-b27e-6fd8a2041e9b.author: Seneca

6a46656a-40f9-4b23-9dde-bb3b4e143636.text: The problem, Paulinus, is not that we have a short life, but that we waste time.
6a46656a-40f9-4b23-9dde-bb3b4e143636.author: Seneca

ca69d76f-a4b2-43b1-934c-20b79fb1490a.text: The road is long if one proceeds by way of precepts but short and effectual if by way of personal example.
ca69d76f-a4b2-43b1-934c-20b79fb1490a.author: Seneca

39b62cfb-96c8-4661-98f2-0e5c6177b2f5.text: The shortest route to wealth is the contempt of wealth.
39b62cfb-96c8-4661-98f2-0e5c6177b2f5.author: Seneca

065300ba-8061-48b6-83d2-700fae6b74a7.text: The sun also shines on the wicked.
065300ba-8061-48b6-83d2-700fae6b74a7.author: Seneca

dd962043-c7c8-49b0-a39b-7abcddd0d178.text: The supreme ideal does not call for any external aids. It is homegrown, wholly self-developed. Once it starts looking outside itself for any part of itself it is on the way to being dominated by fortune.
dd962043-c7c8-49b0-a39b-7abcddd0d178.author: Seneca

2f8eac27-bbf4-4d43-ac1d-f3b3be9683a8.text: The surest way for those who want to rule  is praising moderation, talking of peace and quiet.
2f8eac27-bbf4-4d43-ac1d-f3b3be9683a8.author: Seneca

24e40c9e-2995-41dd-a3f1-bc9525174890.text: The things that are indispensable require no elaborate pains for their acquisition; it is only the luxuries that call for labour. Follow nature, and you will need no skilled craftsmen.
24e40c9e-2995-41dd-a3f1-bc9525174890.author: Seneca

a2d953a6-1463-4837-a527-ca2ca079d046.text: The time of the actual enjoyment is short and swift, and made much shorter through their own fault. For they dash from one pleasure to another and cannot stay steady in one desire.
a2d953a6-1463-4837-a527-ca2ca079d046.author: Seneca

530b5c58-3ae8-4224-81a2-75037a96fdb6.text: The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.
530b5c58-3ae8-4224-81a2-75037a96fdb6.author: Seneca

2a7b94c5-fb75-476f-929f-dece1f15b783.text: The willing, Destiny guides them. The unwilling, Destiny drags them.
2a7b94c5-fb75-476f-929f-dece1f15b783.author: Seneca

3abef40b-4c61-4ee0-ab35-aa809f8c73c4.text: The wise man is self-sufficient, that he can do without friends, not that he desires to do without them. When I say "can," I mean this: he endures the loss of a friend with equanimity.
3abef40b-4c61-4ee0-ab35-aa809f8c73c4.author: Seneca

5373621e-e37a-4fea-8823-bb0e68980d58.text: The wise man regards the reason for all his actions, but not the results.
5373621e-e37a-4fea-8823-bb0e68980d58.author: Seneca

aa06d3da-dfaf-4de4-98c8-929fd6d7f2c7.text: The wise man, he said, lacked nothing but needed a great number of things, whereas 'the fool, on the other hand, needs nothing (for he does not know how to use anything) but lack everything.
aa06d3da-dfaf-4de4-98c8-929fd6d7f2c7.author: Seneca

a0ad8bd8-6245-447b-8d0a-e27913c1d1b7.text: The young character, which cannot hold fast to righteousness, must be rescued from the mob.
a0ad8bd8-6245-447b-8d0a-e27913c1d1b7.author: Seneca

e1899d60-d50f-4715-b077-f35e9017ab75.text: Then they reflect how pointlessly they acquired things they never would enjoy, and how all their toil has been in vain.
e1899d60-d50f-4715-b077-f35e9017ab75.author: Seneca

612646d1-6786-4595-825a-d2b511a650d2.text: There are a few men whom slavery holds fast, but there are many more who hold fast to slavery.
612646d1-6786-4595-825a-d2b511a650d2.author: Seneca

a18942ce-31eb-41f7-a48b-ee8e4f300cf3.text: There are more things likely to frighten us than there are to crush us; we suffer more in our imagination than in reality.
a18942ce-31eb-41f7-a48b-ee8e4f300cf3.author: Seneca

3afa2cc5-3a43-4dfd-b9f7-ff912648eba0.text: There are more things to alarm us than to harm us, and we suffer more often in apprehension than reality.
3afa2cc5-3a43-4dfd-b9f7-ff912648eba0.author: Seneca

a56e9b75-a91a-42b9-adc4-e33174656f83.text: There are more things, Lucilius, likely to frighten us than there are to crush us; we suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
a56e9b75-a91a-42b9-adc4-e33174656f83.author: Seneca

a43aea96-d039-4c41-8c4e-29f8345bb9bd.text: There can be no place of exile within the world since nothing within the world is alien to men.
a43aea96-d039-4c41-8c4e-29f8345bb9bd.author: Seneca

1acf0f94-a857-413b-a3cb-942227e78671.text: There has never been a great mind without some degree of madness.
1acf0f94-a857-413b-a3cb-942227e78671.author: Seneca

1ac531dd-031b-4142-8960-3731d8bf562b.text: There is a sequence about the creative process, and a work of genius is a synthesis of its individual features from which nothing can be subtracted without disaster.
1ac531dd-031b-4142-8960-3731d8bf562b.author: Seneca

46e501a3-14c2-4c88-8180-b7c9d2db7b61.text: There is an old adage about gladiators, - that they plan their fight in the ring.
46e501a3-14c2-4c88-8180-b7c9d2db7b61.author: Seneca

03e5a273-a163-47ca-9753-bb3a249c60c1.text: There is but one chain holding us in fetters, and that is our love of life.
03e5a273-a163-47ca-9753-bb3a249c60c1.author: Seneca

149aa8a1-c648-4109-895c-f72a6c928fdb.text: There is never a time when new distraction will not show up; we sow them, so several will grow from the same seed.
149aa8a1-c648-4109-895c-f72a6c928fdb.author: Seneca

b592d3d2-6579-45f7-9b6b-672965aa853c.text: There is no easy way from the earth to the stars.
b592d3d2-6579-45f7-9b6b-672965aa853c.author: Seneca

4acefc9c-c9d5-4c27-a789-803a0debb3bb.text: There is no enjoying the possession of anything valuable unless one has someone to share it with.
4acefc9c-c9d5-4c27-a789-803a0debb3bb.author: Seneca

f2092fe2-6c4a-4979-95c2-e6e4e9a0ac57.text: There is no favorable wind for the sailor who doesn’t know where to go.
f2092fe2-6c4a-4979-95c2-e6e4e9a0ac57.author: Seneca

6e84603f-1c94-4b6e-97c1-c52a98e400ca.text: There is no genius without a touch of madness.
6e84603f-1c94-4b6e-97c1-c52a98e400ca.author: Seneca

b602d7c0-6def-4549-9b24-b9bed03a958d.text: There is no great genius without a tincture of madness.
b602d7c0-6def-4549-9b24-b9bed03a958d.author: Seneca

5da6e515-5784-4606-9dfe-0115ff31031c.text: There is no great genius without some touch of madness.
5da6e515-5784-4606-9dfe-0115ff31031c.author: Seneca

24444b00-0703-47e5-9e7a-bd907b203b82.text: There is no great genius without tincture of madness.
24444b00-0703-47e5-9e7a-bd907b203b82.author: Seneca

6c2cf162-123d-4503-892a-4d7fbd40ba40.text: There is no need to complain of particular grievances, for life in its entirety is lamentable.
6c2cf162-123d-4503-892a-4d7fbd40ba40.author: Seneca

318c8a09-7907-4728-8ff4-738000b1261a.text: There is no such thing as good or bad fortune for the individual; we live in common.
318c8a09-7907-4728-8ff4-738000b1261a.author: Seneca

215e114e-0900-4d06-9575-a682d89818ba.text: There is no worse penalty for vice than the fact that it is dissatisfied with itself and all its fellows.
215e114e-0900-4d06-9575-a682d89818ba.author: Seneca

a6573cea-d734-47e3-beee-bf8d1ca347db.text: There is nothing in the world so much admired as a man who knows how to bear unhappiness with courage.
a6573cea-d734-47e3-beee-bf8d1ca347db.author: Seneca

d72f2135-0c6f-48c5-ae6d-891529fd4184.text: There is nothing the busy man is less busied with than living:  there is nothing that is harder to learn.
d72f2135-0c6f-48c5-ae6d-891529fd4184.author: Seneca

d224e96b-78ea-4a39-9174-036e99a606f2.text: There is nothing the wise man does reluctantly. He escapes necessity because he wills what necessity is going to force on him.
d224e96b-78ea-4a39-9174-036e99a606f2.author: Seneca

42c7d7c5-73c2-4b66-9d5a-5f0b8b2d2eca.text: There is only one relief for great sufferings, and that is to endure and surrender to their compulsion.
42c7d7c5-73c2-4b66-9d5a-5f0b8b2d2eca.author: Seneca

f9652ec5-629d-4c66-8e05-ea59c8b1ec5a.text: There will always be causes for anxiety, whether due to prosperity or to wretchedness. Life will be driven on through a succession of preoccupations: we shall always long for leisure, but never enjoy it.
f9652ec5-629d-4c66-8e05-ea59c8b1ec5a.author: Seneca

a4824d5d-a1af-4f6c-836b-e28f6f2be9f7.text: Therefore it is better to conquer our grief than to deceive it. For if it has withdrawn, being merely beguiled by pleasures and preoccupations, it starts up again and from its very respite gains force to savage us.
a4824d5d-a1af-4f6c-836b-e28f6f2be9f7.author: Seneca

ffdc6df1-8c84-46d0-9744-58e2795a86d4.text: Therefore whenever his last day comes, the wise man will not hesitate to meet death with a firm step.
ffdc6df1-8c84-46d0-9744-58e2795a86d4.author: Seneca

72fa4d77-e5ab-47eb-a034-8146dabc5e74.text: Therefore, my dear Lucilius, begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life. He who has thus prepared himself, he whose daily life has been a rounded whole, is easy in his mind.
72fa4d77-e5ab-47eb-a034-8146dabc5e74.author: Seneca

941ac773-0017-41ce-9aa9-2fbea7b744d6.text: Therefore, nothing ought to be unexpected by us. Our minds should be sent forward in advance to meet all problems, and we should consider, not what is wont to happen, but what can happen.
941ac773-0017-41ce-9aa9-2fbea7b744d6.author: Seneca

0c437ef8-91fd-4ad9-aea2-7e3e634863b5.text: Theseus: What is the crime for which you must pay by death? Phaedra: My life.
0c437ef8-91fd-4ad9-aea2-7e3e634863b5.author: Seneca

8d32828e-ad41-4704-9719-8d9d48eca4a4.text: They are like prowling enemies who pounce on you when occasion offers, and allow you neither to be at the ready as in war nor at ease as in peace.
8d32828e-ad41-4704-9719-8d9d48eca4a4.author: Seneca

f40ad54b-3c89-4c73-825f-dcc2b5e527cf.text: They lose the day in expectation of the night, and the night in fear of the dawn.
f40ad54b-3c89-4c73-825f-dcc2b5e527cf.author: Seneca

8dee10ee-2407-4c4f-bad5-b2204a163d68.text: They lose the day in waiting for the night, and the night in fearing the dawn.
8dee10ee-2407-4c4f-bad5-b2204a163d68.author: Seneca

a11dcbcb-62db-4a6e-a7b0-f77d1a140d8d.text: Think for a long time whether or not you should admit a given person to your friendship. But when you have decided to do so, welcome him heart and soul, and speak as unreservedly with him as you would with yourself.
a11dcbcb-62db-4a6e-a7b0-f77d1a140d8d.author: Seneca

b462a09e-501a-4e1b-96fd-cdfaafce70ca.text: Think your way through difficulties: harsh conditions can be softened, restricted ones can be widened, and heavy ones can weigh less on those who know how to bear them.
b462a09e-501a-4e1b-96fd-cdfaafce70ca.author: Seneca

5bd5a446-a2fb-4a37-a43a-4259f634682a.text: This evil of taking our cue from others has become so deeply ingrained that even that most basic feeling, grief, degenerates into imitation.
5bd5a446-a2fb-4a37-a43a-4259f634682a.author: Seneca

7cc38e0e-5a3a-497d-96e9-3acf6249328a.text: This will not be a gentle prescription for healing, but cautery and the knife. What shall I achieve? That a soul which has conquered so many miseries will be ashamed to worry about one more wound in a body which already has so many scars.
7cc38e0e-5a3a-497d-96e9-3acf6249328a.author: Seneca

784d21ac-b271-446a-a3c6-7fd19a3ff74d.text: This wretched body, the chain and prison of the soul, is tossed hither and thither; upon it punishment and pillage and disease wreak havoc: but the soul itself is holy and eternal, and it cannot be assailed with violence.
784d21ac-b271-446a-a3c6-7fd19a3ff74d.author: Seneca

2413571c-b322-4fc1-aa76-2f95160988e5.text: This, I say, is the highest duty and the highest proof of wisdom, – that deed and word should be in accord, that.
2413571c-b322-4fc1-aa76-2f95160988e5.author: Seneca

399e0cfc-9027-4107-b7fe-b5ea82278fd8.text: Those who are busy with other things do not notice it until the end comes.
399e0cfc-9027-4107-b7fe-b5ea82278fd8.author: Seneca

261df9f7-a268-4598-bfcc-ebacef0e432e.text: Those who choose to have no real purpose in life are ever rootless and dissatisfied, tossed by their aimlessness into ever-changing situations.
261df9f7-a268-4598-bfcc-ebacef0e432e.author: Seneca

bc2ddd90-3f73-4751-8e13-6125fc795301.text: Those who forget the past, ignore the present, and fear for the future have a life that is very brief and filled with anxiety.
bc2ddd90-3f73-4751-8e13-6125fc795301.author: Seneca

2d05e86f-879a-4de3-8dcf-10046c462eed.text: Those who forget the past, neglect the present, and fear for the future have a life that is very brief and troubled. They lose the day in expectation of the night, and the night in fear of the dawn.
2d05e86f-879a-4de3-8dcf-10046c462eed.author: Seneca

d5c4a870-e1e0-46f5-95bb-8bc2a48f9c32.text: Those who lack self-control lead disturbed and tumultuous lives; their crimes are balanced by their fears, and they are never at ease.
d5c4a870-e1e0-46f5-95bb-8bc2a48f9c32.author: Seneca

d49a2909-9693-4f3b-83e1-2b0edef38137.text: Throw aside all hindrances and give up your time to attaining a sound mind.
d49a2909-9693-4f3b-83e1-2b0edef38137.author: Seneca

8a3da32f-ea1e-4c15-967d-d6df62e7c3bc.text: Thus far, you have indeed not been sluggish, but you must quicken your pace. Much toil remains; to confront it, you must yourself lavish all your waking hours, and all your efforts, if you wish the result to be accomplished.
8a3da32f-ea1e-4c15-967d-d6df62e7c3bc.author: Seneca

8ca1985e-401a-4ceb-a83a-6e8094eec376.text: Thus the time we are given is not brief, but we make it so. We do not lack time; on the contrary, there is so much of it that we waste an awful lot.
8ca1985e-401a-4ceb-a83a-6e8094eec376.author: Seneca

e2a11141-581c-4b23-a1b7-6cfe2e2758cd.text: Timendi causa est nescire -  Ignorance is the cause of fear.
e2a11141-581c-4b23-a1b7-6cfe2e2758cd.author: Seneca

e7b09e69-0f54-442b-97a9-ae2b0aa74f31.text: To be always fortunate, and to pass through life with a soul that has never known sorrow, is to be ignorant of one half of nature.
e7b09e69-0f54-442b-97a9-ae2b0aa74f31.author: Seneca

7db79006-84d6-4ee5-9fc1-33928414a872.text: To be everywhere is to be nowhere.
7db79006-84d6-4ee5-9fc1-33928414a872.author: Seneca

31f639cd-23d0-4b63-a835-662527efcf63.text: To be everywhere, is to be no where at all.
31f639cd-23d0-4b63-a835-662527efcf63.author: Seneca

2abf2b2a-c567-4e0d-b602-f7f3afa6bc77.text: To be everywhere; is to be nowhere.
2abf2b2a-c567-4e0d-b602-f7f3afa6bc77.author: Seneca

e2873f1c-a1f5-44fc-816c-ffc8207aa922.text: To be everywhere; is to nowhere.
e2873f1c-a1f5-44fc-816c-ffc8207aa922.author: Seneca

b3e37fc3-7964-4b9e-afdb-d7b689225543.text: To consort with the crowd is harmful; there is no person who does not make some vice attractive to us, or stamp it upon us, or taint us unconsciously therewith.
b3e37fc3-7964-4b9e-afdb-d7b689225543.author: Seneca

5305e5ac-60fd-4963-b896-84af13684ac7.text: To expect punishment is to suffer it; and to earn it is to expect it.
5305e5ac-60fd-4963-b896-84af13684ac7.author: Seneca

0500cea8-eb30-4aec-9d86-95d2124c672a.text: To have may be taken from us, to have had, never. A man is thankless in the highest degree if, after losing something, he feels no obligation for having received it.
0500cea8-eb30-4aec-9d86-95d2124c672a.author: Seneca

a8cd7d40-3963-455c-a9f5-8a1a1413f3d8.text: To know how many are jealous of you, count your admirers.
a8cd7d40-3963-455c-a9f5-8a1a1413f3d8.author: Seneca

556fd944-b6c4-4548-a509-138200743f26.text: To live under constraint is a misfortune, but there is no constraint to live under constraint.
556fd944-b6c4-4548-a509-138200743f26.author: Seneca

cba51bb9-315c-439d-a190-4b91edfed03c.text: To make Pythocles rich, do not add to his store of money, but subtract from his desires.
cba51bb9-315c-439d-a190-4b91edfed03c.author: Seneca

4883a52f-6a83-4714-ae14-8948cd4eab28.text: To reduce your worry, you must assume that what you fear may happen is certainly going to happen.
4883a52f-6a83-4714-ae14-8948cd4eab28.author: Seneca

c0d81a73-22b3-487f-8b1d-d53fd43d413a.text: To what lengths would so precocious an ambition not go?
c0d81a73-22b3-487f-8b1d-d53fd43d413a.author: Seneca

77c6d431-7f14-47f2-b2e0-2ba646defc07.text: To win true freeedom you must be a slave to philosophy.
77c6d431-7f14-47f2-b2e0-2ba646defc07.author: Seneca

2d3d952d-12d1-47f0-858e-d1385ac3ea57.text: To wish to be well is a part of becoming well.
2d3d952d-12d1-47f0-858e-d1385ac3ea57.author: Seneca

6c0e7e32-9e9b-48a2-8199-0adb0913e2d9.text: Treat your inferiors in the way in which you would like to be treated by your own superiors. And whenever it strikes you how much power you have over your slave, let it also strike you that your own master has just as much power over you.
6c0e7e32-9e9b-48a2-8199-0adb0913e2d9.author: Seneca

792ad17c-7186-426e-9dcd-2aa9356845ae.text: True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future, not to amuse ourselves with either hopes or fears but to rest satisfied with what we have, which is sufficient, for he that is so wants nothing.
792ad17c-7186-426e-9dcd-2aa9356845ae.author: Seneca

fa6fde51-b68a-44b3-a299-ee5a19a5e6ac.text: True happiness is... to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.
fa6fde51-b68a-44b3-a299-ee5a19a5e6ac.author: Seneca

32a6f84e-297c-4086-bfdb-6ebb96a0aac1.text: Truth often harms the one who digs it up.
32a6f84e-297c-4086-bfdb-6ebb96a0aac1.author: Seneca

01200119-8ae8-44a3-9656-b3470707334a.text: Ubicumque ex aequo ad caelum erigitur acies, paribus intervallis omnia divina ab omnibus humanis distant - From whatever point on the earth's surface you look up to heaven the same distance lies between the realms of gods and men.
01200119-8ae8-44a3-9656-b3470707334a.author: Seneca

8469f2ee-11a4-4af0-9cdc-68f7b463fa9d.text: Unblest is he who thinks himself unblest.
8469f2ee-11a4-4af0-9cdc-68f7b463fa9d.author: Seneca

018375d0-7b1a-4aa3-a859-b9f58ef237f9.text: Unbroken prosperity cannot bear a single blow; but he who has waged an unceasing strife with his misfortunes has gained a thicker skin by his sufferings, yields to no disaster, and even though he fall yet fights on his knee.
018375d0-7b1a-4aa3-a859-b9f58ef237f9.author: Seneca

bcc19b43-14c7-4b84-b5ee-516df798268c.text: Undisturbed by fears and unspoiled by pleasures, we shall be afraid neither of death nor the gods.
bcc19b43-14c7-4b84-b5ee-516df798268c.author: Seneca

9302382b-64f0-46df-ab57-0f24d5f53d89.text: Unless we are complete ingrates, the lives of all those men that preceded us should be seen as sacred. Their collective existence paved the way for our own time on Earth.
9302382b-64f0-46df-ab57-0f24d5f53d89.author: Seneca

486d76c4-5953-409b-9b30-c684298f57c1.text: Until we have begun to go without them, we fail to realize how unnecessary many things are. We've been using them not because we needed them but because we had them.
486d76c4-5953-409b-9b30-c684298f57c1.author: Seneca

1b31a3e0-8bcd-48cd-9416-eb76f110b93a.text: Vices have to be crushed rather than picked at.
1b31a3e0-8bcd-48cd-9416-eb76f110b93a.author: Seneca

3befbaed-fc3b-47cb-8f5c-d4322e895d04.text: Virtue is according to nature; vice is opposed to it and hostile.
3befbaed-fc3b-47cb-8f5c-d4322e895d04.author: Seneca

616fd404-f259-41ce-87e7-99f12c041394.text: Virtue is not vouchsafed to a soul unless that soul has been trained and taught, and by unremitting practice brought to perfection.
616fd404-f259-41ce-87e7-99f12c041394.author: Seneca

43ca9c21-d8cc-4d5a-87bb-59727876fc6c.text: We abandon nature and surrender to the mob – who are never good advisers in anything, and in this respect as in all others are most inconsistent.
43ca9c21-d8cc-4d5a-87bb-59727876fc6c.author: Seneca

eea0d875-e27d-44c2-98eb-432e323322c9.text: We all rush through life torn between a desire for the future and a weariness of the present. But he who devotes his time to his own needs, who plans out every day as if it were his last, neither longs for nor fears for tomorrow.
eea0d875-e27d-44c2-98eb-432e323322c9.author: Seneca

c0eb9448-4c75-4a3b-8b48-fadcc6349a06.text: We always feel anger longer than we feel hurt.
c0eb9448-4c75-4a3b-8b48-fadcc6349a06.author: Seneca

3ce0370f-0898-4992-8067-a57c9f974129.text: We are all bound by this oath: "To bear the ills of mortal life, and to submit with a good grace to what we cannot avoid."
3ce0370f-0898-4992-8067-a57c9f974129.author: Seneca

64f293a0-aa9a-466f-9801-0d008aa6b5c2.text: We are born under circumstances that would be favorable if we did not abandon them. It was nature's intention that there should be no need of great equipment for a good life: every individual can make himself happy.
64f293a0-aa9a-466f-9801-0d008aa6b5c2.author: Seneca

9f43f0db-b672-4cfc-9c14-dab51681a084.text: We are born under circumstances that would be favourable if we did not abandon them.
9f43f0db-b672-4cfc-9c14-dab51681a084.author: Seneca

edfe08fe-4d6c-4157-b7b2-19ff83fa63ea.text: We are frightened at uncertainties, just as if they were certain. We observe no moderation. The slightest thing turns the scales and throws us forthwith into a panic.
edfe08fe-4d6c-4157-b7b2-19ff83fa63ea.author: Seneca

55f8b114-79c2-4c1d-8f7a-8032b338de8a.text: We are in the habit of saying that it was not in our power to choose the parents who were allotted to us, that they were given to us by chance. But we can choose whose children we would like to be.
55f8b114-79c2-4c1d-8f7a-8032b338de8a.author: Seneca

95ac127f-ab08-4240-9e20-35cbf367f0fc.text: We are indeed apt to ascribe certain faults to the place or to the time; but those faults will follow us, no matter how we change our place.
95ac127f-ab08-4240-9e20-35cbf367f0fc.author: Seneca

373a4f26-738b-47c7-a019-7d77bcaa10c2.text: We are indeed apt to ascribe certain faults to the place or to the time; but those faults will follow us, no matter how we change our place.  You.
373a4f26-738b-47c7-a019-7d77bcaa10c2.author: Seneca

947fbe10-b8a3-4956-ab0c-c08c79979e61.text: We are mad, not only individually but nationally. We check manslaughter and isolated murders, but what of war and the much-vaunted crime of slaughtering whole peoples?
947fbe10-b8a3-4956-ab0c-c08c79979e61.author: Seneca

1c891109-3f44-4d09-89b1-bc1c2c927597.text: We are members of one great body, planted by nature…. We must consider that we were born for the good of the whole.
1c891109-3f44-4d09-89b1-bc1c2c927597.author: Seneca

b870d947-ee28-41c8-909a-59edd4e31e60.text: We are mistaken when we look forward to death; the major portion of death has already passed, Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.
b870d947-ee28-41c8-909a-59edd4e31e60.author: Seneca

7356184f-8fcd-40f3-be15-28f42fe96b63.text: We are more often frightened than hurt; and we suffer more from imagination than from reality.
7356184f-8fcd-40f3-be15-28f42fe96b63.author: Seneca

e9cf86d2-c8d4-4d41-84bc-ca158d96243e.text: We are not given a short life but we make it short, and we are not ill-supplied but wasteful of it.
e9cf86d2-c8d4-4d41-84bc-ca158d96243e.author: Seneca

032542a0-77a9-4256-aa6b-dc1fdf8c735e.text: We are not given a short life but we make it short... Life is long if you know how to use it.
032542a0-77a9-4256-aa6b-dc1fdf8c735e.author: Seneca

ddc9608d-ed41-471e-85db-0d4f901521af.text: We are weak, watery beings standing in the midst of unrealities; therefore let us turn our minds to the things that are everlasting.
ddc9608d-ed41-471e-85db-0d4f901521af.author: Seneca

1237fdc9-05e1-43b0-979c-7fd0ac3926df.text: We are wont to say that it was not in our power to choose the parents who fell to our lot, that they have been given to men by chance; yet we may be the sons of whomsoever we will.
1237fdc9-05e1-43b0-979c-7fd0ac3926df.author: Seneca

c973d6ca-3118-465f-b66e-f267cd7602bb.text: We cease to be so angry once we cease to be so hopeful.
c973d6ca-3118-465f-b66e-f267cd7602bb.author: Seneca

ea80caf2-69a0-4322-aeaa-f4ebe3a3ad4b.text: We deceive ourselves in thinking that death only follows life whereas it both goes before and will follow after it for where is the difference in not beginning or ceasing to exist the effect of both is not to be.
ea80caf2-69a0-4322-aeaa-f4ebe3a3ad4b.author: Seneca

48bdf969-3ef5-4ee6-b49f-57ec4f693e2d.text: We do not need many words, but, rather, effective words.
48bdf969-3ef5-4ee6-b49f-57ec4f693e2d.author: Seneca

a3ad79b8-e2ac-4212-a91f-427fa793c602.text: We do not receive a life that is short, but rather we make it so.
a3ad79b8-e2ac-4212-a91f-427fa793c602.author: Seneca

a6ed6bbb-4e8d-464b-981a-1ab5b6bab4f8.text: We do not receive a life that is short, but rather we make it so; we are not beggar in it, but spendthrifts.
a6ed6bbb-4e8d-464b-981a-1ab5b6bab4f8.author: Seneca

b1b4da3d-489b-493c-abfc-58c6f916ee5d.text: We learn not in the school, but in life.
b1b4da3d-489b-493c-abfc-58c6f916ee5d.author: Seneca

1d840005-8b7f-4789-8cfe-1d3e037fd1a1.text: We live among wicked man through our own wickedness. One thing alone can bring us peace, an agreement to treat one another with kindness.
1d840005-8b7f-4789-8cfe-1d3e037fd1a1.author: Seneca

f973b8b7-748b-4dfb-80f0-1e158773c90d.text: We must indulge the mind and from time to time allow it the leisure which is its food and strength.
f973b8b7-748b-4dfb-80f0-1e158773c90d.author: Seneca

fd398683-1c2a-4219-bccf-9ba005a0bc95.text: We must, therefore, take a less serious view of all things, tolerating them in a spirit of acceptance: It is more human to laugh at life than to weep tears over it.
fd398683-1c2a-4219-bccf-9ba005a0bc95.author: Seneca

fb0a188b-21d2-4e70-bcd4-b5cba2a65c27.text: We ought frequently to remind ourselves that we must love the things of this life as we would what is shortly to leave us, or indeed in the very act of leaving us.
fb0a188b-21d2-4e70-bcd4-b5cba2a65c27.author: Seneca

fca6defc-b1d4-448b-889f-c7a49f879962.text: We ought not, therefore, to give over our hearts for good to any one part of the world. We should live with the conviction: 'I wasn't born for one particular corner: the whole world's my home country.
fca6defc-b1d4-448b-889f-c7a49f879962.author: Seneca

22fdad40-e7b8-44ad-9c8b-1b9779a2866f.text: We ought not, therefore, to give over our hearts for good to any one part of the world. We should live with the conviction: 'I wasn‟t born for one particular corner: the whole world‟s my home country.
22fdad40-e7b8-44ad-9c8b-1b9779a2866f.author: Seneca

dd1523d2-4c7e-4f9b-bbb2-7ffd070dd25f.text: We perish because we follow other men's examples: we should be cured of this if we were to disengage ourselves from the herd.
dd1523d2-4c7e-4f9b-bbb2-7ffd070dd25f.author: Seneca

578f9b6d-8894-4311-8c12-c1b4da5327ef.text: We shall be rich with all the more comfort, if we once learn how far poverty is from being a burden.
578f9b6d-8894-4311-8c12-c1b4da5327ef.author: Seneca

45792287-446e-45b3-8517-31517938f5ed.text: We shall consider later whether these evils derive their power from their own strength, or from our own weakness.
45792287-446e-45b3-8517-31517938f5ed.author: Seneca

18708d06-900b-43fc-9a6e-bb25697bcf88.text: We should conduct ourselves not as if we ought to live for the body, but as if we could not live without it. Our too great love for it makes us restless with fears, burdens us with cares, and exposes us to insults.
18708d06-900b-43fc-9a6e-bb25697bcf88.author: Seneca

ff5d0ed4-00d6-43db-80df-7a8cba7f7db5.text: We should every night call ourselves to an account;  What infirmity have I mastered today?  What passions opposed? What temptation resisted? What virtue acquired? Our vices will abort of themselves if they be brought every day to the shrift.
ff5d0ed4-00d6-43db-80df-7a8cba7f7db5.author: Seneca

2e3a3bc4-b9f9-4cda-bbc8-b07c875a51f8.text: We should often withdraw into ourselves; for mixing with persons of dissimilar natures throws into disorder our settled composure and wakens our passions anew, exacerbating whatever is weak in the mind and not properly healed.
2e3a3bc4-b9f9-4cda-bbc8-b07c875a51f8.author: Seneca

b46580bb-6432-4d33-a68f-f1676fedb38d.text: We Stoics are not subjects of a despot: each of us lays claim to his own freedom.
b46580bb-6432-4d33-a68f-f1676fedb38d.author: Seneca

55c1be43-8cc1-4b53-b891-8c35c2bbb12e.text: We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
55c1be43-8cc1-4b53-b891-8c35c2bbb12e.author: Seneca

00ccfc8a-f75b-4958-9f06-025cd7dd6c24.text: Wealth however limited, if it is entrusted to a good guardian, increases by use.
00ccfc8a-f75b-4958-9f06-025cd7dd6c24.author: Seneca

481c1da9-af1e-472f-bea7-ffcd567ddb6f.text: Wealth is the slave of a wise man. The master of a fool.
481c1da9-af1e-472f-bea7-ffcd567ddb6f.author: Seneca

8c4bd1a5-8eb0-4dd6-b0ce-59137549038a.text: Wealth is the slave of the wise man and master of the fool.
8c4bd1a5-8eb0-4dd6-b0ce-59137549038a.author: Seneca

af904e5b-837e-4262-b9f3-0906745f228f.text: Weigh carefully your hopes as well as your fears, and whenever all the elements are in doubt, decide in your own favour; believe what you prefer.
af904e5b-837e-4262-b9f3-0906745f228f.author: Seneca

c87fdda4-06f9-469b-a171-cc7dfe9d0bbe.text: What Chance has made yours is not really yours.
c87fdda4-06f9-469b-a171-cc7dfe9d0bbe.author: Seneca

772a521a-1c05-488e-855e-4c8e44ef28bc.text: What difference does it make, after all, what your position in life is if you dislike it yourself?
772a521a-1c05-488e-855e-4c8e44ef28bc.author: Seneca

f9c7d629-380c-49f7-8265-de969178d4d9.text: What fortune has made yours is not your own.
f9c7d629-380c-49f7-8265-de969178d4d9.author: Seneca

65089184-38aa-4598-ad25-9fb327f15490.text: What good does it do you to go overseas, to move from city to city? If you really want to escape the things that harass you, what you’re needing is not to be in a different place but to be a different person.
65089184-38aa-4598-ad25-9fb327f15490.author: Seneca

b42ff6d0-71cc-4155-ac68-3850d5752aaf.text: What is death? Either a transition or an end. I am not afraid of coming to an end, this being the same as never having begun, nor of transition, for I shall never be in confinement quite so cramped anywhere else as I am here.
b42ff6d0-71cc-4155-ac68-3850d5752aaf.author: Seneca

c8e18445-3245-43ee-86fb-3855447b15ec.text: What is freedom, you ask?  It means not being a slave to any circumstance, to any constraint, to any chance; it.
c8e18445-3245-43ee-86fb-3855447b15ec.author: Seneca

10166d2a-7ab5-470f-8d4b-1d4f412ebeba.text: What is harder than rock? What is softer than water? Yet hard rocks are hollowed out by soft water?
10166d2a-7ab5-470f-8d4b-1d4f412ebeba.author: Seneca

691515b0-73ec-46d1-be8c-bdc2b4e357c8.text: What is sweeter than to be so valued by one's wife that one becomes more valuable to oneself for this reason? Hence my dear Paulina is able to make me responsible, not only for her fears, but also for my own.
691515b0-73ec-46d1-be8c-bdc2b4e357c8.author: Seneca

f0cf0967-635b-4b28-90e8-77c05fab676a.text: What man can you show me who places any value on his time, who reckons the worth of each day, who understands that he is dying daily?
f0cf0967-635b-4b28-90e8-77c05fab676a.author: Seneca

1f046450-fb3c-4f6c-af0a-7754dbc8f1e6.text: What mental darkness, what ignorance of the truth blinds those who, though afflicted by the fear of poverty, yet take pleasure in imitating it!
1f046450-fb3c-4f6c-af0a-7754dbc8f1e6.author: Seneca

a186b5cf-f7c2-42c1-ad20-3252c08e04d2.text: What need is there to weep over parts of life? The whole of it calls for tears.
a186b5cf-f7c2-42c1-ad20-3252c08e04d2.author: Seneca

507642b1-f103-4c12-af02-5b622fe57da8.text: What progress, you ask, have I made? I have begun to be a friend to myself.
507642b1-f103-4c12-af02-5b622fe57da8.author: Seneca

5d3b765a-31cd-473c-b9b8-9a28bb3b1ab3.text: What really ruins our character is the fact that none of us looks back over his life.
5d3b765a-31cd-473c-b9b8-9a28bb3b1ab3.author: Seneca

a8fee5e4-9a5c-4cd5-86e2-489dc3ba0c90.text: What shall we not go in fear of if we fear that which cowardice itself has chosen for its refuge?
a8fee5e4-9a5c-4cd5-86e2-489dc3ba0c90.author: Seneca

2525adfc-f671-4f10-b680-e289c10394d6.text: What then is good? The knowledge of things. What is evil? The lack of knowledge of things.
2525adfc-f671-4f10-b680-e289c10394d6.author: Seneca

e3c61c0e-ddbe-4c36-b23f-d54905de22cb.text: What's the good of dragging up sufferings which are over, of being unhappy now just because you were then?
e3c61c0e-ddbe-4c36-b23f-d54905de22cb.author: Seneca

5a851e81-c6df-44cc-bf90-7e8644139a8e.text: What's the use of overcoming opponent after opponent in the wrestling or boxing rings if you can be overcome by your temper?
5a851e81-c6df-44cc-bf90-7e8644139a8e.author: Seneca

eda8737f-d4c9-4d41-bb05-cbb80c929cb0.text: Whatever can happen at any time can happen today.
eda8737f-d4c9-4d41-bb05-cbb80c929cb0.author: Seneca

603038ce-19e3-4ce1-b540-a20278581ea8.text: Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.
603038ce-19e3-4ce1-b540-a20278581ea8.author: Seneca

6d2a62bb-ab2a-4513-962c-c584fecaa978.text: When a man does not know what harbor he is making for, no wind is the right wind.
6d2a62bb-ab2a-4513-962c-c584fecaa978.author: Seneca

dba49ff0-834e-4e10-82a1-2b1a87ba1d6c.text: When a mind is impressionable and has none too firm a hold on what is right, it must be rescued from the crowd: it is so easy for it to go over to the majority.
dba49ff0-834e-4e10-82a1-2b1a87ba1d6c.author: Seneca

30ac7100-91f4-4f9e-981b-ce50dc8dd7b1.text: When a person spends all his time in foreign travel, he ends by having many acquaintances, but no friends.
30ac7100-91f4-4f9e-981b-ce50dc8dd7b1.author: Seneca

525617d1-ac7e-4c64-98d0-75b0f2383fa1.text: When a soul rises superior to other souls, when it is under control, when it passes through every experience as if it were of small account, when it smiles at our fears and at our prayers, it is stirred by a force from heaven.
525617d1-ac7e-4c64-98d0-75b0f2383fa1.author: Seneca

11a1b4c3-6e6b-4350-8d36-aa7d8f0f2e23.text: When arrogant hands once seize power, the ruler thinks authority resides in stubbornness.
11a1b4c3-6e6b-4350-8d36-aa7d8f0f2e23.author: Seneca

1f62642d-b5b6-46dc-97a7-3c5dd09b865e.text: When one is busy and absorbed in one's work, the very absorption affords great delight; but when one has withdrawn one's hand from the completed masterpiece, the pleasure is not so keen.
1f62642d-b5b6-46dc-97a7-3c5dd09b865e.author: Seneca

fa653d52-07d5-4f85-92ec-224499d3fb12.text: When things are at their worst,  there are no tears.
fa653d52-07d5-4f85-92ec-224499d3fb12.author: Seneca

df01f329-6c61-4df5-a71b-2e8d14e2d090.text: When we have done everything within our power, we shall possess a great deal: but we once possessed the world.
df01f329-6c61-4df5-a71b-2e8d14e2d090.author: Seneca

fd2ce1ea-6911-4b57-9e97-12b6ec121696.text: When Zeno received news of a shipwreck and heard that all his luggage had been sunk he said, "Fortune bids me to be a less encumbered philosopher."
fd2ce1ea-6911-4b57-9e97-12b6ec121696.author: Seneca

c290ae7c-048c-4098-bdb4-74a3cfeb903e.text: When Zeno received news of a shipwreck and heard that all his luggage had been sunk he said, 'Fortune bids me to be a less encumbered philosopher.
c290ae7c-048c-4098-bdb4-74a3cfeb903e.author: Seneca

f69d754b-ca05-432b-aa6f-1d3f165a4ebe.text: When Zeno received news of a shipwreck and heard that all his luggage had been sunk he said, “Fortune bids me to be a less encumbered philosopher.”
f69d754b-ca05-432b-aa6f-1d3f165a4ebe.author: Seneca

1e2abb11-a147-47c8-9ef0-fc155eb9fa4d.text: Whenever I wish to enjoy the quips of a clown, I am not compelled to hunt far; I can laugh at myself.
1e2abb11-a147-47c8-9ef0-fc155eb9fa4d.author: Seneca

8b1f178e-38bc-439d-9c77-5c3444836018.text: Where you arrive does not matter as much as what sort of person you are when you arrive there.
8b1f178e-38bc-439d-9c77-5c3444836018.author: Seneca

adf5d060-668f-4a82-96dc-a44b9c65af01.text: Where you arrive does not matter so much as what sort of person you are when you arrive there.
adf5d060-668f-4a82-96dc-a44b9c65af01.author: Seneca

b0f35af1-6a69-4af9-9bc2-6652831e3f50.text: Where, then, lies the mistake, since all men crave the happy life?  It is that they regard the means for producing happiness as happiness itself, and, while seeking happiness, they are really fleeing from it.
b0f35af1-6a69-4af9-9bc2-6652831e3f50.author: Seneca

b51fdd69-0d30-4146-b10b-8adbdd0fad1e.text: Wherever there is a human being, there is an opportunity for a kindness.
b51fdd69-0d30-4146-b10b-8adbdd0fad1e.author: Seneca

09912131-6d1f-49ff-a6c7-3a4e6ead9a35.text: Wherever there is a human being, there is an opportunity for crisis.
09912131-6d1f-49ff-a6c7-3a4e6ead9a35.author: Seneca

1546d23d-d33a-4c36-94a8-4a94fedd1392.text: While the fates permit, live happily; life speeds on with hurried step, and with winged days the wheel of the headlong year is turned.
1546d23d-d33a-4c36-94a8-4a94fedd1392.author: Seneca

7b89628c-ec81-4275-9bca-c401ed13cb56.text: While we are postponing, life speeds by.
7b89628c-ec81-4275-9bca-c401ed13cb56.author: Seneca

1aae13fd-8e31-407c-a69f-82cdd2ac80a6.text: While we wait for life, life passes.
1aae13fd-8e31-407c-a69f-82cdd2ac80a6.author: Seneca

8ea50623-9168-4978-848a-13f0a4428595.text: Who as though inspired with divine utterance sings salutary verses: Life.
8ea50623-9168-4978-848a-13f0a4428595.author: Seneca

4b0d8a96-2165-44ce-9ea6-80a56dcac38e.text: Who can doubt, my dear Lucilius, that life is the gift of the immortal gods, but that living well is the gift of philosophy?
4b0d8a96-2165-44ce-9ea6-80a56dcac38e.author: Seneca

540232a3-e5d3-47e1-b476-1c6ea0b1a61c.text: Who scorns his own life is lord of yours.
540232a3-e5d3-47e1-b476-1c6ea0b1a61c.author: Seneca

78447a8c-d6cd-4128-ae24-b3126983c984.text: Why do I not rather seek some real good - one which I could feel, not one which I could display? These things that draw the eyes of men, before which they halt, which they show to one another in wonder, outwardly glitter, but are worthless within.
78447a8c-d6cd-4128-ae24-b3126983c984.author: Seneca

b2cc1a5c-5e9e-4fb2-b311-75e2c410ec74.text: Why do you voluntarily deceive yourself and require to be told now for the first time what fate it is that you have long been labouring under? Take my word for it: since the day you were born you are being led thither.
b2cc1a5c-5e9e-4fb2-b311-75e2c410ec74.author: Seneca

057aea39-08e4-463f-a262-414825331df5.text: Why do you wonder that globe-trotting does not help you, seeing that you always take yourself with you? The reason which set you wandering is ever at your heels.
057aea39-08e4-463f-a262-414825331df5.author: Seneca

c26c0eca-2b0e-4b59-83b9-d5d74bb1b95f.text: Why need we weep over parts of our life? the whole of it calls for tears: new miseries assail us before we have freed ourselves from the old ones.
c26c0eca-2b0e-4b59-83b9-d5d74bb1b95f.author: Seneca

1416df02-ce5d-415b-ad83-42cd6cc79626.text: Why not stop trying to prevent posterity being silent about you? You were born to die, and a silent funeral is less bothersome.
1416df02-ce5d-415b-ad83-42cd6cc79626.author: Seneca

bd9d0663-5b92-4813-a2c2-d1b77e3b60d5.text: Why should I demand of Fortune that she give rather than demand of myself that I should not crave? .
bd9d0663-5b92-4813-a2c2-d1b77e3b60d5.author: Seneca

dfe2628c-5c18-4dc4-9499-29cf7b395a1e.text: Withdraw into yourself, as far as you can. Associate with those who will make a better man of you. Welcome those whom you yourself can improve. The process is mutual; for men learn while they teach.
dfe2628c-5c18-4dc4-9499-29cf7b395a1e.author: Seneca

eb85061c-ad66-4d6c-b0ee-f9297095be50.text: Words need to be sown like seeds. No matter how tiny a seed may be, when in lands in the right sort of ground it unfolds its strength and from being minute expands and grows to a massive size.
eb85061c-ad66-4d6c-b0ee-f9297095be50.author: Seneca

af1d1d76-44d7-4f5c-b5e0-17e36584c514.text: Would you rather be poor and sated, or rich and hungry? Prosperity is not only greedy, but it also lies exposed to the greed of others. And as long as nothing satisfies you, you yourself cannot satisfy others.
af1d1d76-44d7-4f5c-b5e0-17e36584c514.author: Seneca

5e65d890-2e34-4c00-96e1-d06576913c17.text: Write something therefore in a simple style, merely to pass the time, for your own use, and not for publication. Less labour is needed when one does not look beyond the present." Then.
5e65d890-2e34-4c00-96e1-d06576913c17.author: Seneca

3a4ffb0e-99b1-47db-856e-abbfbad87c4c.text: You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire.
3a4ffb0e-99b1-47db-856e-abbfbad87c4c.author: Seneca

ba78d34d-0bba-4267-aa55-9fdd7e09d6c6.text: You are retained as counsel for unhappy mankind. You have promised to help those in peril by sea, those in captivity, the sick and the needy, and those whose heads are under the poised axe. Whither are you straying? What are you doing?
ba78d34d-0bba-4267-aa55-9fdd7e09d6c6.author: Seneca

7e1e8984-5ebb-48c0-89da-96158094608c.text: You are unfortunate in my judgment, for you have never been unfortunate. You have passed through life with no antagonist to face you; no one will know what you were capable of, not even you yourself.
7e1e8984-5ebb-48c0-89da-96158094608c.author: Seneca

8f381e25-2e7e-4a62-af03-8976ad219711.text: You ask what is the proper limit to a person's wealth? First, having what is essential, and second, having what is enough.
8f381e25-2e7e-4a62-af03-8976ad219711.author: Seneca

7943815c-7576-4dee-996f-16b99087bde0.text: You can put up with a change of place if only the place is changed.
7943815c-7576-4dee-996f-16b99087bde0.author: Seneca

a2c62654-b75d-468e-972f-e491c76c900d.text: You can tell the character of every man when you see how he receives praise.”   Difficult.
a2c62654-b75d-468e-972f-e491c76c900d.author: Seneca

c20bdbd1-8a9f-44b0-9ac2-aa508a5185bf.text: You fear everything as mortals but desire to have everything as gods.
c20bdbd1-8a9f-44b0-9ac2-aa508a5185bf.author: Seneca

4565134b-ddca-4359-9968-d028cf85c469.text: You have all the fears of mortals and all the desires of immortals.
4565134b-ddca-4359-9968-d028cf85c469.author: Seneca

3aca9e8c-b40f-41a1-b5a7-08fdee534461.text: You live as if you will live forever, no care for your mortality ever enters your head, you pay no mind to how much time has already gone by.
3aca9e8c-b40f-41a1-b5a7-08fdee534461.author: Seneca

961e4de0-cb18-4c13-b4cb-0b1d7480b422.text: You live as though you were going to live for ever, at no time taking thought for your weakness, and you fail to note how much time has already passed by.
961e4de0-cb18-4c13-b4cb-0b1d7480b422.author: Seneca

64b351b7-589c-4536-924c-1fd8ac2125a4.text: You must go to the scene of action, first, because men put more faith in their eyes than in their ears, and second, because the way is long if one follows precepts, but short and helpful, if one follows patterns.
64b351b7-589c-4536-924c-1fd8ac2125a4.author: Seneca

82e60e04-93be-47fa-b70d-0e673cc82ae0.text: You must lay aside the burdens of the mind; until you do this, no place will satisfy you.
82e60e04-93be-47fa-b70d-0e673cc82ae0.author: Seneca

6f84e61e-5e3d-46a8-ae77-c88f382d9b62.text: You must linger among a limited number of master thinkers, and digest their works, if you would derive ideas which shall win firm hold in your mind. .
6f84e61e-5e3d-46a8-ae77-c88f382d9b62.author: Seneca

9e2610cf-547b-4a60-9e68-80f3cf4436af.text: You must linger among a limited number of master thinkers, and digest their works, if you would derive ideas which shall win firm hold in your mind. Everywhere means nowhere.
9e2610cf-547b-4a60-9e68-80f3cf4436af.author: Seneca

d51ee97c-e7be-4eab-97ec-5aaf723b6381.text: You must set your hands to tasks which you can finish or at least hope to finish, and avoid those which get bigger as you proceed and do not cease where you had intended.
d51ee97c-e7be-4eab-97ec-5aaf723b6381.author: Seneca

52c96309-7f40-4e88-8268-b5623a9f7ba0.text: You must vie with time's swiftness in the speed of using it, and, as from a torrent that rushes by and will not always flow, you must drink quickly.
52c96309-7f40-4e88-8268-b5623a9f7ba0.author: Seneca

9235cdfa-0807-42f8-9bc2-3705a24280d8.text: You should … live in such a way that there is nothing which you could not as easily tell your enemy as keep to yourself.
9235cdfa-0807-42f8-9bc2-3705a24280d8.author: Seneca

6fc4a5ae-e945-43b0-b79d-26615c4c22fc.text: You should, I need hardly say, live in such a way that there is nothing which you could not as easily tell your enemy as keep to yourself.
6fc4a5ae-e945-43b0-b79d-26615c4c22fc.author: Seneca

0bf12f00-2875-48da-aafe-53ba4271ca72.text: You will notice that the most powerful and highly stationed men let drop remarks in which they pray for leisure, praise it, and rate it higher than all their blessings.
0bf12f00-2875-48da-aafe-53ba4271ca72.author: Seneca

300f2648-2867-4e19-a556-2f1090c9472f.text: Your greatest difficulty is with yourself; for you are your own stumbling-block.
300f2648-2867-4e19-a556-2f1090c9472f.author: Seneca
